CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Computer lab-enhanced instruction examines nature and purposes of financial accounting theory, procedures and reporting for economic entities including financial statements and valuation. This course develops foundation knowledge for additional learning in subsequent courses. (2 hrs. lecture, 2 hrs. laboratory) No prerequisite. Offered on: A-E-G / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Demonstrate understanding of fundamental accounting topics including:
    1. Recording transactions using the double-entry system
    2. Adjustments for accruals and deferrals
    3. Standard and required financial statements
    4. Merchandising operations
    5. Inventory
    6. Working capital
    7. Receivables and payables
    8. Long-lived assets and depreciation
    9. Equity financing
  2. Utilize accounting software.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Computerized enhanced instruction develops accounting principles and procedures as applied to partnerships and corporations. Designed primarily for students anticipating careers in accounting or who otherwise require detailed understanding of financial accounting practices. Prerequisite: ACC101. Offered on: A-E-G / 4 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Have a more thorough understanding of basic principles learned in ACC101/AC11.
  2. Understand fundamental accounting topics such as:
    1. Generally accepted accounting principles
    2. Partnerships
    3. Corporations
    4. Analysis of financial statements
    5. Statements of cash flow
    6. Debt and equity investments
    7. Bond and mortgage obligations
    8. The use of accounting as a tool for management
  3. Utilize accounting software.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Emphasis on attention-directing and problem-solving functions of accounting with respect to management planning and controlling fiscal activities. Recommended for all students outside accounting emphasis. Prerequisite: ACC101. Offered on: A-E-G / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Understand the field of management accounting and the role the accountant plays in the business organization
  2. Understand corporation organization and operation, process and job order cost accounting, budgeting and standard system, and cost-volume profit analysis.
  3. Identify the managerial accounting principles to be used in making various economic decisions.
  4. Analyze the role of the managerial accountant in the business world, develop and awareness of the opportunities available in the field of accounting.
  5. Assess current accounting literature through classroom discussion and outside reading assignments.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Includes three practice sets specially designed to provide students opportunity to prepare federal and state tax forms relating to depreciation, payroll, sales tax, corporate income, and franchise taxes. Also covers the one-write system, bank reconciliations and physical inventory procedures. Prerequisite: ACC101. Offered on: A-E-G / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Understand of various business entities and their legal and reporting responsibilities.
  2. Prepare:
    1. Bank reconciliations
    2. Payroll records and tax filings.
    3. Accounting records and financial statements
    4. Tax filings for sole proprietors
    5. Tax filings for partnerships
    6. Tax filings for S corporations
    7. New York State Sales tax forms
    8. Depreciation tax forms.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Introduction to concepts and procedures of fund accounting as applied to government and nonprofit institutions. Topics include principles of fund accounting, appropriations, encumbrances, expenditures, and problems and procedures related to use and control aspects of budgets. Prerequisite: ACC101. Offered on: A-E-G / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Describe the characteristics that distinguish governments and not-for-profit organizations from businesses, and the accounting and reporting implications of these characteristics;
  2. Explain the information requirements of the main users of the financial reports of governments and not-for-profit entities;
  3. Describe the nature of funds, including why they are used and the interrelationship among them;
  4. Account for the basic fund-types used by government – governmental funds, proprietary funds and fiduciary funds;
  5. Prepare the primary financial statements-both government wide and fund- issued by governments;
  6. Explain how the fund structures and financial reports of not-for-profits differ from those of government;
  7. Describe the key purposes of budgets, the various ways of classifying expenditures and the limitations of actual-to-budget comparisons;
  8. Explain why governments focus on current financial resources and use the modified accrual basis to account for their governmental funds;
  9. Account for various (property taxes, fines, sales tax, income taxes, grants) types of revenues;
  10. Employ the modified accrual basis of accounting for expenditures and explain the rationale for the differences between that basis and the full accrual basis;
  11. Explain why and how governments uses capital projects funds to account for resources accumulated to acquire long-lived assets;
  12. Account for debt service funds;
  13. Explain arbitrage and why it concerns governments;
  14. Account for special assessments;
  15. Account for fixed assets;

*These statements must appear verbatim in course outlines. However, additional outcomes may be added to individual course outlines at the instructor’s discretion. Revised 1/10

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Introductory course providing students with real-life exposure to use of major accounting applications programs on a computer. Payroll, receivables, payables, inventory as well as integrated packages are utilized. Prerequisite: ACC101. Offered on: A-E-G / 4 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Understand the capabilities of accounting software and the operational benefits that can be derived from the use of such software.
  2. Setup, operate, and utilize accounting applications programs.
  3. Understand various accounting principles.
  4. Identify, through simulation, accounting activities which occur in the workplace.
  5. Setup company books using program setup process and identify the strengths and weaknesses of this approach.
  6. Set up customized company books and identify the strengths and weaknesses of this approach.
  7. Process customer related transactions and analyze customer reports.
  8. Process vendor related transactions and analyze vendor reports.
  9. Setup and process sales tax requirements.
  10. Setup, process and monitor inventory requirements and analyze inventory reports.
  11. Setup and process payroll transactions & reports.
  12. Generate and analyze financial statements.
  13. Complete the entire accounting cycle in a computerized environment.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Fraud examination will cover the principles and methodology of fraud detection and deterrence. The course includes such topics as skimming, cash larceny, check tampering, register disbursement schemes, billing schemes, payroll and expense reimbursement schemes, non-cash misappropriations, corruption, accounting principles and fraud, fraudulent financial statements and interviewing witnesses. Prerequisite: ACC101. Offered on: E / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Understand the seriousness of the fraud problem
  2. Understand how skimming is committed and concealed
  3. Understand what “lapping” is and how it is used by fraudsters to conceal receivables skimming
  4. Identify cash larceny
  5. Understand how cash receipts schemes differ from fraudulent disbursements
  6. Identify weaknesses in internal controls as inducing factors to cash larceny
  7. Identify the five major categories of fraudulent disbursements
  8. Understand proactive audit tests that can be used to detect billing schemes
  9. Understand how check tampering is hidden in a company’s accounting records
  10. Identify fraud in financial statements
  11. Understand fraud deterrence
  12. Understand and detect concealed liabilities and expenses
  13. Identify red flags associated with fictitious revenues

*These statements must appear verbatim in course outlines. However, additional outcomes may be added to individual course outlines at the instructor’s discretion. Revised 1/10

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Stresses theoretical and analytical aspects of financial accounting. Topics include the Balance Sheet and Income Statement with particular emphasis on current assets, fixed assets and current liabilities. Pertinent pronouncements of the Financial Accounting Standards Board (FASB) are an integral part of the course. Prerequisite: ACC102. Offered on: A-E-G / 4 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Understand the basic assumptions underlying accounting practices.
  2. Analyze accounting literature such as opinions of the Accounting Principles Board of the Financial Accounting Standard Board.
  3. Answer problems which have appeared on the Uniform CPA Exam through homework assignments and classroom discussions.
  4. Identify the basic concepts and principles presented in introductory accounting, emphasizing the theoretical as well as the problem solving aspects of accounting.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Involves same theoretical and analytical approach of ACC102 but topical emphasis is on corporate capital, long-term liabilities, investments, fund flow, analysis, and reconstruction of financial statements. Pertinent pronouncements of the Financial Accounting Standards Board (FASB) are an integral part of the course. Prerequisite: ACC201. Offered on: A-E-G / 4 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Understand of accounting principles an application thereof.
  2. Understand the various accounting concepts introduced in earlier courses.
  3. Employ knowledge in “business” related occupations.
  4. Answer problems which have appeared on the Uniform CPA exam.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Basic principles and procedures of cost accounting and cost control in a manufacturing organization through study of job order, process and standard cost procedures, budgeting, predetermined cost, variance and decision analysis. Prerequisite: ACC102 or ACC115. Offered on: A-E-G / 4 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Understand the basic cost accounting assumptions underlying a manufacturing business.
  2. Analyze the cost accounting system of job, process and standard costing.
  3. Describe the contemporary cost accounting issues and techniques.
  4. Analyze complex cost accounting problems.
  5. Solve the type of cost problems which have previously appeared on the Uniform CPA and CMA examination.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Concentrates on financial and managerial accounting applications with particular emphasis on using advanced spreadsheet financial functions related to recording business transactions; developing adjusted trial balance; preparing financial statements; analyzing and presenting accounts receivable; analyzing inventory; accounting for property, plant, and equipment; examining bonds payable and time value of money; evaluating performance; understanding cost-volume-profit relationships; and capital budgeting supported by spreadsheet graphics, database and macro capabilities. Prerequisite: ACC101 and either ACC137, BUS112, or CST101. Offered on: A-E-G / 4 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Use basic tools of spreadsheet software.
  2. Create and analyze financial graphs and charts.
  3. Prepare program macros into spreadsheet files to facilitate data entry and computation.
  4. Manipulate accounting files through the use of database sorting, finding, extracting and report generating techniques.
  5. Incorporate advanced financial functions into accounting problem solutions.
  6. Routinely utilize the presentation enhancement capabilities of spreadsheet software in accounting reports.
  7. Identify technological advances and resources available to accountants and accounting students.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Introductory course in business financial management. Deals with need for funds within the firm and alternative institutions and financial instruments available. Prerequisite: ACC102. Offered on: A-E-G / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Understand basic financial management principles.
  2. Identify methodologies utilized by financial managers to maximize shareholder wealth.
  3. Understand risk-return implications associated with decisions concerning financial alternatives.
  4. Analyze and develop solutions to complex financial problems.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: History of income taxation, gross income and exclusions therefrom; deductions; credits; exemptions; capital gains; depreciation, inventory and accounting methods; accounting records; preparation and filing of tax returns, with special emphasis on small business and individual taxpayers. Prerequisite: ACC102 or ACC115. Offered on: A-E-G / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Understand federal income tax concepts that affect individual taxpayers and small businesses.

  2. Understand core taxation concepts, such as:

    1. Gross Income and Exclusions
    2. Capital Gains and Losses
    3. Dividends and Interest
    4. Deductions for and from Adjusted Gross Income
    5. Tax Credits
    6. Basis
    7. Estimated Tax
    8. MACRS Tax Depreciation
    9. Alternative Minimum Tax
  1. Apply tax software.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Independent study courses in accounting may be available. See the online catalog for a complete listing or contact academic chair. Offered on: A-E-G / 1-4 cr. hrs.

Introductory course studying broad range of cultural similarities and differences among human populations. Using ethnographic accounts as a database, initial focus is on non-Western cultures. Comparisons with more technologically advanced cultures provide important insights into how culture works. Note: Fulfills SUNY General Education Requirement for Social Sciences and Other World Civilizations. Prerequisite: RDG099 or ESL012 or equivalent. Offered on: A-E-G / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Identify and describe the similarities and differences between the cultural practices of several Non-Western Cultures.
  2. Compare and contrast the cultural elements exhibited in Non-Western Cultures with those of the Western World.
  3. Identify and describe the components, characteristics, and organizational structure of various cultures, which may include language, religion, family, society, economy and politics.
  4. Analyze and discuss the interplay between elements of culture, which may include language, religion, family, society, economy and politics.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Explores fields of paleontology, primatology and human physical variation as they relate to human evolution. Change and stability, adaptation and extinction are major themes. Findings from evolutionary biology, behavioral ecology, and the hominid fossil record are integrated in order to understand the transition from ape to human. Where do we come from? Why do we behave the way we do? Where are we going? No prerequisite. Note: Fulfills SUNY General Education Requirement for Social Sciences. Offered on: A-E-G / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Identify and describe the linkages between findings from the fossil record and the theories of evolutionary biology.
  2. Describe the concepts of change and stability in the context of human adaptation to changes in the physical environment.
  3. Identify and describe the elements of human behavior with respect to changes over an evolutionary time span.
  4. Analyze and discuss the concepts of adaptation and extinction with respect to the human fossil record in a biological framework.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Explores basic concepts and methods of archaeological research, including nature of the archaeological record and how archaeologists generate and analyze data. Excavation, analysis and interpretation of material remains from well-known Old World and New World prehistoric and historic sites are examined. Cultural variation and culture change are major themes. Emphasizes application of these concepts to our own culture. Note: Fulfills SUNY General Education Requirement for Social Sciences and Other World Civilizations. No prerequisite. Offered on: A / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Identify and describe the basic concepts, techniques and methods of archaeological research.
  2. Describe the findings from archaeological studies of well-known sites.
  3. Identify, describe and analyze the cultural elements of various pre-historic and modern societies based upon the findings of archaeological research.
  4. Analyze and discuss past cultures in a modern and current context.
  5. Analyze and discuss the concepts of adaptation and extinction with respect to the human fossil record in a biological framework.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Studies religion as an institution in primitive society. Places emphasis on anthropological methodology as a tool for understanding folk religious systems. Works of such anthropologists as Durkheim, Malinowski, Boas and Levi-Strauss are considered as they pertain to religious development. Application of anthropological methodology is demonstrated by use of North American, South American, Oceanic and African culture areas. Note: Fulfills SUNY General Education Requirement for Social Sciences and Other World Civilizations. Prerequisite: ANT101. Offered on: G / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Employ anthropological methodologies to identify and describe the basic role of religion in small-scale, folk societies, and industrialized societies.
  2. Discuss the relative merits and problems with the theories on religion and culture promulgated by various noted anthropologists.
  3. Apply anthropological methodology and analyze the results of such studies in various regions of the world.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Archaeology, prehistory and traditional development of Native American culture. Explores diversity of American Indian culture in terms of social systems, institutions and behavior patterns. Groups such as the Aztec, Navajo, Pueblo and Eskimo are studied in relation to their environmental adaptation and cultural development. Note: Fulfills SUNY General Education Requirement for Other World Civilizations. Prerequisite: ANT101. Offered on: A / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Identify, describe and analyze the social systems, institutions and behavioral patterns of a diverse array of Native American cultures compare and contrast the development of social systems, institutions and behavioral patterns of a diverse array of Native American cultures.
  2. Apply anthropological methodology and analyze the results of studies related to environmental adaptation and cultural differentiation between several major Native American cultures.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Interdisciplinary study of historical and contemporary elements of diverse cultures in the Caribbean. Topics include history, economics, social institutions, cultural patterns and the arts. May be taken for social science or humanities credit. Note: Fulfills SUNY General Education Requirement for Other World Civilizations. No prerequisite. Offered on: E-G / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Identify, define and describe the critical elements of Caribbean cultures.
  2. Compare and contrast the relationships between the historical, economic, artistic, and social elements of culture among Caribbean cultures.
  3. Employ an interdisciplinary approach to regional study.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Special and current topics in Anthropology may be available. See "Class Schedule Search" for a complete listing each term. Offered on: A-E-G / 3-4 cr. hrs.

Honors special topics in Anthropology may be available for Honors students as well as those who have received permission from campus Honors Program Coordinator. See "Class Schedule Search" for a complete listing each term. Offered on: A-E-G / 3-4 cr. hrs.

Introductory course designed to identify major visual art forms. Includes examination of selected masterpieces through use of films, slides and field trips; also, experience with simple methods and materials to illustrate basic concepts, gain insight into the creative process, and cultivate aesthetic values. Note: Fulfills SUNY General Education Requirement for Humanities and The Arts. No prerequisite. Offered on: A-E-G / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Identify major masterpieces from the Western canon by artist, title and approx. date.
  2. Identify significant personal, period and cultural styles.
  3. Define and correctly apply the formal language specific to art and art history (e.g. line, shape, color etc.).
  4. Describe the function of a work of art in its culture (its reason for existence).
  5. Explain how an object embodies or communicates a major theme of its time period.
  6. Differentiate forms of art (for example, relief sculpture, painting, ceramics).

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Methods and skills students can adopt to promote their success in the Visual Art program and prepare them to transfer successfully into BFA programs. Students will learn the college's expectations, how to manage their time and resources, and how to access college programs and resources to assure a successful educational experience. The art curriculum, prospective transfer schools, and career opportunities in the field of visual art will be discussed throughout the semester. Fulfills College Seminar requirements for students in Visual Arts - A.S. degree. No prerequisite. Offered on: A-G / 1.5 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Discuss with greater insight both educational and career goals to determine areas that may need further development.
  2. Demonstrate basic study skills including time management, goal setting, test and note taking
  3. Synthesize information and procedures for establishing priorities, clarifying values, and determining short- and long-term goals with the career, personal and educational setting
  4. Create a course schedule to prepare for academic advisement throughout their academic study
  5. Effectively use the computer to manage activities at the college including E-mail, Internet usage and course registration, online and with an advisor
  6. Demonstrate library research methods to search for career opportunities within the field of visual arts and to research equipment requirements for a chosen career
  7. Effectively use college resources including academic advisement and career services
  8. Recognize and demonstrate an understanding of the diversity within academic life and one’s personal life as well as the diversity of working as a visual artist.
  9. Identify resources that are available on campus for health, computing, and career services
  10. Assemble a vocabulary of terms when discussing visual art to communicate research, problem-solving, techniques, and critical thinking
  11. Demonstrate a thorough understanding of the SCCC Visual Art curriculum and degree requirements, facilities, and faculty.
  12. Identify the ingredients of a strong transfer portfolio.
  13. Describe a personal creative process explaining the criteria used to make creative decisions.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Introductory survey of principal movements and trends in painting, sculpture and architecture from pre-historic to Renaissance. Note: Fulfills SUNY General Education Requirement for Humanities and The Arts. No prerequisite. Offered on: A-E-G / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Identify major masterpieces from the Western canon by artist, title and approx. date.
  2. Identify significant personal, period and cultural styles.
  3. Define and correctly apply the formal language specific to art and art history (e.g. line, shape, color etc.).
  4. Describe the function of a work of art in its culture (its reason for existence).
  5. Explain how an object embodies or communicates a major theme of its time period.
  6. Differentiate forms of art (for example, relief sculpture, painting, ceramics).

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Introductory survey of principal movements and trends in painting, sculpture and architecture from Renaissance to 20th century. (May be taken out of sequence.) Note: Fulfills SUNY General Education Requirement for Humanities and The Arts. No prerequisite. Offered on: A-E-G / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Identify major masterpieces from the Western canon by artist, title and approx. date.
  2. Identify significant personal, period and cultural styles.
  3. Define and correctly apply the formal language specific to art and art history (e.g. line, shape, color etc.).
  4. Describe the function of a work of art in its culture (its reason for existence).
  5. Explain how an object embodies or communicates a major theme of its time period.
  6. Differentiate forms of art (for example, painting, photography, decorative arts, performance)

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Study of history of painting, sculpture and architecture from 1850 to the present. Emphasizes primarily art of the 20th century. Lectures supplemented with slides, film and museum and gallery trips. Note: Fulfills SUNY General Education Requirement for Humanities and The Arts. No prerequisite. Offered on: A-E-G / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Identify individual artworks by artist, title and date.
  2. Identify significant personal, period and cultural styles.
  3. Define and discuss the difference between the terms ‘Modern,’ ‘Avant-Garde’ and ‘Postmodern.’
  4. Define and correctly apply the formal language specific to art and art history (e.g. line, shape, color etc.).
  5. Explain and apply selected ideas of art critics, social critics and philosophers, and anthropologists.v
  6. Discuss reasons for the significance of a work of art in its historical context (authorial intention, formal or theoretical contribution to the notion of ‘Art,’ personal or political symbolism etc.)
  7. Ability to answer the following questions: why does the art look like it does at different times? Why does it change? What purpose does it serve? Who is it meant to serve?

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Photography's contribution to the visual arts, focusing on individual photographers and development of particular styles. Relationship between photography and other fine art media considered, as well as effect of photographic imagery on our culture. Note: Fulfills SUNY General Education Requirement for The Arts. No prerequisite. Offered on: E-G / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Appreciate and understand the key events in the history of photography
  2. Use the Internet to develop research on photographers/artist and events involved in the history of photography
  3. Analyze in write about photographic images, trends, and photographers.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: This course is designed to teach students both fundamental and advanced topics in Adobe Illustrator. The course will begin by teaching students the beginning steps of working with illustrator in the computer environment. Students will then learn how to create text and gradients, draw and compose an illustration, transform and distort objects, work with layers, patterns, brushes, filters and transparency. Concentrates on drawing with symbols, creating graphs, using the gradient mesh tool, and creating 3D objects. Students will learn how to prepare graphics for the Web, prepress and printing. No prerequisite. Offered on: E / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Develop basic techniques and skills of computer-based design using Adobe Illustrator along with the Macintosh computer but applicable to Windows-based computers
  2. Utilize the computer as a tool in design and other specialized areas of the arts industry
  3. Demonstrate knowledge and skill to produce effective solutions using Adobe Illustrator software
  4. Explore to critically examine technical and production alternatives
  5. Demonstrate basic production of electronic illustrations using Adobe Illustrator
  6. Identify procedures for producing camera-ready art from gathering information and creating thumbnail sketches to producing and printing the finished project
  7. Demonstrate an industry appropriate work ethic emphasizing accuracy, timeliness and neatness by adhering to stringent deadlines for project completion and participating in classroom critiques
  8. Integrate supplemental information from other visual art courses
  9. Demonstrate knowledge and practice of basic art principles, such as balance, line, space, contrast, movement, shape and color

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: An overview of hardware components used to produce images including film and flatbed scanners, computers, monitors, printers, recording media and storage devices. An introduction of the basic tools used for image manipulation in Adobe Photoshop including filters, layers, image modification, selections, composites, and text are stressed. The importance of image quality is addressed and their relationship to file size management, proofing and printing. (2 hrs. lecture, 2 hrs. studio) No prerequisite. Offered on: E / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Develop basic techniques and skills of computer-based design using Adobe Illustrator along with the Macintosh computer but applicable to Windows-based computers
  2. Utilize the computer as a tool in design and other specialized areas of the arts industry
  3. Demonstrate knowledge and skill to produce effective solutions using Adobe Illustrator software
  4. Explore to critically examine technical and production alternatives
  5. Demonstrate basic production of electronic illustrations using Adobe Illustrator
  6. Identify procedures for producing camera-ready art from gathering information and creating thumbnail sketches to producing and printing the finished project
  7. Demonstrate an industry appropriate work ethic emphasizing accuracy, timeliness and neatness by adhering to stringent deadlines for project completion and participating in classroom critiques
  8. Integrate supplemental information from other visual art courses
  9. Demonstrate knowledge and practice of basic art principles, such as balance, line, space, contrast, movement, shape and color>

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Introduction to the principles of color and an exploration of color theory as it relates to design and media. The course investigates hue, saturation, value, and examines how color relates to surroundings. Color temperature and psychology will be explored. (1 hr. lecture, 3 hrs. laboratory) Prerequisite: ART130. Offered on: E / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Create harmony and balance using color to emphasize and unify composition and form.
  2. Distinguish between primary, secondary, tertiary, analogous, and complementary colors.
  3. Employ the vocabulary of terms necessary to identify, define, describe, compare, and contrast the influence of one color against another.
  4. Create, classify, distinguish, and differentiate various color palettes.
  5. Demonstrate an understanding of the emotional effects of color.
  6. Demonstrate control of hue, saturation, value, and color temperature.
  7. Differentiate between additive and subtractive mixture of color.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Introduces students to Macintosh computer and desktop publishing software. Elements of electronic page design to be covered are type specification, typesetting, page layout, creation and digitizing of illustrations, and final printing. Students work with a Macintosh computer, laser printer and a scanner. (1 hr. lecture, 4 hrs. studio) No prerequisite. Offered on: A-E / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Think creatively and critically.
  2. Understand the role of balance, order, unity and repetition in design.
  3. Utilize color effectively.
  4. Effective marketing strategy.
  5. Discretionary and applicable use of the internet a research tool for material.
  6. Proper scanning methods.
  7. Productive use of group discussion to analyze and evaluate other students’ work
  8. Give a presentation articulating verbally, as well as demonstrating on the computer, the problem solving and design choices used to create the presentation piece.
  9. Manipulate and combine creatively and skillfully the tools of Photoshop and InDesign to execute a broad range of printed pieces.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Enables students to create and modify illustrations and scanned images. Students use Macintosh computer as electronic drawing tool with image enhancement techniques and technologies to create studies and illustrations. (1 hr. lecture, 4 hrs. studio) No prerequisite. Offered on: A-E / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Create digital illustrations which visually articulate an idea shaped by a broader concept.
  2. Digitally draw, paint, composite digital photographs, and collage or montage using a variety of techniques and input devices.
  3. Determine appropriate resolution, color mode, size, and format for output and display of digital work.
  4. Effectively compose through objective analysis of the principles and elements of visual organization. IE: unity and variety, balance and visual weight, emphasis and focal point, proportion and scale, rhythm and movement.
  5. Creatively solve visual problems.
  6. Show evidence of their creative process including brainstorming lists and/or maps, thumbnail and compositional sketches, and revision (evident in multiple project files) used to achieve visual solutions.
  7. Employ technical and aesthetic vocabulary when discussing two-dimensional works of art.
  8. Constructively critique their own work as well as the work of others utilizing critical thinking and creative problem solving.
  9. Create a body of work which successfully utilizes a variety of digital techniques.
  10. Make decisions regarding whether digital, conventional, or a combination of techniques are used in making a work of art.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Familiarizes students with several areas of commercial design and techniques used in those fields. Advertising design, fashion illustration, interior design and textile/surface design are explored. Students are made aware of the possibilities of expanding their art into a commercial field. Advice given about the student¿s continuing education and the preparation of a portfolio. (4 hrs. studio) No prerequisite. Offered on: G / 3 cr. hrs.

Electronic foundation course in three-dimensional design emphasizing fundamental esthetic principles of design and construction of three-dimensional models on computers using Maya software. Covers basic concepts in model building. (Offered fall semester only.) (5 hrs. studio) Prerequisite: ART130. Offered on: E / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Comprehend the process of computer animation and related elements;
  2. Comprehend the concept of 3d coordinate space and the use of axes, planes, and views within this space;
  3. Demonstrate competency with industry-standard 3d graphics software in the area of 3d modeling and rendering
  4. Use 3d primitives to create more complex models and scenes;
  5. Use polygon modeling techniques to create 3d models;
  6. Use nurbs modeling techniques to create 3d models;
  7. Create lighting effects within a 3d scene;
  8. Use virtual cameras to control how viewers see a 3d scene;
  9. Create materials and apply them to objects within a 3d scene;
  10. Create project maps for surfaces within a 3d scene;
  11. Use render tools to output 3d scenes into different file formats

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Explores computer as a tool for generating two-dimensional graphic images. Includes overview of hardware components used to produce images including scanners, computers, monitors, printers and storage devices and their relationship to image quality. Examines and explores basic software operations in relationship to the art-making process, primarily using Adobe Photoshop and Illustrator. Provides framework in which to make comparisons between traditional and digital methods in commercial and fine art. (1 hr. lecture, 4 hrs. studio) Recommended prerequisite or corequisite: ART130. Offered on: E-G / 3 cr. hrs.

Building upon ART126, students use computer as artmaking tool to generate freehand images and manipulate scanned images using sophisticated digital imaging systems such as Adobe Photoshop and Illustrator. Explores color theory, design and composition as artistic problems that can be solved using the computer. Students investigate how best to input and output their images producing professional quality results for both hard copy and digital environments. (1 hr. lecture, 4 hrs. studio) Prerequisite: ART126. Offered on: G / 3 cr. hrs.

Teaches fundamentals of computer-generated animation. Macintosh computer platform used to create real-time animation for presentation, computer video production and other computer applications. Design and creative animation projects are created first in storyboard format and applied to animation computer software packages. (1 hr. lecture, 4 hrs. studio) No prerequisite. Offered on: A / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Create digital animations which visually articulate an idea shaped by a broader concept.
  2. Communicate characteristics of symbols, environments, objects, and or characters through objective analysis of both pictorial (static) and progressive (motion) considerations.
  3. Create an effective animation in each of the following categories: expressive sequential, narrative (linear or non-linear), interactive.
  4. Determine appropriate technical approach to create motion in an animation. IE: Frame by Frame, Rotoscoping, and/or Shape or Motion Tweening
  5. Creatively solve visual problems.
  6. Show evidence of their creative process including brainstorming lists and/or maps, thumbnail sketches, narrative or action synopsis, scripting, storyboards, and revision (evident in multiple project files) used to achieve visual solutions.
  7. Employ technical and aesthetic vocabulary when discussing time-based works of art.
  8. Constructively critique their own work as well as the work of others utilizing critical thinking and creative problem solving.
  9. Create a body of work which successfully utilizes a variety of digital animation techniques.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Foundation course in two-dimensional design. Exploration of historical and contemporary concepts of space and pictorial composition. Studio problems employing elements of line, texture, shape, form and color. A basic course for painting, graphics, photography and commercial art. Note: Fulfills SUNY General Education Requirement for The Arts. (1 hr. lecture, 4 hrs. studio) No prerequisite. Offered on: A-E-G / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Describe visual experience as possessing two aspects: form (or spatial aspect) and color.
  2. Manipulate various qualities of spatial experience (size, shape, texture, location, number, figure/ground, and edge delineation) to produce visually compelling black and white compositions.
  3. Demons trate fluency with concepts associated with color organization and color harmony: color’s three dimensions, hue, value, and saturation; primary, secondary and tertiary hues; achromatic, monochromatic and analogous color combinations; complements and split-complements; and simultaneous contrast.
  4. Employ effectively basic design concepts: rhythm, proportion, balance, hierarchy, symmetry, asymmetry, unity and unified variety in artistic composition.
  5. Explain the importance of the gestalt concepts of figure-ground, and part-group-whole; and describe the significance of polar states such as active-passive, light-dark, warm-cool, ordered-chaotic in esthetic communication.
  6. Manipulate skillfully the attributes of color and form, while effectively employing various design principles, to produce a variety of creative and visually compelling two-dimensional compositions. Use design principles to communicate an emotion or idea in a work of art.
  7. Make succinct written and oral analyses of the design of a two-dimensional works of art.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Introduction to fundamentals of drawing. Drawing of objects to develop student's understanding of proportion, value, perspective, form and shape. Develops accurate observation, understanding and memory of key forms, properties of illumination, and effective use of drawing materials. Note: Fulfills SUNY General Education Requirement for The Arts. (1 hr. lecture, 4 hrs. studio) No prerequisite. Offered on: A-E-G / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Render form, texture, space and light in line and value.
  2. Measure and describe the accurate proportions of objects.
  3. Create unified and balanced compositions.
  4. Demonstrate effective and controlled use of a variety of black and white drawing media and materials.
  5. Produce "blind" and "modified" contour drawings.
  6. Rapidly capture the formal essence of a visual event through the use of gesture drawing.
  7. Define space using linear and atmospheric perspective.
  8. Demonstrate an understanding of all the stages of the creative process, from conception of the idea to final presentation.
  9. Apply a basic vocabulary of art terms when discussing artwork.
  10. Apply unique and creative solutions to a set of visual problems.
  11. Constructively critique the work of others.
  12. Push themselves, willingly taking the necessary risks, to reach his or her maximum level of achievement.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: More detailed investigation of concepts explored in ART133: Drawing I. Investigation of various wet and dry drawing media. (1 hr. lecture, 4 hrs. studio) Prerequisite: ART133. Offered on: A-E-G / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Demonstrate mastery in the use of several drawing media: graphite, colored pencil, pastel, and ink.
  2. Graphically represent form through the combined use of line (as boundary or contour) and value (light and dark areas between edges).
  3. Demonstrate knowledge of perspective and proportion to produce accurately drawn representations of the visual world.
  4. Demonstrate knowledge of basic drawing techniques such as "blind" and "modified" contour drawings, gesture drawing, and negative space drawing.
  5. Utilize design concepts of order, unity, balance, repetition and variation, positive/negative space, and hierarchy to form creative judgments, to produce compelling compositions, and to objectively analyze a drawing.
  6. Use drawing to produce artistic, esthetically sophisticated, and personally expressive art.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Centers on mechanics of graphically representing the figure and on principles of anatomy relevant to pictorial and sculptural composition. Attention to use of materials on individual basis. A foundation for both fine and commercial art. Note: Fulfills SUNY General Education Requirement for The Arts. (1 hr. lecture, 4 hrs. studio) Prerequisite: ART133. Offered on: A-E-G / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Utilize effectively the following drawing media: pencil, charcoal, ink and ink wash.
  2. Graphically depict human form through the combined use of both line (as boundary or contour), and value (light and dark areas between edges).
  3. Vary line weight and value contrast at edges to create “atmospheric perspective” that will help produce an illusion of the figure in space.
  4. Effectively employ perspective and proportion to produce accurately drawn representations of human form. Draw foreshortened forms accurately.
  5. Begin a drawing by efficiently blocking-in form to produce an overall “envelop” shape, and control the placement of this shape on the page.
  6. Rapidly capture the movement of human mass in space through the use of gesture drawing. Employ a line that is free, investigative and searching.
  7. Create imaginative, visually compelling compositions using the human form. Use representations of the figure as a vehicle for sophisticated artistic expression.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Centers on mechanics of graphically representing the figure and on principles of anatomy relevant to pictorial and sculptural composition. Attention to use of materials on individual basis. A foundation for both fine and commercial art. (1 hr. lecture, 4 studio hrs. each week.) Prerequisite: ART135. Offered on: A-E-G / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Utilize effectively the following drawing media: pencil, charcoal, ink and ink wash. Color will be employed via pastel, colored pencil or colored inks.
  2. Graphically depict human form through the combined use of both line (as boundary or contour), and value (light and dark areas between edges).
  3. Vary line weight and value contrast at edges to create “atmospheric perspective” that will help produce an illusion of the figure in space.
  4. Effectively employ perspective and proportion to produce accurately drawn representations of human form. Draw foreshortened forms accurately.
  5. Begin a drawing by efficiently blocking-in form to produce an overall “envelop” shape, and control the placement of this shape on the page.
  6. Rapidly capture the movement of human mass in space through the use of gesture drawing. Employ a line that is free, investigative and searching.
  7. Create imaginative, visually compelling compositions using the human form. Use representations of the figure as a vehicle for sophisticated artistic expression.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Introduces basic camera skills including exposure control, composition, depth of field, and movement control while photographing in available light. Students will also learn basic imaging processing skills using a digital darkroom consisting of computer, software and inkjet printers. Image processing skills will include density and contrast control, color balance, dodging, burning, file size management, basic retouching, printing and archival storage of digital images will be explored. Students must provide their own fully-adjustable digital camera having a resolution of 6-megapixels or greater and some other supplies. Note: Fulfills SUNY General Education Requirement for The Arts. (2 hrs. lecture, 2 hrs. laboratory) No prerequisite. Offered on: E-G / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Effectively use a digital camera
  2. Demonstrate basic camera techniques to obtain consistent exposures in daylight, low light, and at night
  3. Creatively use the photographic techniques of depth-of-field and movement control
  4. Practice photographic composition to produce images beyond that of a snapshot
  5. Creatively use light to strengthen the aesthetic quality of their images
  6. Demonstrate basic digital workflow management
  7. Effectively use basic image processing skills to balance digital images including density and contrast control, basic black and white conversion, dodging, burning, cropping, and retouching using adobe elements
  8. Demonstrate basic ink jet printing skills to properly make balanced prints
  9. Demonstrate print presentation and archival storage methods.

CourseInventory.CourseLongTitle: Black and White Photography and Darkroom Techniques
CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Introduction to art and techniques of the camera and darkroom. Students learn basic black and white available-light photography, including film exposure and development and variable contrast enlargement printing. Students must provide their own fully adjustable 35mm camera with manual f-stops and shutter speeds, film, paper and some other supplies. Note: Fulfills SUNY General Education Requirement for The Arts. (2 hrs. lecture, 2 hrs. laboratory) No prerequisite. Offered on: G / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Effectively use a 35mm camera system including choosing the appropriate lens in creating photographic images.
  2. Successfully use basic camera techniques to obtain consistent film exposures in daylight, low light, and night situations.
  3. Creatively use the photographic techniques of depth-of-field and movement control to produce images beyond that of a snapshot.
  4. Use composition and light to strengthen the esthetic quality of their work.
  5. Develop 35mm black and white film.
  6. Effectively use darkroom equipment to print and process black and white resin coated silver-based prints.
  7. Safely use, mix, measure and dispose of or recycle black and white photographic chemicals.
  8. Present their work using the presentation methods of dry mounting of resin coated black and white prints, dust spotting, and be able to practice safe storage methods for all photographic materials.
  9. Speak about photographic skills/techniques and talk about their own photographic images as well as the photographic work of others.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Introduction to career exploration and study skills needed to succeed in the field of professional photography. Connects learning skills with those skills needed for a career as a professional photographer. Fulfills College Seminar requirement for students in Photographic Imaging curriculum. (Offered fall semester only.) No prerequisite. Offered on: E-G / 1.5 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Discuss with greater insight both educational and career goals to determine areas that may need further development.
  2. Demonstrate basic study skills including time management, goal setting, test and note taking
  3. Synthesize information and procedures for establishing priorities, clarifying values, and determining short- and long-term goals with the career, personal and educational setting
  4. Create a course schedule to prepare for academic advisement throughout their academic study
  5. Effectively use the computer to manage activities at the college including E-mail, Internet usage and course registration, online and with an advisor
  6. Demonstrate library research methods to search for career opportunities within the field of photography and to research equipment requirements for a chosen career
  7. Effectively use college resources including academic advisement and career services
  8. Recognize and demonstrate an understanding of the diversity within academic life and one’s personal life as well as the diversity of working as a professional photographer
  9. Identify resources that are available on campus for health, computing, and career services
  10. Assemble a vocabulary of terms when discussing photography to communicate research, problem-solving, techniques, and critical thinking

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Students learn basic digital camera skills beginning with exposure control, including bracketing, reciprocity, exposure modes, and the use of the histogram. The creative techniques of depth of field and movement control are explored as well as techniques for low light and night photography. Image processing skills are introduced including basic digital workflow management, density and contrast control, basic black and white conversion, dodging, burning, cropping and retouching. Print presentation and archival storage will be explored. Note: Students are required to have a full-adjustable DSLR camera, tripod, memory cards, portable hard drive, photo quality ink jet paper and some other supplies. (2 hrs. lecture, 3 hrs. laboratory) No prerequisite. Offered on: E-G / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Use a digital camera system
  2. Demonstrate basic camera techniques to obtain consistent exposures in daylight, low light, and at night
  3. Apply exposure compensation techniques of bracketing and reciprocity.
  4. Employ the photographic techniques of depth-of-field and movement control
  5. Practice photographic composition to produce images beyond that of a snapshot
  6. Use light to strengthen the aesthetic quality of their images
  7. Demonstrate basic digital workflow management
  8. Operate basic image processing skills to balance digital images including density and contrast control, basic black and white conversion, dodging, burning, cropping, and retouching using Adobe Photoshop
  9. Employ basic ink jet printing skills to properly make balanced contact and enlargement prints
  10. Apply print presentation and archival storage methods.
  11. Develop a vocabulary to speak about photographic images.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Builds on the fundamental photography and image processing skills introduced in ART145: Digital Photography I. Color photography is studied in-depth, including photographic color theory, color management during image processing, color printing corrections and techniques. Advanced camera and image processing techniques are introduced, including lens filtration, close-up photography, digital workflow management, layers, levels, channels, histograms, text, restoration, advance gray scale tonal control, and image size management. Through creative visual assignments, students will be encouraged to develop their own individual photographic styles. Print finishing, including window matting and archival storage of print and digital media, will be explored. Note: Students are required to have a full-adjustable DSLR camera, tripod, memory cards, portable hard drive, photo quality ink jet paper and some other supplies. (2 hrs. lecture, 3 hrs. laboratory) Prerequisite: ART145. Corequisite: ART149. Offered on: E-G / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Operate advance camera controls to manage file formats, white balance, color mode, and auto bracketing.
  2. Use image histograms in maintaining image detail in both the shadow and highlight regions of the image during exposure.
  3. Apply camera lens filters for correction and creative control of photographic situations.
  4. Experiment with basic close-up photography techniques
  5. Practice photographic compositions that are aesthetically correct.
  6. Use digital workflow management from image capture to output of color corrected photographic prints.
  7. Operate the digital imaging software to process digital images including levels for color, channels, curves, noise reduction, color space, advance black and white conversions, and image size.
  8. Demonstrate the beginning of a personal vision and style.
  9. Analyze and discuss photographic images.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: The basic study of digital imaging technology. The topics covered are image formation and evaluation, photosensitive sensors, exposure technology, tone reproduction, visual perception, physics of light, camera lenses, computer technology, image processing, software applications, scanner and printer technologies. (Offered fall semester only.) No prerequisite. Offered on: E-G / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Examine image formation on light sensitive materials and sensors
  2. Evaluate the physics of light for use in photography
  3. Compare different camera systems and their use
  4. Define the principles of lens systems and their use
  5. Apply the principles of photographic color theory
  6. Analyze the photographic digital process
  7. Explain the principles of exposure
  8. Compare methods of image output
  9. Speak using photographic terminology

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: This course makes use of visual exercises to teach students how to evaluate, control and manipulate light. Situations include natural light conditions, using portable flash, and the introduction to studio lighting using both tungsten and electronic studio flash equipment. Light theory will be explored in-depth to connect all of the above lighting situations together so the student will be able to professionally handle any lighting situation. Note: Students are required to have a full-adjustable DSLR camera, tripod, memory cards, portable hard drive, photo quality ink jet paper and some other supplies. (offered spring semester only) (2 hrs. lecture, 3 hrs. laboratory) Prerequisite: ART145. Corequisite: ART146. Offered on: E-G / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Apply light theory when making decisions on how to professionally light subjects
  2. Use light as a creative form of artistic expression
  3. Employ the use of reflectors to control shadows in both natural and studio lighting situations
  4. Operate a portable flash unit as both a main and fill light source
  5. Demonstrate the ability to use both tungsten and studio flash lighting equipment
  6. Operate studio lighting equipment including the ability to setup lighting for a professional photo shoot
  7. Choose the appropriate professional light modifying devices such as soft-boxes, umbrellas, barn doors, gobos, scrims, honeycomb grids, and diffusers
  8. Calculate camera exposures using handheld incident and reflective flash light meters.
  9. Analyze and apply the Zone System as it applies to studio lighting and exposure.
  10. Discuss their knowledge of photographic light theory and lighting techniques.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Introduction to processes and materials of ceramics through exploration of functional and non-functional forms in clay. Students investigate nature of clay by creating forms with several handbuilding methods such as coilbuilding, slabbuilding and pinch pots, as well as introduction to potter's wheel. Basic decorating, glazing and firing techniques explored. Note: Fulfills SUNY General Education Requirement for The Arts. (1 hr. lecture, 4 hrs. studio) No prerequisite. Offered on: A-G / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Use the medium of clay in creating ceramic art.
  2. Demonstrate a variety of techniques used in creating ceramic art.
  3. Understand and use the appropriate tools required in ceramics.
  4. Understand the ceramic processes from wedging clay to glazing and firing.
  5. Conceptualize projects through critical thinking.
  6. Solve problems applying artistic process and procedure.
  7. Develop a vocabulary of art terms when discussing ceramic art.
  8. Perform critical critiques of their own art work as well as the art work of others.
  9. Discuss the history of ceramic art.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Continued investigation of materials and processes of ceramics on a more technical level. Intensive study of skills learned in ART161. Students explore basics of glaze and clay body formulation and develop their skill on the potter's wheel. (1 hr. lecture, 4 hrs. studio) Prerequisite: ART161. Offered on: A / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Use the Potter’s wheel in creating ceramic art.
  2. Demonstrate improved hand-building techniques.
  3. Develop an artistic workflow from concept to a critical analysis of the finished work.
  4. Use critical thinking to help conceptualize projects and use problem solving skills to search out multiple solutions for a single concept.
  5. Apply personal aesthetic decisions that reflect a personal point-of-view in the creation of their work.
  6. Use research from historical and contemporary artist to help define and guide their own creative process and work.
  7. Constructively critique art identifying strengths and weaknesses
  8. Develop a vocabulary of art terms when discussing ceramic art.
  9. Discuss the history of ceramic art.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Continued investigation of materials and processes of ceramics on a more technical level. Intensive study of skills learned in ART161. Students explore basics of glaze and clay body formulation and develop their skill on the potter's wheel. (1 hr. lecture, 4 hrs. studio) Prerequisite: ART161. Offered on: A / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Use the Potter’s wheel in creating ceramic art.
  2. Demonstrate improved hand-building techniques.
  3. Develop an artistic workflow from concept to a critical analysis of the finished work.
  4. Use critical thinking to help conceptualize projects and use problem solving skills to search out multiple solutions for a single concept.
  5. Apply personal aesthetic decisions that reflect a personal point-of-view in the creation of their work.
  6. Use research from historical and contemporary artist to help define and guide their own creative process and work.
  7. Constructively critique art identifying strengths and weaknesses
  8. Develop a vocabulary of art terms when discussing ceramic art.
  9. Discuss the history of ceramic art.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Examines use of potter's wheel in ceramic arts. Teaches students fundamental skills necessary to create wheel-thrown objects in clay. Students explore pottery wheel's functions and care in order to utilize its many creative possibilities. Off-wheel techniques such as texture modalities, different glazing techniques and kiln firing skills also explored. (1 hr. lecture, 4 hrs. studio) No prerequisite. Offered on: A-G / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Demonstrate fundamental wheel throwing techniques.
  2. Prepare clay properly for wheel throwing.
  3. Use the appropriate tools required in ceramics.
  4. Employ and utilize a variety of glazing techniques, demonstrating a knowledge and understanding of how glazes function.
  5. Differentiate between bisque and glaze firing.
  6. Apply correct terminology when discussing ceramics.
  7. Discuss the historical and contemporary use of the potter's wheel.
  8. Demonstrate creative solutions to homework and studio assignments.
  9. Apply library research to the design of ceramic forms.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Introduction to fundamentals of sculpture emphasizing the figure. Various problems in form are explored. Emphasis on modeling techniques in clay and other materials. Note: Fulfills SUNY General Education Requirement for The Arts. (1 hr. lecture, 4 hrs. studio) No prerequisite. Offered on: A-G / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Use various building materials including clay in creating sculptural art.
  2. Demonstrate a variety of building techniques used in creating sculptural art.
  3. Understand and use the appropriate tools required in creating sculpture.
  4. Conceptualize projects through critical thinking.
  5. Solve problems applying artistic process and procedure.
  6. Develop a vocabulary of art terms when discussing sculptural art.
  7. Perform critical critiques of their own art work as well as the art work of others.
  8. Discuss the history of ceramic art.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Continued investigation of skills and concepts learned in ART171. Students encouraged to develop their own direction in their work. (1 hr. lecture, 4 hrs. studio) Prerequisite: ART171. Offered on: A-G / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Demonstrate improved sculptural building techniques.
  2. Develop an artistic workflow from concept to a critical analysis of the finished work.
  3. Use critical thinking to help conceptualize projects and use problem solving skills to search out multiple solutions for a single concept.
  4. Apply personal aesthetic decisions that reflex a personal point-of-view in the creation of their work.
  5. Use research from historical and contemporary artist to help define and guide their own creative process and work.
  6. Constructively critique art identifying strengths and weaknesses
  7. Develop a vocabulary of art terms when discussing sculptural art.
  8. Discuss the history of sculpture.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Continued investigation of skills and concepts learned in VA7l. Students encouraged to develop their own direction in their work. (4 studio hrs. each week.) Prerequisite: ART171. Offered on: A-G / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Demonstrate improved sculptural building techniques.
  2. Develop an artistic workflow from concept to a critical analysis of the finished work.
  3. Use critical thinking to help conceptualize projects and use problem solving skills to search out multiple solutions for a single concept.
  4. Apply personal aesthetic decisions that reflex a personal point-of-view in the creation of their work.
  5. Use research from historical and contemporary artist to help define and guide their own creative process and work.
  6. Constructively critique art identifying strengths and weaknesses
  7. Develop a vocabulary of art terms when discussing sculptural art.
  8. Discuss the history of sculpture.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Basic printmaking techniques in a variety of graphic media. Introduction to intaglio processes such as etching, aquatint, dry point and wood cut. Note: Fulfills SUNY General Education Requirement for The Arts. (1 hr. alecture, 4 hrs. studio) No prerequisite. Offered on: A / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Demonstrate a variety of approaches to drawing and “mark making” with a focus on expression.
  2. Differentiate between relief and intaglio forms of printmaking.
  3. Execute various methods of printmaking such as monotype, linoleum cut, dry point and solar etching, and come to appreciate each for its own aesthetic qualities.
  4. Produce a small limited edition demonstrating consistent control of technique.
  5. Exhibit good-clean printmaking techniques and studio maintenance.
  6. Participate in critique sessions in which they will articulate personal interests and demonstrate the ability to apply constructive criticism as a problem solving tool.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Continued investigation of materials and processes of intaglio such as engraving, softground, sugar lift and color printing. Refining of basic skills and exploration of the media. (1 hr. lecture, 4 hrs. studio) Prerequisite: ART181. Offered on: A / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Develop their drawing or “mark making” abilities with a focus on expression.
  2. Learn the difference between relief and intaglio forms of printmaking.
  3. Execute various methods of printmaking such as monotype, linoleum cut, and solar etching, and come to appreciate each for its own aesthetic qualities.
  4. Control their technique, producing a small limited edition by the end of the course.
  5. Practice good-clean printmaking techniques and studio maintenance.
  6. Understand the function and importance of critique sessions.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Introduction to painting techniques in oil and other media. Explores perception of light, shadow and color and the rendering of these elements. Note: Fulfills SUNY General Education Requirement for The Arts. (1 hr. lecture, 4 hrs. studio) Prerequisite: ART133 or permission of Chair/Academic Dean. Offered on: A-E-G / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Make the appropriate choices of materials and tools used in the craft of oil painting to reach a desired visual or expressive result.
  2. Demonstrate the use of a variety of oil painting techniques including; wet into wet, painting in layers, transparent washes, impasto, scumbling, and glazing.
  3. Apply these techniques to translating observed form, space and texture in a sensitive and engaging manner.
  4. Mix color to match observed local color and create harmonies in the painting’s overall design.
  5. Use the principles of color to describe form, light and space.
  6. Use the principles of design to create a unified, well-balanced, rhythmic composition.
  7. Differentiate between the picture plane treated as a surface and as an imaginary window.
  8. Reinterpret a subject by reducing it to its formal components, describing it through a subjective, expressive approach.
  9. Start to conceive of ideas that are unique and inventive which reflect his or her experience and point of view.
  10. Make aesthetic choices concerning form and subject matter to communicate these ideas.
  11. Apply a vocabulary of art terms when discussing his or her work or the work of others.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Continued exploration of problems and skills explored in ART202, with an emphasis on developing independent work. (1 hr. lecture, 4 hrs. studio) Prerequisite: ART202. Offered on: A-E-G / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Conceive of ideas that are unique and inventive which reflect his or her experience and point of view.
  2. Make aesthetic choices concerning form and subject matter to communicate these ideas.
  3. Apply a vocabulary of art terms when discussing his or her work or the work of others.
  4. Respectfully and constructively critique fellow students’ work, identifying strengths as well as failings, in order to help each student improve.
  5. Work through all stages of the artistic process starting with the conception of multiple ideas, selecting one through critical analysis, revising that idea, refining it during its development, and finally completing the work through its thoughtful presentation.
  6. Be critical of one’s own work, assigning challenges to oneself in effort to grow artistically and as an individual.
  7. Analyze paintings, both historical and contemporary, for their artistic merit.

As well as to:

  1. Effectively use techniques and materials that he or she has not had exposure to in Painting I.
  2. Demonstrate increased sensitivity to the materials used in painting and to an observed subject.
  3. Define the beginning of a stylistic approach and content that is unique to his or her sensibility.
  4. Relate ideas from one assignment to the next and in doing so present a personal point of view.
  5. Begin a painting from a purely conceptual starting point.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Continued exploration of problems and skills explored in ART202, with an emphasis on developing independent work. (1 hr. lecture, 4 hrs. studio) Prerequisite: ART202. Offered on: A-E-G / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Conceive of ideas that are unique and inventive which reflect his or her experience and point of view.
  2. Make aesthetic choices concerning form and subject matter to communicate these ideas.
  3. Apply a vocabulary of art terms when discussing his or her work or the work of others.
  4. Respectfully and constructively critique fellow students’ work, identifying strengths as well as failings, in order to help each student improve.
  5. Work through all stages of the artistic process starting with the conception of multiple ideas, selecting one through critical analysis, revising that idea, refining it during its development, and finally completing the work through its thoughtful presentation.
  6. Be critical of one’s own work, assigning challenges to oneself in effort to grow artistically and as an individual.
  7. Analyze paintings, both historical and contemporary, for their artistic merit.

As well as to:

  1. Effectively use techniques and materials that he or she has not had exposure to in Painting I.
  2. Demonstrate increased sensitivity to the materials used in painting and to an observed subject.
  3. Define the beginning of a stylistic approach and content that is unique to his or her sensibility.
  4. Relate ideas from one assignment to the next and in doing so present a personal point of view.
  5. Begin a painting from a purely conceptual starting point.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Continued exploration of problems and skills explored in ART202, with an emphasis on developing independent work. (1 hr. lecture, 4 hrs. studio) Prerequisite: ART202. Offered on: A-E-G / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Conceive of ideas that are unique and inventive which reflect his or her experience and point of view.
  2. Make aesthetic choices concerning form and subject matter to communicate these ideas.
  3. Apply a vocabulary of art terms when discussing his or her work or the work of others.
  4. Respectfully and constructively critique fellow students’ work, identifying strengths as well as failings, in order to help each student improve.
  5. Work through all stages of the artistic process starting with the conception of multiple ideas, selecting one through critical analysis, revising that idea, refining it during its development, and finally completing the work through its thoughtful presentation.
  6. Be critical of one’s own work, assigning challenges to oneself in effort to grow artistically and as an individual.
  7. Analyze paintings, both historical and contemporary, for their artistic merit.

As well as to:

  1. Effectively use techniques and materials that he or she has not had exposure to in Painting I.
  2. Demonstrate increased sensitivity to the materials used in painting and to an observed subject.
  3. Define the beginning of a stylistic approach and content that is unique to his or her sensibility.
  4. Relate ideas from one assignment to the next and in doing so present a personal point of view.
  5. Begin a painting from a purely conceptual starting point.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Instruction in various techniques of watercolor painting, with reference to European and American traditions. Notes: (1) It is recommended that students take ART133 prior to enrolling in ART209. (2) Fulfills SUNY General Education Requirement for The Arts. (1 hr. lecture, 4 hrs. studio) No prerequisite. Offered on: A-E-G / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Demonstrate a variety of techniques, including flat washes, variegated washes, wet into wet blends, dry brush and other textural effects, with the watercolor medium.
  2. Use these techniques to describe form, light and space.
  3. Create unified, rhythmic compositions that are both abstract and representational.
  4. Work in a process that is both quick and spontaneous as well as a controlled and planned out, using many steps.
  5. Identify the differences in the most common watercolor materials and make the appropriate choices to achieve a desired effect.
  6. Be critical of ones own work in order to improve upon it and offer constructive criticism.
  7. Use a basic vocabulary of art terms when discussing watercolor.
  8. Explore new ideas and take risks as a means of discovering ones own creative potential.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Foundation course in three-dimensional design. Exploratory problems that help develop understanding of and sensitivity to use of three-dimensional design fundamentals. Analysis of concepts as a basis for sculpture, ceramics, architecture and industrial design. Note: Fulfills SUNY General Education Requirement for The Arts. (1 hr. lecture, 4 hrs. studio) No prerequisite. Offered on: A-E-G / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Understand the basic principles of 3D Design.
  2. Demonstrate a variety of art making techniques in the construction of 3D art.
  3. Choose and understand of appropriate construction materials used in creating 3D art.
  4. Understand and use the appropriate tools required in creating 3D art.
  5. Conceptualize ideas and through artistic process and procedure produce 3D art.
  6. Develop a vocabulary of art terms when discussing 3D art.
  7. Critical critiques of their own art work as well as the art work of others.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Focuses on historical and nontraditional processes such as pinhole photography, handcoloring, cyanotype, van dyke brown printing, toning, Polaroid transfer, positive/negative printing, ortho film and liquid light. Students must supply their own film, paper and some other supplies. (2 hr. lecture, 3 hrs. laboratory) Prerequisite: ART141 or ART146 or permission of Chair/Academic Dean. Offered on: G / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Use contemporary and historical photographic materials in creating photographic art
  2. Demonstrate a variety of alternative photographic techniques
  3. Employ the appropriate tools and equipment in creating alternative photographic images
  4. Conceptualize projects through critical thinking.
  5. Solve problems applying artistic process and procedure.
  6. Use a vocabulary of art terms when analyzing, critiquing, and discussing photographic art
  7. Define and discuss the history of photography as it relates to alternative photographic processes.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Examines history and use of authoring tools in multimedia production. Covers use of authoring tools in basic programming techniques, animation control, modeling, texturing and design principles using computer animation software. Emphasizes character animation involving looping, character interacting, timing, color and sound. (6 hrs. studio) (offered fall semester only) Prerequisite: ART115, ART120 and ART133. Offered on: E / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Identify, discuss and implement the principles of animation
  2. Demonstrate drawing vector line art and tracing imported bitmap files within Flash
  3. Demonstrate the basics of Flash animation [frames, keyframes, time line, motion/shape tweening, layers, motion guides, scenes, symbols, scenes, loops, transitions]
  4. Examine the Flash toolbar and menu selections
  5. Construct scenes, movie clips, and animated buttons
  6. Demonstrate the introduction of audio file types and their use in an artistic manner for enhancing a visual animation
  7. Demonstrate how to apply classic principles in character action [easing, arcs, squash and stretch, center points, skewing, timing, straight-ahead and pose-to-pose exaggeration , anticipation, overshoot, follow-through and overlapping action along with second action]
  8. Examine the relationship between different limbs of each digital character
  9. Publish an animation in an HTML file for use on the Internet
  10. Determine actions and interactive design concepts to construct a multilevel user interface for web site navigation
  11. Identify and implement storytelling, storyboarding and character design
  12. Demonstrate the ability to edit graphic information received from

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Emphasizes practical aspects of 2D game design such as interface, documentation and characters. Based on knowledge acquired in ART221, students plan electronic productions with emphasis on pre-production, production and post-production techniques using computer animation software. (offered spring semester only) (6 hrs. studio) Prerequisite: ART221 or permission of Chair/Academic Dean. Offered on: E / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Develop a basic understanding of the logics and concepts of game play
  2. Investigate the game development process from conception to completion
  3. Research the introduction to the business of the game industry
