(3 hrs. lecture, 3 hrs. laboratory) Prerequisite: MAT007 or equivalent. Offered on: A-E / 4 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Know the basic characteristics of the monera, protista and fungi kingdoms and their relation to plants.
  2. Describe the basic characteristics of the major divisions of the plant kingdom and their evolutionary significance.
  3. Become familiar with the vocabulary of botany associated with plant morphology on both macro and microscopic scales and its application to plant taxonomy and plant physiology.
  4. Understand the structure and chemistry of the plant cell and its role in metabolism and energy exchange in the processes of photosynthesis and cellular respiration.
  5. Understand the life cycles of plants including their mechanism for inheritance, molecular genetics and reproduction.
  6. Describe how plants are adapted to various environments and be able to give examples of their ecological significance.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: This course introduces the science of entomology in a survey of the taxonomy, morphology, ecology, evolution and behavior of insects (Class Hexapoda). In addition to general insect biology, the course covers insect-plant and insect-human interactions (e.g. pollination, medical entomology). Through field and laboratory work, students will practice insect collection, identification and preservation techniques, and apply these skills in the preparation of a formal insect collection as a term project. Notes: (1) Course specifically designed for non-science majors. (2) Fulfills SUNY General Education Requirement for Natural Sciences. (3 hrs. lecture, 2 hrs. laboratory) Prerequisite: MAT007 or equivalent. Offered on: E / 4 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Demonstrate understanding of the methods scientists use to explore natural phenomena, including observation, hypothesis development, measurement and data collection, experimentation, evaluation of evidence, and employment of mathematical analysis.
  2. Demonstrate application of scientific data, concepts, and models in entomology.
  3. Understand the unifying principles of evolution and apply them to explain physical, chemical and behavioral adaptations of modern insects.
  4. Understand the basic structure and function of the cells, tissues and organs of insects.
  5. Recognize the adaptive significance of insect senses, defense, communication and sociality.
  6. Characterize the interactions between insects and humans, and how these interactions affect our society and environment.
  7. Characterize the interactions between insects and plants, and how these interactions affect the evolution of both groups.
  8. Locate and collect live specimens of major insect groups in a variety of field habitats then properly mount, preserve and label these specimens.
  9. Understand the relationships among different taxonomic groups of insects and employ dichotomous keys to identify insect specimens to family level.
  10. Integrate insect collection and preservation skills with taxonomic knowledge to curate a formal insect collection.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Basic principles of the structure and function of the human body are discussed in depth for each of the organ systems. Physiology is presented from both a biochemical and organismal point of view. Basic chemistry, physics and mathematics are introduced where useful and necessary for understanding these biological phenomena. Special attention given to the application of these principles and concepts to health-related areas. First course in a two-semester sequence. Note: Fulfills SUNY General Education Requirement for Natural Sciences. (3 hrs. lecture, 3 hrs. laboratory) Prerequisite: MAT007 and high school chemistry or CHE100 or equivalent. Recommended: high school biology, BIO101 or BIO105. Offered on: A-E-G / 4 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Use (follow, understand and apply) the scientific method,
    1. by performing experiments to test formulated hypotheses and understanding the basic components of the design of those experiments
    2. by solving problems with the correct use of appropriate scientific notation and equipment
    3. by quantifying (observing, describing and measuring) various empirical phenomena
    4. by logically reaching valid conclusions based on these data through critical analysis and interpretation
  2. Describe how the basic structure of inorganic elements is energetically organized through chemical bonding into organic compounds
    1. that constitute the anatomy of the human body
    2. that determine the physiology of its organ systems in the maintenance of homeostasis through negative feedback mechanisms
  3. Select, apply and use appropriate mathematical functions correctly in solving various physical, chemical and biological problems.
  4. Explain the relationship between structure and function at each level of organization of the body commencing with the cell and culminating with the total organism as it relates to the integumentary, skeletal, muscular and nervous systems.
  5. Identify, locate and classify various anatomical structures at the cellular, histological, organal and systemic levels of organization as it relates to the integumentary, skeletal, muscular and nervous systems.
  6. Describe and explain selected physiological processes at the cellular, histological, Organal and systemic levels of organization as it relates to the integumentary, skeletal, muscular and nervous systems.
  7. Use and understand correct and appropriate anatomical and directional terminology and descriptions as well as scientific terminology in general as it relates to the integumentary, skeletal, muscular and nervous systems.
  8. Identify and explain how selected pathologic conditions apply to the normal functions of the topic being studied as it relates to the integumentary, skeletal, muscular and nervous systems.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Basic principles of the structure and function of the human body are discussed in depth for each of the organ systems. Physiology is presented from both a biochemical and organismal point of view. The endocrine, digestive, respiratory, urinary, immune, cardiovascular, and reproductive systems will be emphasized. Basic chemistry, physics and mathematics are introduced where useful and necessary for understanding these biological phenomena. Special attention given to the application of these principles and concepts to health-related areas. Second course in a two-semester sequence. Note: Fulfills SUNY General Education Requirement for Natural Sciences. (3 hrs. lecture, 3 hrs. laboratory) Prerequisite: BIO130 grade of C or better. Offered on: A-E-G / 4 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Use (follow, understand and apply) the scientific method,
    1. by performing experiments to test formulated hypotheses and understanding the basic components of the design of those experiments
    2. by solving problems with the correct use of appropriate scientific notation and equipment
    3. by quantifying (observing, describing and measuring) various empirical phenomena
    4. by logically reaching valid conclusions based on these data through critical analysis and interpretation
  2. Describe how the basic structure of inorganic elements is energetically organized through chemical bonding into organic compounds,
    1. that constitute the anatomy of the human body,
    2. that determine the physiology of its organ systems in the maintenance of homeostasis through negative feedback mechanisms.
  3. Select, apply and use appropriate mathematical functions correctly in solving various physical, chemical and biological problems.
  4. Explain the relationship between structure and function at each level of organization of the body commencing with the cell and culminating with the total organism as it relates to the cardiovascular, lymphatic, digestive, respiratory, urinary, endocrine, and reproductive systems.
  5. Identify, locate and classify various anatomical structures at the cellular, histological, organal and systemic levels of organization as it relates to the cardiovascular, lymphatic, digestive, respiratory, urinary, endocrine, and reproductive systems.
  6. Describe and explain selected physiological processes at the cellular, histological, organal and systemic levels of organization as it relates to the cardiovascular, lymphatic, digestive, respiratory, urinary, endocrine, and reproductive systems.
  7. Use and understand correct and appropriate anatomical and directional terminology and descriptions as well as scientific terminology in general as it relates to the cardiovascular, lymphatic, digestive, respiratory, urinary, endocrine, and reproductive systems.
  8. Identify and explain how selected pathologic conditions apply to the normal functions of the topic being studied as it relates to the cardiovascular, lymphatic, digestive, respiratory, urinary, endocrine, and reproductive systems.

CourseInventory.CourseLongTitle: Fundamentals of Human Structure and Function
CourseInventory.CourseDescription: The human body as a wholly integrated, self-regulating model of functional anatomy. Introduces human structure at the cellular level and progresses to tissues, organs and organ systems. Common pathologic conditions are contrasted with normal form and function. (offered in the spring semester only) Notes: (1) Restricted to students in Health Information Technology. (2) Fulfills SUNY General Education Requirement for Natural Sciences. (3 hrs. lecture, 2 hrs. laboratory) Prerequisite: MAT007. Offered on: G / 4 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Describe and define planes of the body, basic anatomical terminology.
  2. Label and describe the organelles of a typical animal cell.
  3. Utilize a microscope to visualize the four types of tissue.
  4. Label, describe and locate the organs and basic structures of the integumentary system, skeletal system, muscular system, nervous system, endocrine system, cardiovascular system, lymphatic and immune system, respiratory system, digestive system, urinary system, and reproductive system.
  5. Understand the functions of the organs and specified structures of the integumentary system, skeletal system, muscular system, nervous system, endocrine system, cardiovascular system, lymphatic and immune system, respiratory system, digestive system, urinary system, and reproductive system.

CourseInventory.CourseLongTitle: College Biology I: Cellular and Molecular Biology
CourseInventory.CourseDescription: This course is a comprehensive study of the basic processes in living systems at the cellular and molecular levels of organization. Basic chemistry, aspects of cell structure, metabolism, cell energetics, and elements of classical and molecular genetics serve as the foundation for subsequent investigation of living systems. The principles of evolution underlie all discussions in the course. This course is the first semester of a three-semester sequence designed for science majors. (3 hrs. lecture, 3 hrs. laboratory.) Prerequisite: High school chemistry in the last three years with B or better, or CHE100 or equivalent; and MAT101 or higher. Offered on: A-E-G / 4 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Have an in-depth understanding of major biological concepts from a molecular perspective including how the Laws of Thermodynamics apply to living systems.
  2. Understand and comprehend the concepts of metabolism and energy exchange in the processes of photosynthesis, cellular respiration, and fermentation.
  3. Become familiar with possible events leading to the origins of life and with the concepts of evolution.
  4. Integrate the interrelationships of metabolism, genetics, and evolution to other scientific concepts.
  5. Identify and apply the mechanisms of inheritance, reproduction and molecular genetics.
  6. Explain the concepts of natural selection and its relationship to evolution.
  7. Apply biological concepts and the use of the scientific method, observations and data analysis to daily life.
  8. Use techniques in accumulation and analysis of biological data as graphing, chromatography, spectrophotometry and gel electrophoresis.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: This course is an introduction to the structure, development and the physiological processes of plants and animals. All levels of biological organization from the cellular to the organism are assessed. It includes the comparative study of major organismal systems including nutrition, transport and gas exchange systems, regulation of the internal environment, the nervous system, and reproduction. Special attention is placed on the phylogenetic origins and ecological placement of different taxonomic groups as their anatomy and physiologies are discussed. Designed for science majors. (3 hrs. lecture, 3 hrs. laboratory) Prerequisite: BIO150 with a C or better. Offered on: A-E-G / 4 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Compare systems for nutrient acquisition, digestion, gas exchange, internal transport, structural support, movement, osmoregulation, and excretion in representative species
  2. Explain the relationship between structure and function at cellular, tissue, organ and organismal levels in both plants and animals
  3. Explain the maintenance of homeostasis through biofeedback mechanisms
  4. Analyze the intricacies of neural control and effectors of increasing complexity seen from simple organisms to the human species
  5. Describe the physiological and biochemical mechanisms of hormonal regulation in growth, development and regulatory processes in plants and animals
  6. Correlate patterns of reproduction and embryonic development with habitat and evolutionary history of representative species
  7. Further develop skills in dissection, microscopy, experimentation with living organisms, and making physiological measurements
  8. Synthesize strategies for problem-solving, making scientific observations, data analysis, and formulating inquiries and conclusions about biological phenomena
  9. Apply critical thinking strategies to understand the complexity and similarity in the basic anatomical and physiological processes found in living organisms

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Comprehensive study of the basic processes in living organisms at the following levels of organization: molecules, cells, organs and organ systems, organisms and ecosystems. Evolution and ecology serve as the contexts in which bioenergetics, information transfer, biosystematics, morphology and physiology are studied. Designed for science majors. (3 hrs. lecture, 3 hrs. laboratory) Prerequisite: BIO150 with a C or better. Offered on: A-E-G / 4 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. to trace the functional and structural adaptations in the evolution from simple to complex organisms in their respective environments
  2. to apply principles of systematics to construct taxonomic schema, and to investigate contemporary molecular systematics
  3. to compare and contrast systems for nutrient acquisition, digestion, gas exchange, internal transport, osmoregulation, and excretion in representative species
  4. to explain the maintenance of homeostasis through biofeedback mechanisms
  5. to analyze the intricacies of neural control and effectors in the evolutionary progression from unicellular organisms to the human species
  6. to understand the physiological and biochemical mechanisms of hormonal control in growth, development and regulatory processes in plants and animals
  7. to correlate patterns of reproduction and embryonic development with natural habitats and evolutionary station of representative species
  8. to develop skills in biotechnology, dissection, microscopy, experimental testing on living organisms, and making physiological measurements
  9. to synthesize strategies for problem-solving, making scientific observations, data analysis, and formulating conclusions and inquiries about biological phenomena
  10. to apply critical thinking strategies to arguments on contemporary controversial issues in biology and medicine

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: The course considers the functional aspects of natural communities and ecosystems. The relation of ecology to evolutionary ideas is stressed and the natural population in its community serves as the basic study unit. Examples largely drawn from communities of North America, Long Island in particular. Field trips emphasize identification of local life forms and their role in natural communities. Lab work investigates general ecological principles. (offered spring semester only) Note: Fulfills SUNY General Education Requirement for Natural Sciences. (3 hrs. lecture, 3 hrs. laboratory) Prerequisite: BIO101 or BIO150 or MAR105 or ENV128. Offered on: A-E / 4 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Discuss and explain basic ecological concepts and how they apply to a wide variety of ecosystems.
  2. Properly use and apply elementary methods used for measuring and identifying various properties of natural populations and communities.
  3. Identify many local life forms and discuss their role in the composition of many local biotic communities.
  4. Develop, analyze, organize, and discuss through writing information on natural history and ecology.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: An introduction to microbiology through a survey of methods, tools and techniques used in studying main groups of bacteria and other microorganisms and application of this knowledge in physical and chemical control of microorganisms. The relationship of microorganisms to disease is discussed. Note: Fulfills SUNY General Education Requirement for Natural Sciences. (3 hrs. lecture, 4 hrs. laboratory) Prerequisite: BIO132 or VST102 and VST112. Offered on: A-E-G / 4 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Explain basic microbiologic concepts, including cell biology and genetics.
  2. Explain the fundamental differences between prokaryotes and eukaryotes.
  3. Gain an understanding of the basic characteristics of individual microbial groups: bacteria, archaea, fungi, protists, algae, and viruses.
  4. Gain an understanding of the laboratory tools and techniques used in the analysis of microbes.
  5. Explain physical and chemical methods for controlling microbial growth.
  6. Gain a better understanding of metabolism.
  7. Acquire knowledge pertaining to basic concepts in microbial genetics.
  8. Explain the relationship of microorganisms to health and disease.
  9. Explain mechanisms of pathogenicity and immune defense mechanisms.
  10. Explain the usefulness of microbes in food production, therapeutics, and bioremediation.
  11. Discuss biotechnology in theory and in practice and the importance of microbes in everyday life.
  12. Acquire knowledge pertaining to the relationship of microorganisms to the environment.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Analysis of skeletal, muscular and nervous systems provides basis for understanding human movement with emphasis on sport skills and dance forms. Mechanical principles underlying movement and their relationship to performance of skills emphasized. (Offered fall semester only.) (3 hrs. lecture, 2 hrs. laboratory) Prerequisites: BIO130 and BIO132. Offered on: A / 4 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Identify important anatomical landmarks of the musculoskeletal system.
  2. Determine for selected muscles, the joint(s) that it crosses, and type of actions at that joint(s).
  3. Demonstrate an understanding of the musculoskeletal, and nervous systems as they relate to human movement.
  4. Identify the actions of specific primary muscle groups and their effects on the joints that they cross.
  5. Utilize knowledge of kinesiology to qualitatively analyze human movement and improve movement skills.

CourseInventory.CourseLongTitle: Anatomy and Physiology of Human Movement
CourseInventory.CourseDescription: The course is a detailed treatment of structure and function of muscular and skeletal systems and their nervous coordination, including those aspects of respiratory and circulatory systems pertaining to muscular function, cardiovascular physiology and physiology of exercise. (offered fall semester only) Note: Fulfills SUNY General Education Requirement for Natural Sciences. (3 hrs. lecture, 3 hrs. laboratory) Prerequisite: BIO130 and BIO132. Offered on: A / 4 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Describe and locate the:
    1. skeletal muscles on the a human cadaver
    2. Identify muscle origins, insertions, actions and innervations.
    3. Identify key structures and articulations of the human skeleton.
  2. Describe the physiological basis of muscular activity.
  3. Explain the roles of the nervous, cardiovascular, respiratory and endocrine systems in muscular activity.
  4. Understand basic clinical applications for the various systems.

CourseInventory.CourseLongTitle: College Biology III: Organisms and Ecosystems
CourseInventory.CourseDescription: This course is an introductory study of the basic processes leading to the biodiversity of life from the organismal to ecosystem level of organization. An in-depth study of natural selection and evolution will serve as the context for the study of the biodiversity of major groups of living organisms and their phylogenetic relationships. The course will also cover central themes in ecology from population and community structure to geochemical cycling in the biosphere. Designed for science majors. (3 hrs. lecture, 3 hrs. laboratory) Prerequisite: BIO150 with a C or better. Offered on: A-E-G / 4 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Explain the concepts of natural selection and evolution in its various forms along with their effects on representative taxonomic groups
  2. Trace the functional and structural adaptations in the evolution of simple to complex organisms in their respective environments
  3. Apply principles of systematics to construct taxonomic schema and to investigate various contemporary models of taxonomic classification
  4. Describe possible events leading to the origins of life and relate them to central themes in biology and evolution
  5. Describe inter- and intraspecific interactions within ecosystems and explain conditions necessary for, and the ecological impacts of, these types of interactions
  6. Describe population growth dynamics and explain energy flow patterns within ecosystems
  7. Further develop skills in dissection, microscopy, experimentation with living organisms, and collecting biologically relevant data
  8. Synthesize strategies for problem-solving, making scientific observations, data analysis, and formulating inquiries and conclusions about biological phenomena
  9. Apply critical thinking strategies to contemporary issues in biology and ecology

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: This course focuses on the biological aspects of forensic investigation and analyses of biological evidence from various crime scenes. Particular emphasis will be given to DNA analyses, fingerprinting, serological analyses of body fluids and other biological materials, the role of the environment on body decomposition, the role of anthropology, and the role of entomology and plant materials in crime investigation. This course is designed for non-science and science majors and includes field trips to the Suffolk County Forensics Laboratory. (3 hrs. lecture, 3 hrs. laboratory) Prerequisite: BIO101 for non-science majors; BIO130 or BIO150 for science majors. Offered on: A/ 4 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Apply the scientific method in analyses of biological materials used in forensic investigations, provide critical analyses of data and integrate the theoretical knowledge obtained in class to the data obtained in laboratory. Students will be able to conduct individual and group research projects.
  2. Define the role of biology in the forensic investigation, the application of various laboratory techniques in specific investigative situations, and provide theoretical background for the approach used.
  3. Identify useful sources of organic materials found on a crime scene that are used in biological analyses, their proper collection, handling and documentation.
  4. Demonstrate knowledge of insect families most often used in forensic biology for determination of time of death, and the value of other organisms covered in the course.
  5. Understand the limitations of the tools and techniques used in forensic biology, court admissibility of evidence and proper presentation of conclusions based on scientific research.
  6. Demonstrate proper application of the knowledge obtained in class and laboratory to solve a crime presented to them in form of set-up crime scene.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: The study of classical modes of inheritance and molecular genetics with emphasis on research techniques. Laboratory experiments using living organisms illustrate genetic principles and techniques. Note: Fulfills SUNY General Education Requirement for Natural Sciences. (3 hrs. lecture, 3 hrs. laboratory) Prerequisite: BIO132 or BIO150. Offered on: A / 4 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Have in depth understanding of different areas of the science of Genetics and how each of these areas relates to the biological world.
  2. Become familiar with the basic concepts of molecular genetics, the structure of DNA, genetic information and its regulation.
  3. Understand the cell cycle, mitosis, and meiosis and explain how the movements and recombination of chromosomes are related to the patterns of Mendelian inheritance. Explain the various mechanisms utilized to achieve recombination and its importance to evolution.
  4. Use the principles of Mendelian genetics to explain experimental results and design experiments, understand the extensions of Mendelian Genetics, the principles of Non-Mendelian genetics and the relation of linkage studies to gene mapping.
  5. Understand chromosomal aberrations and explain their role in gene expression, disease, and evolution, link gene mutation mechanisms and their effects on protein structure and function.
  6. Explain the basic concepts of regulation of gene expression in prokaryotes and eukaryotes.
  7. Use the basic concepts of population genetics, apply the Hardy-Weinberg Law to solve problems in population genetics and how natural selection change gene frequencies.
  8. Understand the basic concepts of molecular evolution.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: The study of morphological and biochemical events occurring during development. The development of major organ systems in representative vertebrate species are examined with emphasis on genetic and environmental factors involved in congenital malformations. Note: Fulfills SUNY General Education Requirement for Natural Sciences. (2 hrs. lecture, 4 hrs. laboratory) Prerequisite: BIO152 or BIO132. Offered on: A / 4 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Describe gametogenesis, fertilization and the organization of the early embryo.
  2. Trace the development of the major organ systems of representative vertebrates.
  3. Identify the development of organ systems in prepared microscope slides of representative vertebrates.
  4. Explain the relationship between genetics and development of the organism.
  5. Describe abnormalities in development and discuss the causes of selected defects.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: An introduction to the study of microorganisms and their environments. Introduces students to microbial physiology, microbial genetics (including recombinant DNA technology), immunology, microbial ecology and evolution. Designed for science majors. Note: Fulfills SUNY General Education Requirement for Natural Sciences. (3 hrs. lecture, 4 hrs. laboratory) Prerequisite: BIO152 or permission of Chair/Academic Dean. Offered on: A-E-G / 4 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Discuss the similarities and differences between prokaryotic cells and eukaryotic cells.
  2. List the factors that influence microbial growth and explain bacterial growth curve.
  3. Describe the formation of biofilm and the cell to cell communication involved in regulating this process.
  4. Explain diverse functioning of unique prokaryotic metabolic systems, including anaerobic respiration, fermentations, chemolithotrophy, anoxygenic photosynthesis.
  5. Discuss the molecular interactions that occur in DNA replication and protein synthesis.
  6. Define molecular chaperones and discuss their functions.
  7. Describe the regulation of gene expression including global control systems such as quorum sensing.
  8. Explain the mechanisms of genetic variation such as conjugation, transformation, transduction and mutation.
  9. Discuss plasmids and transposable elements.
  10. Discuss different aspects of recombinant DNA technology such as the use of restriction enzymes and vectors.
  11. Perform agarose gel electrophoresis and explain why and when this procedure is used.
  12. Explain genomic analysis of microbes and bioinformatics.
  13. Outline gene mapping.
  14. Discuss the reproduction of bacteriophages and eukaryotic viruses.
  15. Describe the major disinfectants and antibiotics, including how each chemical functions to kill microbes or inhibit the growth of microbes.
  16. Describe the role of microbes in nutrient recycling and symbiotic relationships including various beneficial aspects of microbes such as the use of microbes in food production.
  17. Outline the components of microbial taxonomy and major taxonomic bacterial groups including sample species in each group.
  18. Discuss nonspecific and specific defenses of the human body against microbes.
  19. List principal mechanisms utilized by bacteria and viruses to function as pathogens.
  20. Discuss representative fungal and protozoan pathogens.
  21. Discuss some of the major bacterial pathogens.
  22. Describe some of the major procedures used in identifying and analyzing microbes.
  23. Discuss the microorganisms in aquatic and terrestrial environments.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: An introduction to the study of the plant kingdom including the origin and evolution of land plants. Topics include cellular structure and function, in depth plant anatomy and plant physiology emphasizing hormonal systems involved in growth, development, fructification and senescence. The course covers all major groups of plants concentrating on flowering plants including an in depth study of floral biology, angiosperm reproduction and angiosperm taxonomy. This course also covers an overview of plant ecology, major uses of plants and major issues in plant conservation. Three hours of lecture and one three-hour laboratory per week. (3 hrs. lecture, 3 hrs. laboratory) Prerequisite: BIO152. Offered on: A-E-G / 4 cr.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Develop a biological vocabulary that will allow them to describe plant structure and function.
  2. Describe vegetative plant structures and functions including the organization of plant histology and morphology.
  3. Examine and comprehend basic plant physiology including the role of plant hormones.
  4. Describe reproductive plant structures and functions including organization of plant histology and morphology.
  5. Identify and contrast plant reproductive strategies and their role in evolution.
  6. Integrate factual knowledge of plants into a conceptual understanding of plant structure and function.
  7. Demonstrate the ability to apply the scientific process to biological questions and information.
  8. Develop laboratory skills to investigate plant evolution, anatomy, and physiology.
  9. Design an experimental approach that addresses a key question or problem in plant biology.
  10. Be able to apply critical thinking strategies to topics and discussions on plant evolution and plant biodiversity.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Special and current topics in Biology may be available. See "Class Schedule Search" for a complete listing each term. Offered on: A-E-G / 3-4 cr. hrs.

Honors special topics in Biology may be available for Honors students as well as those who have received permission from campus Honors Program Coordinator. See "Class Schedule Search" for a complete listing each term. Offered on: A-E-G / 3-4 cr. hrs.
Independent study courses in biology may be available. See the online catalog for a complete listing or contact academic chair. Offered on: A-E-G / 1-4 cr. hrs.

BNR001 Banner ¿ Overview, Policies and Procedures
This course provides an overview of the Banner Finance System, with the focus on changes in policies and procedures that will provide users greater information on and control over their financial resources. This course is a given for all administrators and staff.

Banner # 002 Banner ¿ Budget and Budget Management
This course addresses the changes in the College¿s chart of account. It introduces all Banner users to the FOAPAL structure, the building block for all financial activity; the Banner budget structure, and budget transfer policies and procedures. This course is a must for all administrators and staff with budget management and purchasing responsibility. Enrollees should print out, review and bring to the course the attached document on Self-Service Banner- Finance, that¿s attached to the course (CRN) in which you enroll. Particular attention should be paid to pages 9-end. This is a hands-on course that will allow you to explore your budget, process transfers and execute inquiries to find out your budget is, what funds you have encumbered or reserved, what funds you have spent and how much you have left.

CourseInventory.CourseLongTitle: Banner-Direct purchases and Procurement (The Requisition Process)
CourseInventory.CourseDescription:
BNR003 Banner ¿ Direct Purchases and Procurement (The Requisition Process)
This course addresses how Banner handles the requisition portion of the purchasing process. It examines when you can make a direct purchase and how requisitions are entered. This courses is required for everyone who is involved in the purchasing process. Users will process requisitions in self-service Banner. To get a leg-up on the course, you are strongly encouraged to print out, review and bring to the course materials (with your notes and questions) on the Self-Service Banner- Finance document that¿s attached to the course when you register. Particular attention should be paid to pages 9-end. This is be a hands-on course, where you will initiate requisitions through their approval and submittal to the College¿s purchasing office, and track requisitions through the ordering receiving and payment process. A special course will be offered at a later date for super-users who process lengthy and very complex orders.

CourseInventory.CourseLongTitle: Banner-Vendor Set-up, Purchasing and Bidding and Payment Processing (INB)
CourseInventory.CourseDescription:
BNR004 Banner ¿ Vendor Set up, Purchasing and Bidding, and Payment Processing (INB)
This course is for campus business office and central business office staff (only). It covers functionality that¿s delivered by Internet Native Banner (INB), particularly taking requisitions from their submittal for approval to buyers for action to their completion as purchase orders, with a side-tangent through the bidding. It also covers receiving, payment processing and fixed-asset tagging. This specialized course will be offered in the Annex.

Delves into the most significant activities in business. Topics include ownership, organization, marketing, purchasing, production, business finance, personnel, labor relations and government regulation. Recommended as background for further studies in business. No prerequisite. Offered on: A-E-G / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Explain the interrelationship between the economic, legal, social and technical aspects of the business environment in order to make better decisions;
  2. Identify the major historical influences on U.S. business.
  3. Identify various models with regard to social responsibility of business to society and the role of government in helping to satisfy those responsibilities.
  4. Recognize the “consumerism” and “environmental” movements and incorporate their principles in business activities.
  5. Identify the advantages and disadvantages of the various types of business organizations.
  6. Identify and familiarize themselves with various sources of short term and long term financing.
  7. Identify and explain the functions of management.
  8. Explain the development of organized labor.
  9. Identify the various aspects of production management.
  10. Identify and explain the concept of marketing and its components and be able to integrate these ideas in practice.
  11. Identify and explain the pricing and distribution functions in marketing.
  12. Demonstrate an awareness of career opportunities in business.
  13. Identify and explain the role of information technology and use of Internet resources.
  14. Identify the globalization forces affecting business.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Basic coverage of money and credit creation, financial markets and financial decision-making. No prerequisite. Offered on: E-G / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. The three areas of finance; financial markets, investments, and managerial finance.
  2. Money, the money supply and the role of the FED.
  3. Financial instruments and intermediaries.
  4. Financial business concepts based on analysis of financial statements and financial planning and control concepts.
  5. Corporate decision making based on working capital management and capital structure.
  6. Investment concepts and choices.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Use of mathematics in various business applications. All problem solving is accomplished through arithmetic methods. Topics include percentages, simple and compound interest, discount interest, marketing computations, insurance, basic taxes and investment problems. Does not satisfy mathematics/science elective requirements. No prerequisite. Offered on: A-E-G / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Balance their checking account.
  2. Determine payroll deductions.
  3. Calculate interest charges on credit cards, personal loans, and mortgages.
  4. Figure and understand the implications of income, property, and sales taxes.
  5. Evaluate the financial aspects of a small business (inventory valuations, markup-markdown, depreciation, discounts, and financial statement analysis.
  6. Plan personal investment through the use of insurance, stocks and bonds.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Study of supervisory functions from viewpoint of the first-line supervisor. Emphasis on concepts of supervision and practices used by first-line supervisors in putting them into effect. Gives students actual practice through discussions of case problems arising from work situations. For students enrolled in certificate or A.A.S. business programs who plan to enter the business world immediately upon graduation. No prerequisite. Offered on: A-E-G / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Demonstrate an understanding of the activities involved in the management function in general and on the role of the first-line supervisor in particular as a member of the management team in planning, organizing, staffing, directing and controlling.
  2. Demonstrate techniques for problem solving using the case approach.
  3. Apply oral and written communication skills in the performance of supervisory job duties.
  4. Recognize and evaluate changes in the work place and their impact on the employer.
  5. Demonstrate leadership styles and skills and use them in realistic situations.
  6. Conduct interviews, administer tests, and complete performance appraisals.
  7. Provide rationales for personnel changes such as promotions, transfers, demotions, reclassifications and compensation adjustments.
  8. Identify and apply strategies for introducing change and overcoming resistance.
  9. Integrate management principles in applications in the area of minority and legally protected employees.
  10. Apply strategies for the allocation of work assignments, maintaining discipline and improving morale.
  11. Assess employee complaints and grievances and interact effectively with union representatives.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: State-of-the-art computer skills related to business major. Emphasis on integrated problem-solving approach. Trains students to make bottom-line decisions using "what if" models and decision trees. Business presentation skills presented using PowerPoint. Current technological business research skills emphasized. Students required to construct a one-page business website. No prerequisite. Offered on: A-E-G / 4 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Integrate desktop programs to process complex business information.
  2. Prepare electronic messages, appointments, contacts, tasks and electronic downloads.
  3. Develop analytical skills using Excel, Presentation skills using Power Point and organizational skills using Outlook.
  4. Interpret advanced business charting using Excel.
  5. Apply Business Communications skills through group presentations and team projects.
  6. Understand business analysis using management problem solving with PC software and the World Wide Web.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Introduces business student to general skills needed for success in workplace. Connects the college experience and its impact on students' skills necessary to compete in world of work. Fulfills College Seminar requirement for students in accounting, business-related and paralegal curricula. No prerequisite. Offered on: A-E-G / 1 cr. hr.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Understand the work place skills required by industry.
  2. Understand the need for diversity in the workplaces.
  3. Understand basic time management, goal setting, writing skills necessary to be successful in the workplace and colleges.
  4. Understand teamwork and conflict resolution.
  5. Create a resume and develop the skills to obtain employment using Electronic Portfolio technology.
  6. Understand the connection of college programs, the college and world of work.
  7. Use college resources to advance the students’ career objectives.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Principles of business communication as they relate to the contemporary business organization. Emphasis on management approaches and solutions to communication problems unique to the business community. Topics include word/information processing, employment communication, and effective preparation of business correspondence and reports. Resume writing and marketing oneself for the job search is explored. Prerequisite: ENG101 or permission of instructor. Offered on: A-E-G / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Understand the theories and principles of business communications.
  2. Understand sundry business communication tasks such as planning conferences and conducting business meetings.
  3. Apply skills necessary to write effective letters and memoranda using a psychological business approach.
  4. Apply skills necessary to write formal and informal business reports.
  5. Manage data and use graphics to enhance written communication projects.
  6. Develop an understanding of the principles involved in listening, nonverbal, and cross-cultural skills.
  7. Practice effective techniques for creating, presenting and follow up oral presentations.
  8. Apply ethical and legal guidelines when making communication decisions.
  9. Use terminology and benefits of electronic communication technology as it relates to the efficient formatting of letters, memoranda, reports, and employment postings.
  10. Recognize and utilize formal and informal lines of communication in business organizations.
  11. Produce multi-media presentations working in a team environment.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Introduces scope and responsibilities of administrative office management. Topics include planning, organizing, operating and controlling office operations; leadership and human relations factors; and an overview of the effect office technology has had on the business world including telecommunications, reprographics, office systems, records management, data processing, word processing and voice processing. No prerequisite. Offered on: A-E-G / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Define the functions of Administrative Office Management.
  2. Understanding basic management principles.
  3. Explain the steps in the problem-solving process.
  4. Describe the outcome to be realized by a firm that conducts an effective office terminology program.
  5. Explain the purpose served by a program of job analysis.
  6. Analyze the office space needs of the organization.
  7. Understand the principles that guide administrative office managers in preparing budgets.
  8. Plan an ergonomically sound office environment.
  9. Manage a culturally diverse work force.
  10. Recruit, orient, train, and appraise office employees.
  11. Select office furniture and equipment.
  12. Conduct a communication audit.
  13. Manage office records.
  14. Assess office productivity.
  15. Understand the concept of office systems.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Study of environment of small business and functions and philosophy of entrepreneur. Topics include problems in initiating and achieving success in new small business, including financing, marketing, management and legal governmental relationships involved. No prerequisite. Offered on: A-E-G / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Understand the mechanics of establishing a business and dealing effectively with competitors, customers and employees.
  2. Demonstrate an understanding of the basic financial statements.
  3. Identify alternatives available to finance the new firm.
  4. Determine the most advantageous form and structure of the firm.
  5. Develop a sales volume by understanding the importance of:
    1. advertising and promotion
    2. pricing policies
    3. types of merchandise sold
  6. Understand prudent financial management and control of:
    1. business expenses
    2. customer credit program
  7. Evaluate and deal with business risks.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Study of the nature of people in a business environment, significance of work, and the human resource. Topics include job satisfaction and motivation, formal and informal work groups, organization and authority, employee relations with the public, decision making and problem solving, the needs and goals of both people and the business environment. No prerequisite. Offered on: A-E-G / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Define organizational behavior and relate it to the typical manager's job.
  2. Define organizational structure and describe the differences between universal and contingency approaches to organizational structure.
  3. Define organizational culture and explain its foundations.
  4. Describe the nature of employee motivation including equity theory, expectancy theory, reinforcement theory and need theories of motivation.
  5. Identify and discuss individual and organizational causes of stress.
  6. Describe characteristics of groups and discuss the roles groups play within organizations.
  7. Discuss the common bases of power within organizations and illustrate how power is used.
  8. Explain why ethics is an important component of organizational decision making.
  9. Explain the nature of individual differences in organizations and including attitude formation, dissonance in the workplace and job related attitudes.
  10. Discuss different approaches to work design and show how each contributes to an understanding of how to match people and tasks.
  11. Discuss the use and effects of technology related to organization.
  12. Understand the cultural dynamics found in a diversified organization.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Study of purposes, objectives and techniques of personnel administration. The role of personnel administration, human relations, procurement, interviewing, selection and training of personnel, labor relations, research and control of the personnel functions. No prerequisite. Offered on: A-E-G / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Establish a relationship between human resource management and the total management system.
  2. Explain the role and importance of work in society and the achievement of organizational and individual goals. Explain how and why work is organized and jobs are created.
  3. Explain the functions of management and how the formal personnel program affects employees in the accomplishment of organization goals.
  4. Demonstrate familiarity with the processing and sources involved in human resources recruiting in view of legal and social change.
  5. Outline the roles of the human resource management department interviewer and the supervisor in judging candidates for performance and continuity with the organization.
  6. Recognize the importance of continuous development programs for employees and managers. Explain the role of training and its limitations, the psychological principles of learning and differing methodologies.
  7. Identify some of the major problems facing all organizations due to change, and how management as an agent for change can accomplish the organization’s objectives with and through its people.
  8. Construct the evolutionary relationship of labor and management through recognition procedures, collective bargaining, resolution of differences and current trends.
  9. Establish the importance of an objective wage and salary structure as both a financial and psychological return for work.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Familiarizes business students with international business concepts and practices. Special attention given to organizational structure of international business; letters of credit; bills of exchange; foreign drafts; technical procedures; documentation; foreign, consular, and domestic regulations; foreign credits; insuring and financing; and exports. No prerequisite. Offered on: A-E-G / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Understand the basic international trade concepts and practices.
  2. Understand the issues in handling foreign documentation.
  3. Understand the types of foreign and domestic regulations.
  4. Understand terminology and technical procedures of international business.
  5. Identify the types of foreign credits available in international business.
  6. Understand the financial management of imports and exports.
  7. Understand the general issues related to imports and exports.
  8. Understand the balance of trade and balance payments.
  9. Analyze global market places and business centers.
  10. Understand the issues relevant to managing the international environment and business operations.
  11. Create and present an international business plan.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Cooperative Education is supervised on-the-job training directly related to a student¿s academic major and career interest. Co-op students integrate classroom theory with practical work experience. Through a required weekly seminar, students receive instruction in employment communications and discuss work station learning experiences. Students must be available to work a minimum of 10 hours per week. Interested students should contact appropriate program coordinator on their campus for more information. Registration in this course requires that students purchase liability insurance through the college. Prerequisite: Completion of at least 24 credit hours (12 credits being in the business area, with the exception of CST students), minimum overall GPA of 2.5, and permission of appropriate co-op coordinator or Chair/Academic Dean. Offered on: A-E-G / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Understand systems including organization systems and policies, technological systems, etc.
  2. Apply analytical skills such as problem identification and solution.
  3. Develop agreements involving the exchange of resources and divergent interests.
  4. Analyze realistic case studies and justify alternatives for resolving issues.
  5. Understand past workplace behaviors in order to predict future outcomes.
  6. Understand organizational concepts.
  7. Examine subject areas such as: Time Management, Workplace Ethics, Effective Business communications, Sexual Harassment, Handling Conflicts, etc.
  8. Understand the role of continuing education for further career and professional growth.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Study of basic managerial functions of planning, organizing, staffing, direction and control. Emphasis on theory of management, organization and executive leadership. Case studies of actual business situations present problems requiring executive decisions for solution. No prerequisite. Offered on: A-E-G / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Identify the skills and rolls necessary for effective management.
  2. Explain and relate the basic functions of management- planning, organizing, etc. to all levels of management and to the success of the organization.
  3. Identify and explain the various types of positions and their functions typically found in large organizations.
  4. Identify the various leadership styles and explain relevant motivational theories.
  5. Identify and explain several theories regarding the decision making process.
  6. Relate the concepts of authority, responsibility and accountability to the chain of command.
  7. Explain the nature of delegation and identify the barriers to delegation.
  8. Identify major control techniques used in organizations and how they are applied.
  9. Identify and explain the role of information technology related to management.
  10. Identify issues endemic to a diversified work force.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Advanced capstone course for Business Administration (A.S.) majors taken final semester before graduation. Working individually and in teams, students integrate, strengthen, expand, apply and document business administration skills and competencies. Through solution of case studies, students demonstrate abilities to think critically, solve managerial, quantitative, and ethical business problems, and utilize contemporary business-related technology. Other active learning assignments may be included as students exercise effective business management and leadership skills and develop global business mindset. Prerequisite: Completion of a least 45 credits in the Business Administration A.S. degree curriculum (BUAS-AS), including ACC115, BUS201, ENG101, MKT101 and LAW111. Offered on: A-E-G / 1 cr. hr.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Use contemporary business vocabulary and concepts.
  2. Apply a broad range of information management, quantitative, research, and technological skills to business-related tasks.
  3. Use critical thinking, problem-solving, and decision-making skills.
  4. Communicate well orally and in writing.
  5. Manage business resources through the management functions of planning, organizing, staffing, leading, and evaluating.
  6. Demonstrate the development and use of profitable business strategies related to business operations, marketing, accounting, and management.
  7. Identify and explain examples of ethical and social responsibility decisions faced by domestic and international businesses.
  8. Discuss how globalization has affected U.S. business practices.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Advanced capstone course for Business Administration (A.A.S.) majors taken final semester before graduation. Working individually and in teams, students demonstrate abilities to think critically, solve managerial, quantitative and ethical business problems, utilize business-related technology, and exhibit effective leadership in response to current business events and case studies. Through variety of learner-centered activities, students assemble portfolios documenting effective communication skills, understanding, and practical knowledge of business administration. Prerequisite: Completion of at least 45 credits in BUAD-AAS curriculum, including ACC101, BUS101, LAW111, MKT101, and a business elective. Offered on: A-E-G / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Use contemporary business vocabulary and concepts.
  2. Apply a broad range of information management, quantitative, research, and technological skills to business-related tasks.
  3. Use critical thinking, problem-solving, and decision-making skills.
  4. Communicate well orally and in writing.
  5. Manage business resources through the functions of planning, organizing, staffing, leading, and evaluating.
  6. Identify and explain examples of ethical and social responsibility decisions faced by domestic and international businesses.
  7. Prepare appropriate employment correspondence.
  8. Discuss how globalization has affected U.S. business practices.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Special and current topics in Business may be available. See "Class Schedule Search" for a complete listing each term. Offered on: A-E-G / 3-4 cr. hrs.
Independent study courses in business may be available. See the online catalog for a complete listing or contact academic chair. Offered on: A-E-G / 1-4 cr. hrs.

Comprehensive exploration of historical, pharmacological, social and psychological aspects of abuse of and addiction to substances by society. Explores society¿s attitudes and misconceptions about substance use and reviews current theories of addiction treatment and prevention for both addicts and significant others. No prerequisite. Offered on: A-E-G / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Offer an inclusive and accurate definition of the term “drug”.
  2. Categorize drugs according to their properties, uses, effects, and legal status.
  3. Differentiate the concepts “use”, “misuse”, “abuse”, and “addiction” in relation to drugs.
  4. Demonstrate knowledge of how our history impacts current attitudes and policy related to drugs.
  5. Be able to define and to recognize addictions and to demonstrate knowledge of current theories of use and addiction.
  6. Demonstrate knowledge of current theories of treatment of abuse and addiction.
  7. Demonstrate a knowledge of the effects of addiction upon significant others.
  8. Demonstrate knowledge of current theories of prevention/education as they relate to drugs.
  9. Formulate ideas related to public policy that may mitigate the “drug problem”.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: In-depth exploration of biological, psychological and social theories of substance use, abuse and addiction with emphasis on their implications for prevention and treatment. Related addictive behaviors including concept of co-dependence are studied. Prerequisite: CDC111 or permission of Chair/Academic Dean. Offered on: E-G / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Develop a broader base of knowledge regarding the prerequisite, CDC111.
  2. Create a clear and logically consistent perspective on addictive disease.
  3. Further recognize patterns of addictive behavior.
  4. Develop a strong understanding of current research regarding the neuropsychology of use, abuse, and addiction.
  5. Explore psychoactive substances from a neuro-behavioral approach.
  6. Begin to understand such topics as assessment, treatment planning, education, relapse and recovery

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Comprehensive exploration of effects of addiction and dysfunction on nuclear and extended family systems. Focuses on identification, education and treatment of "significant others" who may be affected by a person's substance abuse or addiction. Prerequisite: CDC111 or permission of Chair/Academic Dean. Offered on: A-E-G / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Identify roles and treatment issues in the addicted family.
  2. Learn the necessary skills needed in treatment of family members affected by addiction.
  3. Theoretically analyze treatment modalities in the field of working with family members of the addicted.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Exploration of formal and informal responses of criminal justice system to crimes and social disorder related to alcohol/substance abuse. Includes analysis of effectiveness of both law enforcement and diversionary strategies to combat endemic problems of controlled substances and alcohol. Prerequisite: CDC111 or permission of Chair/Academic Dean. Offered on: G / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Discuss the relationship between the criminal justice system and the alcohol/drug treatment system.
  2. Discuss the history of the laws pertaining to drugs.
  3. Describe the criminal justice substance abuser.
  4. Identify various correctional treatment programs.
  5. Discuss confidentiality laws.

CourseInventory.CourseLongTitle: Professional Documentation: Data Collection, Assessment, Treatment Planning
CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Comprehensive examination of all documentation utilized in various health system agencies, with particular attention to those agencies specializing in alcohol/drug treatment. Includes actual preparation of various professional materials, i.e., psychosocial data and assessments, treatment plans, clinical reports, progress notes and other specialized material. Prerequisite: CDC111 or permission of Chair/Academic Dean. Offered on: G / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Recount various legal requirements pertaining to the operation of a chemical dependency treatment center and to the practice of chemical dependency counseling in the state of New York.
  2. Demonstrate knowledge of the importance of professional documentation.
  3. Demonstrate the ability to actually document an intake interview, create a psychosocial profile, develop a comprehensive treatment plan, keep ongoing case records, and develop a discharge and follow-up plan.
  4. Demonstrate knowledge of professional standards and the laws pertaining to confidentiality.
  5. Demonstrate knowledge of the impact of AIDS on the chemical dependency counseling field.
  6. Be able to apply the basic principles of counselor wellness in their lives.

CourseInventory.CourseLongTitle: Techniques for Counseling the Chemically Dependent Client
CourseInventory.CourseDescription: In-depth examination of basic precepts of helping relationships. The student studies and practices client interviewing, goal setting, development and implementation of a client action plan, and how to promote client motivation. Emphasizes working with the chemically dependent client. Prerequisite: CDC115 and CDC120 or permission of Chair/Academic Dean. Offered on: G / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Examine their understanding and attitudes toward the disease concept of chemical addiction and judge how they may affect the counseling process.
  2. Personalize and utilize therapeutic communication techniques to address client needs.
  3. Understand and be aware of the negative and positive effects which the client-counselor relationship can have on the counseling process and consciously maximize the latter.
  4. Select from and utilize a wide range of skills in the furtherance of the counseling process.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: History of substance abuse prevention efforts with emphasis on various approaches to the problem and evaluation of their effectiveness. Includes evaluation of needs of special populations within the larger community. Current theory and practice are reviewed through a study of several actual prevention programs. Students expected to develop and present a prevention lesson in the class. Prerequisite: CDC111 or permission of department. Offered on: G / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Understand the bio/psycho/social model to Prevention.
  2. Identify at least five current prevention programs.
  3. Explore prevention strategies.
  4. Identify risk factors and health choices.
  5. Understand the systems approach to prevention and current uses in prevention planning.

CourseInventory.CourseLongTitle: Chemical Dependency Vocational Counseling and Prevention/Education Programs
CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Development and implementation of the Vocational and Educational Treatment Plan with the chemically dependent individual (alcohol/substance). Exploration of the history of substance abuse prevention efforts with emphasis on various approaches to the problem and evaluation of their effectiveness. Includes evaluation of needs of special populations within the larger community. Current theory and practice are reviewed through a study of several actual prevention programs. Students expected to develop and present a prevention lesson in the class. Prerequisite: CDC111 or permission of Chair/Academic Dean. Offered on: G / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Define and understand the process of vocational rehabilitation.
  2. Demonstrate knowledge of the history of vocational rehabilitation.
  3. Demonstrate the ability to assess a client for vocational rehabilitation readiness.
  4. Develop a realistic vocational plan by identifying client’s strengths and weakness’.
  5. Identify public programs and resources to further assist potential clients.
  6. Demonstrate the ability to assist clients with the job search, interview preparation and maintain employment.
  7. Identify potential obstacles to employment for individual’s with chemical dependency history, including legal histories.
  8. Document client data and complete documentation required by public agencies such as OASAS.
  9. Demonstrate the knowledge of the relation of work and recovery.
  10. Understand the bio/psycho/social model to Prevention.
  11. Identify at least five current prevention programs.
  12. Explore prevention strategies.
  13. Identify risk factors and health choices.
  14. Understand the systems approach to prevention and current uses in prevention planning.

CourseInventory.CourseLongTitle: Advanced Techniques for Counseling the Chemically Dependent Client
CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Advanced counseling and therapy concepts and techniques that apply to assessment, diagnosis and treatment modalities for addictions and for psychosocial conditions that may coexist with the chemical dependency condition. Also addresses collateral treatment concerns for ¿significant other¿ persons involved with the chemically dependent client as well as appropriate uses of supervision, peer support, professional affiliations, and continuing professional education for the practitioner. Working with health professionals on the treatment team emphasized. Prerequisite: CDC235. Offered on: G / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Compare and contrast the major therapeutic approaches that are involved with the treatment of addictions as distinguished from those of other disorders.
  2. Demonstrate the ability to develop and intervention and to include an appropriate relapse prevention program into a treatment plan.
  3. Demonstrate the ability to work with clients of various sexual orientations and who may present a wide variety of problems commonly associated with chemical dependency.
  4. Recognize the unique treatment needs of those involved in a dependent relationship and develop an appropriate response to those needs.
  5. Interface professionally with representatives from related treatment disciplines.
  6. Identify the ways that a practitioner may maintain a state of mental and physical health through the appropriate use of supervision, peer support, and professional affiliations.
  7. Demonstrate the knowledge of referral agencies within the local community.
  8. Identify and access appropriate resources for professional development.

CourseInventory.CourseLongTitle: Habilitation and Rehabilitation of Chemically Dependent Client
CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Development and implementation of the Vocational and Educational Treatment Plan with the chemically dependent individual (alcohol/substance). Prerequisite: CDC111 or permission of department. Offered on: G / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Define and understand the process of vocational rehabilitation
  2. Demonstrate knowledge of the history of vocational rehabilitation
  3. Demonstrate the ability to assess a client for vocational rehabilitation readiness
  4. Develop a realistic vocational plan by identifying client’s strengths and weakness’
  5. Identify public programs and resources to further assist potential clients
  6. Demonstrate the ability to assist clients with the job search, interview preparation and maintain employment
  7. Identify potential obstacles to employment for individual’s with chemical dependency history, including legal histories.
  8. Document client data and complete documentation required by public agencies such as OASAS.
  9. Demonstrate the knowledge of the relation of work and recovery

CourseInventory.CourseLongTitle: Chemical Dependency Professional Ethics and Cultural Competence
CourseInventory.CourseDescription: This course includes the OASAS required hours specific to ethics and cultural competence for addiction professionals, including the required child abuse and maltreatment mandated reporter NYS Education Department approved training. Course goals include understanding the ethics and professional responsibilities of the counselor-client relationship, the CASAC Canon of Ethical Principles, ethical decision making and conduct, the importance of critical thinking skills, counselor self-disclosure, confidentiality laws and regulations (HIPPA and 42CFR part 2), responsibility for seeking and using clinical supervision, and the importance of counselor wellness and self-evaluation. The course also addresses counseling special populations/cultural competency. It provides knowledge of the specific chemical dependency prevention/treatment needs of particular populations and development of the skills necessary to effectively counsel individuals in those populations as well as training to develop the ability to understand, communicate with and effectively interact with people across diverse cultures. Prerequisite: CDC230 and CDC235. Offered on: G / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Understand the dynamics of counselor-client relationships:
    1. Knowledge of the therapeutic alliance as a unique relationship between counselor and client.
    2. Integrating basic counseling skills into the therapeutic alliance.
    3. Recognize ethical standards and professional responsibilities to the client, patient rights and informed consent.
    4. Recognizing individual differences and cultural competence in counseling different populations.
    5. Knowledge of clinical boundaries, transference and counter-transference.
  2. Understand the following areas of ethical decision making and conduct:
    1. Knowledge of the use of critical thinking skills and analysis in effective ethical decision making.
    2. Recognize the differences between virtue ethics and ethical decision-making by formal codes of ethics.
    3. Knowledge of professional and ethical responsibilities of Chemical Dependency Counselors.
    4. The CASAC Canon of Ethical Principles.
    5. The Association for Addiction Professionals (NAADAC) Ethical Standards of Alcoholism and Drug Abuse Counselors.
    6. Examine clinical supervision as an ethical obligation throughout the career of a counselor.
  3. Understand Confidentiality and legal issues:
    1. Knowledge of current federal and state laws governing the appropriate delivery of alcoholism and substance abuse services.
    2. When are you permitted to violate confidentiality? Exceptions to the rule.
    3. The difference between consent and informed consent.
  4. Report Child Abuse and Maltreatment as required by all mandated reporter:
    1. Knowledge and skills to be able to effectively report child abuse or maltreatment/neglect.
  5. Recognize the Importance of Counselor Wellness:
    1. Recognize the define compassion fatigue, burnout and other job-related stresses and how to identify, prevent and recover from its effects.
    2. Recognize the importance of and techniques for fostering counselor self-care, self-awareness and evaluation and the relationship between a healthy body, healthy mind and counselor wellness.
  6. Understand the following four components of cultural competence:
    1. Awareness of one's own cultural worldview,
    2. Attitude towards cultural differences,
    3. Knowledge of different cultural practices and worldviews, and
    4. Cross-cultural skills.

CourseInventory.CourseLongTitle: Field Practicum or Cooperative Education in Chemical Dependency
CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Integrates theory with actual practice in a clinical setting. Students perform intake interviews and assessments, develop treatment plans, do counseling and present intervention and education approaches, all within the context of the legal, ethical and professional responsibilities of the chemical dependency counselor. Involves off-campus fieldwork: a minimum of 270 hours of clinical experience and 30 hours of supervision. Students attend two-hour, weekly on-campus supervision seminars. Internship placements must be in a licensed chemical dependency counseling center and be supervised by a qualified professional. Students should take CDC255 in their final semester of study. Note: Registration in this course requires that students contact the program coordinator in the semester prior to enrollment in the course to obtain permission and vital information. Registrants must: 1. Purchase liability insurance through the College; 2. File a Physician's Certificate; 3. Complete other requirements prior to the beginning of class. Please contact the program coordinator for additional information. (18 hrs. clinical, 2 hrs. seminar) Prerequisite: CDC120, CDC225 and CDC235. Corequisite: CDC246. Offered on: G / 7 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Work effectively with crisis intervention and hot line telephone calls.
  2. Perform and intake interview.
  3. Demonstrate the ability to incorporate psycho-social data into a treatment plan in a professional manner.
  4. Identify symptoms pertinent to diagnosis using the DSM-IV diagnostic manual.
  5. Present verbal and written reports on client status and progress.
  6. Perform individual counseling services.
  7. Facilitate group counseling services.
  8. Provide family treatment.
  9. Demonstrate a knowledge of, and an ability to utilize appropriate community resources in treatment and discharge.
  10. Plan/perform educational presentations to the Alcohol/Drug affected population.
  11. Demonstration the ability to provide outreach services to specific target populations.
  12. Participate in the design and implementation of other services related to alcohol and drug rehabilitation.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: A laboratory science elective for non-science majors as well as a required course for Dietetic Technician majors. CHE100 is also required for prospective allied health majors who do not meet the prerequisite for BIO130: Anatomy and Physiology I. Topics include atomic structure, bonding, chemical equations, changes in energy, gas laws, acid-base chemistry, solutions, and chemical equilibria. Laboratory techniques are introduced and followed by experiments which illustrate basic principles presented in lecture. Notes: (1) Credit given for CHE100 or CHE122, but not both. (2) Fulfills SUNY General Education Requirement for Natural Sciences. (3 hrs. lecture, 3 hrs. laboratory) Prerequisite: MAT007 or high school Integrated Algebra or equivalent. Offered on: A-E-G / 4 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Solving problems involving atomic structure.
  2. Solving problems involving chemical bonding.
  3. Chemical nomenclature.
  4. Balancing and interpreting chemical equations.
  5. Solving problems involving chemical reactions.
  6. Comprehending gas-laws and chemical equilibria.
  7. Solving problems involving acids, bases and solutions.
  8. Solving stoichiometry problems.
  9. Performing basic laboratory techniques and experiments, which illustrate the chemical principles presented in lecture.

CourseInventory.CourseLongTitle: Introduction to General Organic and Biochemistry
CourseInventory.CourseDescription: One-semester course required for Veterinary Science Technology students. Basic principles of general, organic and biochemistry are presented with emphasis on applications to health science. Topics include measurement, states of matter, bonding theory, solutions, acids, buffers and pH, structure and function of carbohydrates, lipids, sterols, amino acids, proteins, molecular approach to enzymatic action, digestion, metabolism and nutrition. Note: (1) Fulfills SUNY General Education Requirement for Natural Sciences. (2) Restricted to VST students in the fall and alternative summer semesters. (3 hrs. lecture, 2 hrs. laboratory) Prerequisite: MAT007 or equivalent and high school chemistry with laboratory. Offered on: G / 4 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Solving problems involving atomic structure.
  2. Solving problems involving chemical bonding.
  3. Chemical nomenclature.
  4. Balancing and interpreting chemical equations.
  5. Solving problems involving chemical reactions.
  6. Comprehending gas-laws and chemical equilibria.
  7. Solving problems involving acids, bases and solutions.
  8. Solving stoichiometry problems.
  9. Knowledge of structure and function of basic organic and biochemical molecules.
  10. Observation and recording of data and preparation of laboratory reports.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: One-semester course presenting chemical principles, specifically designed for students enrolled in a science or engineering curriculum who plan to enroll in a one-year course in college chemistry (CHE 133-134). Lectures provide introduction to general principles, laws of chemical combination, thermochemistry, electrochemistry and chemical equilibrium. Laboratory work illustrates basic principles presented in lectures. Notes: (1) When CHE122 is not available, CHE100 may be substituted with permission of department. (2) CHE122 may not be used as a substitute for CHE133. Neither CHE100 nor CHE122 may be taken after a student has completed CHE133 or its equivalent. (3) Credit given for CHE122 or CHE100, but not both. (4) Fulfills SUNY General Education Requirement for Natural Sciences. (3 hrs. lecture, 3 hrs. laboratory) Prerequisite: MAT007 or high school Integrated Algebra or equivalent. Corequisite: MAT111 or permission of Chair/Academic Dean. Offered on: A / 4 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Understanding Laws of general chemical principles.
  2. Writing the name and formula for inorganic compounds.
  3. Using chemical equations representing chemical reactions.
  4. Comprehending and solving problems involving chemical reactions.
  5. Describing electronic configurations and atomic structures.
