  5. Describe the role nutrition plays in the physiological and psychosocial development of children and adolescents.
  6. Identify how gender, race, ethnicity and religion influence the development of food habits in the early years.
  7. Explain the relationship between diet and the prevention of chronic diseases common in adulthood.
  8. Evaluate the nutritional needs of the senior population and explain how diet affects their quality of life.
  9. Apply nutritional assessment tools in determining diet history, anthropometric measures, and biochemical analysis to the evaluation of dietary needs of each age group.
  10. Explain the relationship between exercise, diet and good health throughout the life span.
  11. Describe the principles of maintaining energy balance, identifying factors that lead to under and over nutrition in each age category.
  12. Describe federal, state, county and voluntary community nutrition programs that provide nutrition education and assistance across the lifespan.
  13. Describe factors that affect eating disorders and analyze them in terms of weight management.
  14. Describe county, state and federal programs that are available to provide nutrition education or assistance in feeding to those in need within each age category.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Survey course introducing the variety of foods available, menu planning, purchasing and preparation. Topics include food measurement, legislation, safety and sanitation, preparation techniques for nutritional adequacy, and food acceptability. Food labs held in kitchen. (offered fall semester only) Prerequisite: DTE101 and DTE103 with grades of C or higher. Minimum grade of C is required to advance to next course in DTE sequence. Offered on: E / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Create a menu that is nutritious, economical and appetizing.
  2. Analyze their own diets for macronutrients (protein, fat, carbohydrates) and selected vitamins and minerals and determine realistic strategies to improve them.
  3. In a laboratory environment using methods of food handling that ensure safety and prevent food borne illness, demonstrate principles of food science related to measurement, pH, starch, protein, and fat cookery.
  4. Describe food selection, preparation and storage methods that conserve nutrients and produce acceptable products.
  5. Utilize HACCP (Hazard Analysis Critical Control Point) guidelines to develop a standardized recipe.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Capstone course for the Dietetic Technician Program. Orientation to the profession of dietetics with an emphasis on professional organizations, ethical issues related to dietetics practice, and career and educational opportunities. Legislative and policy making related to dietetics is explored. Application of evidence based practice versus media propaganda is demonstrated. (offered spring semester only) Corequisites: DTE211 and DTE213. Minimum grade of C is required to advance to next course in DTE sequence. Offered on: E / 1 cr. hr.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Compare the education, credentials and responsibilities of various dietetics professionals including a DM, DTR, and RD.
  2. Describe how health care is delivered in the U.S. today.
  3. Demonstrate ethical behavior in accordance with the ADA code of ethics.
  4. Develop a professional resume, cover letter and thank-you letter in preparation for career exploration.
  5. Demonstrate elements of a job interview including appropriate attire.
  6. Describe federal, state, county and voluntary nutrition programs currently available that provide nutrition education and assistance to those in need.
  7. Compare food choices based upon racial, cultural and religious differences.
  8. Contrast the role of complementary and alternative nutrition therapies with traditional medical nutrition therapy.
  9. Identify legislation and public policies that affect food, food security, and nutrition care.
  10. Demonstrate skills in word processing, use of the internet, and email.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Considers rationale and characteristics of selected therapeutic diets, their application, planning, calculation and menu adjustment. Purchase of liability insurance through the college is required. (Offered fall semester only.) (3 hrs. lecture, 132 hrs. clinical, 48 hrs. field work) Prerequisites: CHE100 and DTE121 with grades of C or higher. Minimum grade of C is required to advance to next course in DTE sequence. Offered on: E / 7 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Describe the factors that must be considered in developing a nutritional assessment care plan and progress notes.
  2. Discuss the relationship between nutrition and stress.
  3. Identify and explain various routes of feeding and the use of dietary supplements.
  4. Explain the rationale for diets modified in consistency.
  5. Explain the role of nutrition in the treatment and/or prevention of the following disorders:
    1. Gastrointestinal Tract (Upper and Lower)
    2. Liver
    3. Diabetes
    4. Blood Vessels and Heart
    5. Lungs
    6. Renal
    7. Cancer
    8. AIDS
  6. Discuss meal plans that meet the nutrient requirements of individuals with the aforementioned disorders.
  7. Describe the uses for medication and complementary therapies in the treatment of diseases.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Relates to functions of food service manager regarding policies and procedures; food procurement, preparation and service; sanitation and safety in quality food preparation; interaction and communication of food service personnel with others; personnel functions, cost control and budget implementation; layout and design of kitchen equipment; and use of computerized data processing systems. Registration in this course requires that students purchase liability insurance through the college. (offered spring semester only) Prerequisite: DTE201 and DTE205 with grade of C or higher. Corequisite: DTE203 and DTE213. Offered on: E / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Identify and explain operational procedures used in a foodservice establishment.
  2. Describe and compare the responsibilities of various professional and support personnel who function within a foodservice operation.
  3. Demonstrate types of communication necessary for effective interaction among supervisors, peers, subordinates, clients/patrons and/or patients.
  4. Apply the principles of Total Quality Management to all areas of foodservice operations.
  5. Describe the laws, regulations and standards that affect foodservice operations.
  6. Identify fundamentals of merchandising and marketing and describe how they affect sales in foodservice.
  7. Describe basic principles of food procurement, production, storage, distribution and service and explain how the relationship of these operations contributes to a systems approach in foodservice management.
  8. Describe concepts of financial management in a foodservice operation and explain how they contribute to the bottom line.
  9. Describe how principles of equipment layout and design can be utilized to create an efficient and productive plan for dietary services.
  10. Describe the variety, design, and operation of equipment required to prepare and deliver food.
  11. Describe applications of a computerized data processing system to foodservice operations.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Under direction of fieldwork instructor, student has hands-on experience in all aspects of food service management at a local health care facility. Requires purchase of liability insurance through the college. (offered spring semester only) (1 hr. lecture, 180 hrs. fieldwork) Corequisite: DTE203 and DTE211. Offered on: E / 5 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Identify and demonstrate operational procedures used in a foodservice establishment.
  2. Describe and compare the responsibilities of various professional and support personnel who function within a foodservice operation.
  3. Compare and demonstrate types of communication necessary for effective interaction among peers, supervisors, employees, clients/patrons and/or patients.
  4. Apply the principles of Total Quality Management to all areas of foodservice operations.
  5. Describe the laws, regulations and standards that affect foodservice operations.
  6. Identify fundamentals of merchandising and marketing and describe how they affect foodservice sales.
  7. Demonstrate principles of food procurement, production, storage, distribution and service.
  8. Describe the concepts of financial management in a foodservice operation and explain how they contribute to the bottom line.
  9. Analyze how the layout and design of a foodservice area affects the efficiency of its operation.
  10. Demonstrate the operation of equipment used to prepare and deliver food.
  11. Describe how a computerized data processing system is utilized in a foodservice operation.
  12. Demonstrate procedures to maintain a safe and sanitary environment in a foodservice operation.
  13. Demonstrate ethical behavior that is consistent with the ADA Code of Ethics.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: This 60-hour training course assists new and existing business owners with the creation of a business strategy. The course covers the basic business model: marketing, management, finances, taxes, and business law.Each participant will compleate a business plan. (20 meetings). For more infomation and to register call 631-851-6214. Tuition is $300.00.

This workshop prepares business owners to do business with the government agencies. meetings #1 nad #3 will focus on minority and woman business owners securing certification with New York State. Meeting #2 will biscuss how to identify contract opportunities with government agencies. At the final meeting, participants will learn how to prepare bid proposals. (4 meetings) For more infomation and to registar call 631-851-6214. No Tuition required.

Introduces use of economic methods for understanding social and political events dominating news headlines. Crime, health care, poverty and taxes are issues important in our daily lives and may serve as topics in developing the course. Note: Fulfills SUNY General Education Requirement for Social Sciences. No prerequisite. Offered on: A-E-G / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Use supply and demand as a tool to explain economic theories.
  2. Understand the concept of elasticity.
  3. Differentiate the different market structures (perfect competition, monopoly, monopolistic competition, and oligopoly).
  4. Explain market failure (externalities, public goods).
  5. Explain the different types of unemployment and inflation.
  6. Understand the nature of the business cycle.
  7. Know the difference between monetary and fiscal policy.
  8. Know the limitations of current stabilization policies.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Course begins with simplified description of a complex matter: how and how well does a national economy work? Over short periods of time, production and employment are known to be volatile, while over longer periods of time production and employment grow. Why is each of these observations true and what is role of government (if any) in the process? Note: Fulfills SUNY General Education Requirement for Social Sciences. No prerequisite. Offered on: A-E-G / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Understand the economic way of thinking.
  2. Use opportunity cost.
  3. Understand the uses of production possibility frontiers.
  4. Use supply and demand analysis for individual markets and for the macro economy.
  5. Explain how the U.S. economy is performing through an understanding of the national income accounts.
  6. Understand unemployment, inflation, and business cycles.
  7. Know the difference between the short and long run aggregate supply curve.
  8. Manipulate aggregate demand and supply curves to determine the implications of different fiscal and monetary policies.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Introduces structure and operation of markets for goods, resources and financial instruments. How does a market determine the price for a good? Within a market, how does the firm determine its profit-maximizing production level of a good and employment level of labor? How does competitiveness of the market affect behavior of the firm? Under what circumstances (if any) should government alter decisions of the marketplace? Note: Fulfills SUNY General Education Requirement for Social Sciences. No prerequisite. Offered on: A-E-G / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Use supply and demand curves to explain price and output changes in product and labor markets.
  2. Understand and use the concept of elasticity.
  3. Understand the difference between economic costs and accounting costs.
  4. Know the difference between economic profit, loss minimization, shut down point and break even point.
  5. Explain the difference between the four market structures.
    6. (Perfect Competition, Monopoly, Monopolistic Competition, Oligopoly)
  6. Understand pricing in resource markets.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Special and current topics in Economics may be available. See "Class Schedule Search" for a complete listing each term. Offered on: A-E-G / 3-4 cr. hrs.

Honors special topics in Economics may be available for Honors students as well as those who have received permission from campus Honors Program Coordinator. See "Class Schedule Search" for a complete listing each term. Offered on: A-E-G / 3-4 cr. hrs.

Overview of early childhood education theory, history, philosophy and psychology. Current issues also examined and critiqued. Includes 10 hours of field visits to various early childhood programs. Note: This course is open to all students and can be used as an unrestricted elective in the Liberal Arts and Sciences: General Studies Program. No prerequisite. Offered on: A-E-G / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Compare and analyze the types, elements and philosophies of early childhood programs.
  2. Demonstrate knowledge of and analyze the historical development of early childhood education and attitudes toward children and childhood.
  3. Discuss, analyze and compare the educator/theorists who have influenced early childhood education and their theories.
  4. Identify and explain relevant aspects and theories of child development.
  5. Identify, examine and evaluate personal values, basic principles and appropriate practices as applied to early childhood education.
  6. Observe, analyze discuss and evaluate early childhood education.
  7. Discuss, analyze and evaluate current issues in early childhood education.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: This course covers curriculum development, including activity plans, with an emphasis on the curriculum areas of math, science, and social studies. Principles of developmentally appropriate practice will be presented and applied to building a curriculum which is integrated, child centered and process oriented. Includes 7 hours of field visits to various early childhood programs. Note: This course is open to all students and can be used as an unrestricted elective in the Liberal Arts and Sciences: General Studies Program. Prerequisite or corequisite: EDU101 or permission of Chair/Academic Dean. Offered on: A-E-G/ 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Demonstrate understandings of how young children learn and best practices to allow for and facilitate appropriate and effective learning.
  2. Discuss the ways to develop an appropriate programmatic environment and framework to enhance the learning and development of young children, including practical approaches to room arrangement, scheduling and curriculum development.
  3. Effectively use various recommended planning formats to construct curriculum themes and projects which are developmentally appropriate, child centered and process oriented.
  4. Participate in and effectively plan activities which meet the same criteria as the above.
  5. Use and demonstrate an understanding of the use of various materials appropriate for an early childhood classroom.
  6. Demonstrate an understanding of the ways math, science and social studies are appropriately integrated and constructively developed in an early childhood program.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: This course covers the practice of curriculum development, including activity plans, with a particular emphasis on the curriculum areas of visual arts, music, movement, and language arts. Principles of creativity and developmentally appropriate practice will be presented and applied to the question of how to build a curriculum which is integrated, child centered and process-oriented. Includes 3 hours of field visits to an early childhood program. Note: This course is open to all students and can be used as an unrestricted elective in the Liberal Arts and Sciences: General Studies Program. Prerequisites or corequisite: EDU 101 or permission of Chair/Academic Dean. Offered on: A-E-G/ 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Develop and demonstrate an understanding of the creative process by engaging in activities and using a variety of creative art materials and art forms.
  2. Describe and explain children’s stages of musical development and be able to implement appropriate activities.
  3. Participate in all appropriate singing, instrumental, movement, rhythm & dramatic activities.
  4. Identify and evaluate components of developmentally appropriate child centered experiences, including concepts, behavioral objectives/experiential goals, open-ended questions and evaluation.
  5. Define creativity and select methods of teaching which will encourage and support creative expression in children.
  6. Select and discuss appropriate creative media and materials for all curriculum areas in early childhood.
  7. Identify creative activities which may be used to introduce and reinforce concepts in other curriculum areas.
  8. Read, evaluate, and develop an appreciation for literature written for the young child.
  9. Discuss, analyze, and formulate criteria for language arts experiences and selecting literature appropriate for young children.
  10. Integrate children’s literature into all aspects of the early childhood curriculum.
  11. Observe, analyze, discuss, & evaluate early childhood programs.

CourseInventory.CourseLongTitle: Infants and Toddlers: Programs and Care
CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Study of programs, curriculum and care of children ages 6 weeks through the second year who are in group care settings. Appropriate techniques for fostering emotional, physical, social and cognitive development of the very young are examined. Field visits to infant and toddler programs required as in EDU101. Note: This course is open to all students and can be used as an unrestricted elective in the Liberal Arts and Sciences: General Studies Program. No prerequisite. Offered on: A-E-G / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Identify and compare the various types of Infant and Toddler Programs such as day care and family care in a variety of settings.
  2. Examine and evaluate the goals and philosophy of Infant and Toddler Programs and identify the characteristics of well-planned programs.
  3. Determine and evaluate infant and toddler readiness by defining and discussing the stages of development from birth to age three.
  4. Plan and create developmentally appropriate infant and toddler experiences.
  5. Examine and select appropriate equipment and materials for infants and toddlers and create “teacher-made” material.
  6. Discuss and design appropriate infant and toddler settings.
  7. Define and discuss appropriate planning and teaching strategies for infants and toddlers and examine ways to share these with parents.
  8. Observe, evaluate and discuss three local Infant and Toddler Programs.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Focuses on foundations of educational system in U.S. Students study the school in relation to historical and philosophical premises of education; analyze relationship among social and cultural influences on school and curriculum; examine role of teacher within cultural context; and study physical organization of schools and classrooms in relation to educational goals and curriculum. Prerequisite: Matriculation in the Education (Child Study) curriculum (EDCS-AA) or any Adolescence Education curriculum with successful completion of 30 or more credits or permission of appropriate administrator. Non-majors with 30 credits may enroll with permission of Chair/Academic Dean. Offered on: A-E-G / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Identify and trace the political and historical factors impacting education programs.
  2. Identify and analyze education law, legal issues and the organization of schools.
  3. Examine and discuss curriculum goals and development at the different levels of education.
  4. Identify and examine personal values, goals and professional organizations related to the teaching profession.
  5. Identify and analyze current issues, trends and concerns in education.
  6. Identify and examine the roles and behaviors of effective teachers.
  7. Identify and clarify requirements for New York State teaching certification at the elementary and secondary levels.
  8. Identify developmental stages at the elementary, middle and secondary levels and their impact on the educational process at each level.

CourseInventory.CourseLongTitle: Early Childhood Seminar and Practicum I
CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Examination of the role of the early childhood professional in an educational setting and in relationships with children, parents, staff and teachers. Fosters development of observational skills and instructional techniques. Registration in course requires students to purchase liability insurance through the college. Fingerprint, health and background checks may be required at the student's expense. (Offered fall semester only.) (2 hrs. lecture, 3 hrs. practicum) Prerequisite: EDU102 or EDU103. Offered on: A-E-G / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Participate as an effective assistant in all activities at the early childhood program to which he/she is assigned.
  2. Observe and discuss in seminars his/her observation and actions in the classroom. The physical, social, cognitive and emotional development of the preschool child will be part of these observations.
  3. Plan appropriate curriculum experiences and demonstrate knowledge of subject matter by coordinating activities and materials with developmentally (physical, emotional, cognitive, social) appropriate behavioral objectives.
  4. Demonstrate professional attitudes toward teaching by achieving rapport with all colleagues and staff which will aid in the development of his/her own teaching skills; i.e., seeking resource persons, accepting new assignments, attending program meetings.
  5. Identify his/her own strengths and weaknesses in preparation and teaching techniques through written assignments, child studies, exams, class seminars and individual conferences.

CourseInventory.CourseLongTitle: Early Childhood Seminar and Practicum II
CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Study of the young child's development of self-image and his/her perception of life, death and family roles. Registration in this course requires students to purchase liability insurance through the college. Fingerprint, health and background checks may be required at the student's expense. (Offered spring semester only.) (2 hrs. lecture, 6 hrs. practicum) Prerequisite: EDU211. A-E-G / 4 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Identify and describe patterns of physical, social, emotional and cognitive development in children.
  2. Describe the effect of teacher attitudes and expectations on children’s self-esteem, behavior and room atmosphere.
  3. Demonstrate the ability to work with the cooperating teacher in a professional capacity, sharing and performing those classroom responsibilities assigned.
  4. Demonstrate skill in planning and facilitating developmentally appropriate experiences for individual and groups of children. Experiences are to be designed to enhance and support intellectual, social, emotional and physical development.
  5. Identify and discuss appropriate methods of encouraging self-discipline.
  6. Discuss attitude changes and personal growth and development.
  7. Demonstrate in all plans and interactions the need to respect and support the child, recognizing and accepting the influence of family, community and culture.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: This is a preparatory ESL module. Students will learn an elementary functional vocabulary which they can use in their academic environment. Material is initially presented through listening and speaking activities and continues with reading and writing. Both reading and writing begin with controlled passages. This course lasts for a total of 72 hours (6 hours/week for 12 weeks). There is also a 12 hour lab requirement. Offered on: A-E-W

This is a beginning listening, speakin and reading course whose native language is not English. Listening and speaking skills are developed to provide students with coping skills and cultural information which will help them understand the use of the English language in various situations. Students are taught to read in English with comprehension. This course lasts a total of 36 hours (3 hours/week for 12 weeks). There is also a 6 hour lab requirement. Offered on A-E-W

This is a beginning reading and writing course for students whose native language is not English. Basic structures of written English are introduced. Students are taught to write using appropriate grammatical constructions and incorporate new vocabulary into short paragraphs. This course lasts a total of 36 hours (3 hours/week for 12 weeks). There is also a 6 hour lab requirement. Offered on A-E-W

This is a high beginning grammar course for students whose native language is not English. Simple tenses and grammatical structures taught in Level 1 are reinforced after which additional concepts are introduced. Students are taught to use them with accuracy in order to progress to the next level of study. This course lasts a total of 36 hours (3 hours/week for 12 weeks). There is also a 6 hour lab requirement. Offered on A-E-W

This is a high beginning reading, writing and conversation course for students whose native language is not English. Basic structures of written English are reviewed and examined in context. Students are also taught new vocabulary in context and to read with comprehension. This course lasts a total of 36 hours (3 hours/week for 12 weeks). There is also a 6 hour lab requirement. Offered on A-E-W

This is a low intermediate grammar course for students whose native language is not English. Its purpose is to give the student a strong grammar foundation. This course lasts a total of 36 hours (3 hours/week for 12 weeks). There is a 6 hour lab requirement. Offered on A-E-W

This is a low intermediate reading, writing and conversation course for students whose native language is not English. Furthering the development of reading, writing, and conversation skills in English will be the focus of this course. Students will read controlled short stories to improve reading comprehension skills. They will write short controlled passages as well as experience free writing activities. In addition, students will have the opportunity to practice conversational English through discussion and dialogues. This course lasts a total of 36 hours (3 hours/week for 12 weeks). There is also a 6 hour lab requirement. Offered on A-E-W

This is a high intermediate writing/grammar course for students whose native language is not English. The course focuses on developing ideas and organizing paragraphs and short essays. English grammatical structures are examined within the framework of student generated writing and supplementary exercises. This course lasts a total of 36 hours (3 hours/week for 12 weeks). There is also a 6 hour lab requirement. Offered on A-E-W

This is a high intermediate reading and listening and speaking course for students whose native language is not English. Students will continue to refine language skills acquired at earlier levels. Through examination of authentic literature from well- known writers, students are taught to read with comprehension with active/receptive vocabulary encountered at this level being further developed and reinforced. Readings and conversations regarding current issues and topics of interest to students serve as the stimulus for generating language. This course last a total of 36 hours (3 hour/week for 12 weeks). There is also a 6 hour lab requirement. Offered on A-E-W

This is an advanced ESL integrated skills course for students whose native language is not English. This course focuses on the writing process, and enhancement of reading, listening and speaking skills in the English language. The skills addressed in this level will provide the necessary foundation needed for college-level courses. Successful completion of the level will require students to produce written work and to exhibit skills in conversation, oral presentation and lecture situations. This course lasts a total of 72 hours (6 hours/week for 12 weeks). There is also a 12 hour lab requirement. Offered on A-E-W

Fundamental laws of electricity as applied to solution of resistive circuits with any excitation. Laboratory portion enables students to gain practical experience in use of test equipment and procedures while verifying principles learned in the lecture. (3 hrs. lecture, 2 hrs. laboratory) Corequisite: MAT111. Offered on: A / 4 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Describe and define voltage, current, resistance and power pertaining to DC circuits.
  2. Both mathematically and physically determine voltages, currents resistances and power in various forms of resistive circuits.
  3. Schematically draw series, parallel and combination circuits.
  4. Distinguish between ideal and non-ideal sources and their effects upon circuits.
  5. Solve for and recognize the advantages of using various network theorems such as Thevenin's, Norton's and Superposition.
  6. Solve for current and voltage values, with respect to time, in simple resistor-Capacitor and resistor-Inductor circuits.
  7. Follow prescribed lab test procedures, set up equipment, take measurements, and interpret results.
  8. Utilize LabView, Multisim lab simulation and Elvis lab equipment to verify calculated values of resistance, voltage, current and power.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Introduction to digital electronics. Topics include number systems and codes, Boolean algebra, and combinatorial and synchronous circuits. Laboratory portion of course emphasizes implementation of concepts developed in the lecture and trouble-shooting techniques. (Offered fall semester only.) (3 hrs. lecture, 2 hrs. laboratory) Prerequisite: Admission to Electrical Technology program. Corequisites: MAT111, ELT112, and ELT115. Offered on: A / 4 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Describe and implement the basic terminology and hardware of digital circuits.
  2. Describe / implement the various gates/chips and how to research each IC.
  3. Design, construct and troubleshoot various digital circuits.
  4. Utilize the various test equipment associated with analyzing digital circuits. This includes bench equipment and simulated test equipment.
  5. Utilize the LabView, Multisim simulation and Elvis lab station.
  6. Design, construct and evaluate various timing circuits, memory chips and registers.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Practical methods of solving technical problems are explored. Flowcharting and computer programming skills are developed as tools in the problem solving process. (Offered fall semester only.) (2 hrs. laboratory) Prerequisite: Admission to Electrical Technology program. Corequisites: MAT111, ELT112, and ELT113. Offered on: A / 1 cr. hr.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Outline the basic architecture and components of a personal computer and utilize Word, Excel for documenting lab reports and analysis.
  2. Design programs to solve various technical problems dealing with electricity / electronics.
  3. Design programs to import information, manipulate data and produce a defined output.
  4. Design and implement flow charts for solving technical problems such as D.C. circuit analysis, Inductor / Capacitor design, and various electrical applications.
  5. Write and execute programs using a programming language. Also debug / troubleshoot these programs.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Teaches basics of personal computers, both software and hardware orientation. Hardware orientation taught through disassembly and assembly of personal computers in hands-on lab experience. Software taught in lecture format with some in-class computer work. Students also learn how to deal with upgrades in both hardware and software and problems encountered with them. (2 hrs. lecture, 2 hrs. laboratory) No prerequisite. Offered on: A / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Assemble and disassemble a working PC and/or laptop.
  2. Evaluate current software on a computer and load updates/ patches.
  3. Install / uninstall operating systems.
  4. Research and evaluate a current computer system and upgrade that computer.
  5. Demonstrate understanding of computer components and evaluate/ replace those components.
  6. Apply the techniques and information learned towards the A+ certification.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Covers CISCO Program I and II in one semester. Introduces OSI layers and LAN implementation. First half of semester covers OSI seven-layer model. Second half of semester dedicated to router configuration and five router LAN implementation. Students acquire knowledge to set up and maintain a local network. (3 hrs. lecture, 3 hrs. laboratory) No prerequisite. Offered on: A / 4 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Recognize and explain how the devices and services that are used to support communications across an Internetwork operate.
  2. Use network protocol models to explain the layers of communications in data networks.
  3. Describe the protocols and services provided by the application layer in the OSI and TCP/IP models and describe how these layers operates in various networks.
  4. Analyze the operations and features of the various layer protocols and services and explain the fundamental concepts of routing.
  5. Design, calculate, and apply IP addressing schemes to fulfill given requirements.
  6. Build an Ethernet network using routers and switches.
  7. Use Cisco command-line interface (CLI) commands to perform basic router and switch configuration and verification.
  8. Analyze the operations and features of common application layer protocols such as HTTP, Domain Name System (DNS), Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol (DHCP), Simple Mail Transfer Protocol (SMTP),Telnet, and FTP.
  9. Utilize common network utilities to verify small network operations and analyze data traffic.
  10. Explain the critical role routers play in enabling communications across multiple networks.
  11. Describe and implement the various routing protocols.
  12. Compare, contrast, and implement the various IP addressing configurations.
  13. Use advanced configuration commands with routers.
  14. Design, configure and implement a network containing several routers, switches, servers and other networking devices.
  15. Design, implement and evaluate various networking configurations using simulators such as Packet Tracer and utilizing actual hardware in the networking lab.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Second of two-semester sequence in Local and Wide area networking. Building on knowledge gained from ELT151, course uses hands-on laboratory exercises and threaded case studies to train students in skills needed to design, build and maintain small to medium-size computer networks, enabling students to enter workforce and/or further their education and training in computer networking field. (3 hrs. lecture, 3 hrs. laboratory) Prerequisite: ELT151. Offered on: A / 4 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Identify and correct common network problems at layers 1, 2, 3, and 7 using a layered model approach.
  2. Select the appropriate media, cables, ports, connectors to connect switches to other network devices and hosts and interpret network diagrams.
  3. Explain basic switching concepts and the operation of switches.
  4. Describe enhanced switching technologies such as VLANs, VLAN Trunking Protocol (VTP), Rapid Spanning Tree Protocol (RSTP), Per VLAN Spanning Tree Protocol (PVSTP), and 802.1q.
  5. Describe implement VLANs, create logically separate networks and explain routing occurs between them.
  6. Configure, verify, and troubleshoot VLANs, trunking on Cisco switches, interVLAN routing, VTP, and RSTP.
  7. Verify network status and switch operation using basic utilities such as ping, traceroute, Telnet, Secure Shell (SSH), Address Resolution Protocol (ARP), and ipconfig, as well as the show and debug commands.
  8. Identify, prescribe, and resolve common switched network media issues, configuration issues, auto negotiation, and switch hardware failures.
  9. Manage Cisco IOS® Software, Cisco IOS configuration files (save, edit, upgrade, and restore).
  10. Identify and describe the purpose of the components in a small wireless network, such as Service SetIdentification (SSID), Basic Service Set (BSS), and Extended Service Set (ESS).
  11. Identify basic configuration parameters on a wireless network to ensure that devices connect to the correct access points.
  12. Compare and contrast Wi-Fi Protected Access (WPA) security features and capabilities of open, Wired Equivalent Privacy (WEP), and WPA-1/2 networks.
  13. Describe the impact of Voice Over IP and Video Over IP applications on a network.
  14. Identify and correct common network problems at layers 1, 2, 3, and 7 using a layered model approach.
  15. Implement basic switch security measures such as port security, trunk access, and management VLANs.
  16. Configure/ explain, verify, and troubleshoot DHCP and DNS operations on a router.
  17. Describe current network security threats and explain how to implement a comprehensive security policy to mitigate common threats to network devices, hosts, and applications.
  18. Configure and apply security and filtering using implementations such as ACLs to limit Telnet and SSH access to the router using the Security Device.
  19. Manager command-line interface (SDM/CLI).
  20. Configure/ Explain NAT for given network requirements using SDM/CLI and troubleshoot NAT issues.
  21. Configure and verify a basic WAN serial connection.
  22. Configure and verify a Point-to-Point Protocol (PPP), Configure and verify Frame Relay on Cisco routers.
  23. Troubleshoot WAN implementation issues.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Explores mathematical theory applied to electronic circuits. Creation of sinusoidal functions through filtering, exponential waveforms in R-C and R-L circuits, phase shifting, wave-shaping and function analysis via diode and transistor circuits. Application of complex numbers in R-L-C circuits. (Offered spring semester only.) (2 hrs. lecture) No prerequisite. Offered on: A / 1 cr. hr.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Apply complex number theory to evaluation of DC excited R-C, R-L and R-L-C circuits.
  2. Apply trigonometric rules to the evaluation of AC circuitry.
  3. Utilizing mathematical skills to predict the outputs of wave shaping circuitry.
  4. Calculate gains and losses of electrical systems using logarithm techniques and express those in dB and dBm.
  5. Evaluate and prove the RMS values.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Operation and application of diodes, bipolar and field effect transistors and thryistors. Laboratory portion illustrates use of electronic equipment to test ideas presented in the lecture. (Offered spring semester only.) (3 hrs. lecture, 2 hrs. laboratory) Prerequisite: MAT111, ELT112, and ELT115. Corequisites: MAT124 and ELT224. Offered on: A / 4 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Describe the practical use of pn junctions in electronic devices, define what a diode is, how the reverse and forward bias junction in a diode operates and how diodes are used in various system applications.
  2. Describe the differences between npn and pnp bipolar transistors, determine transistor currents and voltages, understand and use characteristic curves, calculate BJT current and voltage gains.
  3. Describe and calculate for proper BJT transistor dc biasing, stability and linear operation.
  4. Describe basic JFET vs. BJT model construction and operation.
  5. Describe and calculate for proper JFET transistor dc biasing.
  6. Describe basic MOSFET model construction and operation.
  7. Analyze amplifier circuits by reducing them to equivalent small-signal models.
  8. Describe the operations and uses of SCRs, TRIACs, DIACs and other various Thyristor devices.
  9. Follow prescribed lab test procedures, set up equipment, take measurements, and interpret results.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: The understanding of network analysis techniques learned in Electricity I is reinforced and extended to solution of networks with AC excitations. Topics emphasized include impedance, admittance, resonance and frequency response, transformers, power relations and 3-phase systems. Computers used as a problem-solving tool. Objective of the laboratory is to illustrate use of appropriate electronic equipment for testing of principles presented in the lecture. (Offered spring semester only.) (3 hrs. lecture, 2 hrs. laboratory) Prerequisite: ELT112, ELT115, and MAT111. Corequisite: MAT124. Offered on: A / 4 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Explain the differences between AC and DC currents/voltages.
  2. Calculate/measure for voltages, currents, and phase relationships within RC, RL and RLC series, parallel and combination circuits.
  3. Apply Ohm's Law and Kirchoff's Current and Voltage Laws to various reactive circuit configurations under ac excitation.
  4. Calculate ac circuit parameters using various analysis and network theorems, i.e. Thevenin's, Norton's, Superposition, etc.
  5. Calculate circuit resonant frequency and interpret frequency-response curves.
  6. Solve for resonant frequencies, bandwidths and upper/lower cut-off frequencies.
  7. Describe transformer mutual inductance, turns ratio, input/output phase relation, power efficiency and transformer types/uses.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Introduction to general principles and practices of troubleshooting. Topics include design and construction of printed circuit boards. Construction of electronic circuits and systems. (Offered spring semester only.) (2 hrs. laboratory) Prerequisite: ELT112, ELT113, and ELT115. Corequisite: ELT222, and ELT224. Offered on: A / 1 cr. hr.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Take circuit prints and construct a circuit, system or electronic equipment from those prints.
  2. Demonstrate choosing /implement utilizing the correct soldering techniques/ apparatus for the required implementation.
  3. Utilize various soldering apparatus, techniques to solder and assemble circuit boards.
  4. Construct electronic equipment such as handheld multimeter from individual components and circuit boards.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Microprocessors and associated circuitry are examined. Topics include architecture, peripheral devices and software. Laboratory portion deals with application of concepts learned in the lecture to practical working systems. (Offered spring semester only.) (2 hrs. lecture, 2 hrs. laboratory) Prerequisite: ELT112, ELT113, ELT115, and MAT111. Corequisite: ELT222. Offered on: A / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Describe the components of a microcontroller system. Describe the architecture of an 8/16 bit microcontroller including registers, instruction execution, and timing.
  2. Describe / implement how to use the microcontroller instruction set with respect to data transfers, arithmetic and logical functions, stack, I/O, and control functions. Create flow charts and write simple machine language programs. Demonstrate how to assemble programs.
  3. Describe RAM, ROM, EPROM and know how to interconnect these to form larger memory systems.
  4. Connect switches and LEDs to an input-output port to construct a software controlled switch.
  5. Be able to computer assemble programs to take in specific data and make a decision based upon that data to generate a specific output.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Methods of applying mathematical techniques to electrical and electronic circuits. Topics include voltage and current in RLC circuits with various excitations, energy in electrical circuits, instantaneous and average power, etc. (Offered fall semester only.) Prerequisite: MAT124, ELT222, and ELT224. Offered on: A / 4 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Determine the mathematical limits of simple functions.
  2. Determine the instantaneous rate of change and average value of voltages, currents, resistances, temperatures, transconductances, etc. in electrical and electronic circuits and components by use of derivative formulae.
  3. Show by calculation, the output of an RC, RL differentiator and integrator.
  4. Determine, by use of integration formulae, circuit charge from current, energy from power, induced voltages from varying currents, etc.
  5. Calculate, by use of integration formulae, the average and effective values of voltages and currents in electric circuits.
  6. Determine Laplace transforms of functions of time by converting them into functions of the complex frequency domain.
  7. Determine the strengths and phase relationships of various dc, fundamental and harmonic components of waveforms by use of Fourier Series Analysis.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Develops a thorough understanding of electronic circuit analysis techniques. Topics include study of circuits with the following emphases: multi-stage cascaded systems, frequency response, voltage comparators, Schmitt Trigger circuits and saturated and cutoff transistors. Integrated circuits are analyzed. Laboratory portion investigates practical aspects of topics covered in the lecture. (Offered fall semester only.) (2 hrs. lecture, 2 hrs. laboratory) Prerequisite: ELT222 and ELT224. Corequisite: ELT231. Offered on: A / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Solve for currents, voltages, gain, and impedances in a dual supply discrete BJT circuit. Describe the dynamic range of this amplifier. Solve for currents, voltages, and gain in a discrete BJT differential amplifier.
  2. Interpret the specification sheet for an IC operational amplifier. Describe offsets, CMRR, supply rejection, dynamic range, open-loop resistances, slew rate, and gain-bandwidth product.
  3. For both inverting and non-inverting Op Amp configurations, solve, describe and solve for the following terms: Loop gain and closed loop gain, closed loop input and output impedance, frequency response, and CMRR.
  4. Construct Bode plots (gain and phase) for passive and active networks.
  5. Analyze and describe summing amplifiers, instrumentation voltage-current converters, D/A and A/D applications, integrators and differentiators.
  6. Analyze and describe active filters and oscillators using Op amps.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Microprocessor and computer interfacing and introduction to 16 bit microcomputers. Included are computer-controlled test equipment techniques. (Offered fall semester only.) (2 hrs. lecture, 2 hrs. laboratory) Prerequisite: ELT222 and ELT228. Corequisite: ELT236. Offered on: A / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Write flow-chart and microcontroller programs for assembly. Write programs to initialize input/output ports, sense switch closures, drive LED's, DAC's and stepper motors, and sense A/D converters.
  2. Implement and demonstrate the difference between peripheral devices such as programmable input/output chips, and memory devices.
  3. Know the characteristics of the buses to be able to program a device using either system for a specific task.
  4. Implement various circuit interfaces using the specifications of A/D and D/A converters. Interpret resolution, linearity and offset expressed in bits. Example of circuit implementation will be to use a DAC to build a digital voltmeter.
  5. Follow prescribed lab test procedures, set up equipment, take measurements, and interpret results dealing with the microcontrollers and microcontroller interfaces.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Introduction to analogue communication techniques such as AM, FM and pulse code modulation. Public and private communication techniques examined in reference to ISDN, video, cellular, ATM and wireless techniques. Transmission mediums and techniques utilizing fiber, cable, RF, microwave and satellite studied in depth. (2 hrs. lecture, 2 hrs. laboratory) Prerequisite: ELT231 and ELT236. Offered on: A / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Define the various analog systems for communicating electronic information.
  2. Build and troubleshoot circuits used in analog communications.
  3. Transfer between time and frequency domains.
  4. Design, build and troubleshoot RF circuits, transmitters and receivers.
  5. Describe various modulation techniques and where they are used.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Examines data communication systems and techniques such as multiplexing, coding, PSK and others. Explores current technology as well as proposed technology in data communications. Covers how information is transmitted utilizing current digital techniques. (2 hrs. lecture, 2 hrs. laboratory) Prerequisite: ELT231 and ELT236. Offered on: A / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Describe various digital modulation techniques.
  2. Describe synchronous and asynchronous transmission techniques.
  3. Understand basic data communication techniques and principles.
  4. Explain the use and application of various transmission media.
  5. Describe the current data communication services and their application.
  6. Define coding, error correction and advanced modulation techniques.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Capstone course where students are evaluated in equipment setup and usage, trouble-shooting skills, team building and communication skills. Students given projects to design, build and demonstrate, including amplifiers, wireless communication circuits/systems, and signal generation circuits. (2 hrs. lecture, 2 hrs. laboratory) Prerequisite: ELT231, ELT236, and ELT238. Offered on: A / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Design/implement complex circuits involving amplifiers, digital/analog interface and control circuits, wireless communication circuits.
  2. Demonstrate working in groups as team leaders and individual team members.
  3. Demonstrate research and presentation skills.
  4. Implement and utilize circuit analysis skills, appropriate test and measurement equipment, appropriate utilization and implementation of LabView, Multisim and Elvis systems.
  5. Take an electronic system design from concept to completion and present that design in an open forum.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Introduction to analogue and digital data communications techniques a systems design approach. Includes analogue/digital modulation techniques, ISDN, video, cellular ATM, synchronous/asynchronous and wireless techniques. Digital/data communication systems techniques such as multiplexing, coding, PSK and others. Covers systems, transmission media and techniques in the analogue/digital/data transmission. (Offered spring semester only.) (2 hrs. lecture, 2 hrs. laboratory) Prerequisite: ELT231 and ELT236. Corequisite: ELT 243. Offered on: A / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Explain in detail the various modulation/demodulation techniques for electronic communications.
  2. Demonstrate the proper use of electronic equipment to analyze telecommunications systems.
  3. Explain the primary system components for receivers and transmitters.
  4. Identify and explain how the various electronic transmission mediums operate.
  5. Define the analogue and digital systems used for communicating electronic information.
  6. Describe synchronous and asynchronous transmission techniques.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Special and current topics in electrical engineering technology may be available. See online catalog for a complete listing. Offered on: A / 3-4 cr. hrs.

This course will concentrate on listening and speaking skill for non-native speakers of English at the beginning level. It focuses on elementary functional vocabulary which can be used in activities of daily living. Offered on A-E-W

This course will concentrate on listening and speaking skills for non-native speakers of English at the beginning level. It focuses on narrating events, describing people and places, and utilization of verb tenses in the present, past and future. Offered on A-E-W

This course will concentrate on listening and speaking skills for non-native speakers of English at the low intermediate level. Students will have the opportunity to practice converstional English through discussion and dialogues. Offered on A-E-W

This course will concentrate on listening and speaking skills for non-native speakers of English at the high intermediate level. Students will have the opportunity to practice converstional English through discussion of current events and issues as a stimulus for generating language. Students will have the opportunity to present a short prepared oral presentation to the class. Offered on A-E-W

This course will concentrate on listening and speaking skills for non-native speakers of English at the low advanced level. Students will have the opportunity to practice converstional English through discussion and debate. Students will present a short speech describing a process and be able to explain and defend a position. Offered on A-E-W

This workshop is to help students of English as a Second Language improve their pronunciation through listening, speaking, imitating and discussing the basic sound system of the English language. the class will be analyzing and correcting specific individual pronunciation problems, with the focus on individual sounds, although students will also gain an understanding of syllable stress in American English words. Through consistent attendance, class participation and homework, students will show improvement in word/sentence stress, intonation and rhythm as well as awareness of reductions and sound contrasts. Offered on: A-E-W.

ESL students will participate in a highly structured writing class where assignments are meant to familiarize them with academic English and writing style requirements will be examined. Writing preliminaries will involve oral brainstorming, reading assignments, vocabulary development, and applicable grammar instruction. To improve their skills, students will then apply these concepts and structure to their own written work. Offered on: A-E-W

This is a comprehensive language course for students preparing to take the TOEFL test. The focus is on skill-building strategies for more advanced students. It offers instruction and practice in skill areas including reading, listening, speaking, integrated tasks and writing. Practice tests will be included with the actual format for the IBT test. Offered on: A-E-W

This course is designed to expand the ESL student's functional vocabulary in communication, including listening, speaking, reading and writing. Emphasis will be placed on vocabulary in context. A frequent topic of study and discussion will be the news media. Students will have the opportunity to listen to and analyze news reports, as well as read and react to news articles from a variety of periodicals. This course is recommended for students who have completed beginning ESL classes. Offered on: A-E-W

This is a photography based class in which ESL (non-credit) students will acquire not only the skills to produce photographs humanizing conditions by tying particular faces, places and lives to what are often presented as social issues and generalizations but will also express their photographs in written and spoken English.

This workshop is to help students of English as a Second Language improve their pronunciation through listening, speaking, imitating and discussing the basic sound system of the English language. The focus of the class will be to learn to implement American English word stress, rhythm and intonation patterns. Through consistent attendance, class participation and homework, students will show improvement in word/sentence stress, intonation and rhythm as well as awareness of reductions and sound contrasts. Offered on: A-E-W.

Basic writing course for students who have difficulty organizing and expressing their thoughts clearly, who have problems with usage, or who simply lack much practice in writing. All students receive instruction in both developing and expressing ideas. Work on specific problems of spelling, punctuation and grammatical usage is drawn primarily from students¿ own writings. Additional work on related exercises may be required. By placement. To be taken in the first semester. Graded on an S-W-U-R basis. Not applicable toward any degree or certificate. No prerequisite. Offered on: A-E-G / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Develop prewriting, drafting, revising, and proofreading skills.
  2. Plan, write, and revise a series of short essays (1-2 pages, both in-class and out-of-class) developed via prewriting and drafting.
  3. Proofread and edit later drafts by addressing their own individual errors in grammar, mechanics, and usage.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Emphasizes basic writing skills, outlining, development of ideas and reading comprehension. Specific topics in grammar, punctuation, spelling, vocabulary and rhetoric are assigned according to needs of the students. To complete the course, students are expected to write short expository papers which show an understanding of fundamentals of organization and effective sentence structure and which avoid gross errors in grammar and mechanics. By placement. To be taken in the first semester unless placed in ENG009. Graded on an S-W-U-R basis. Not applicable toward any degree or certificate. Prerequisite: ENG009 or placement. Offered on: A-E-G / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Apply strategies for prewriting, drafting, revising, and proofreading (both in-class and out-of-class papers).
  2. Write a series of essays that focus on a main idea and support that main idea via clear, well-ordered paragraphs developed by specific details, examples, or reasons.
  3. Revise and rewrite for some of the following (depending on document):
    1. Central purpose and/or argument
    2. Coherent organization, integration, and structure
    3. Support from relevant examples and evidence
    4. Connections between ideas and examples/evidence
    5. Specific details and facts pertaining to audience and genre
    6. Citations and documentation (where applicable)
    7. Effective word choice, style, and tone
    8. Smooth flow of ideas through use of transitional words, phrases, or paragraphs where necessary
    9. Correction of grammatical and mechanical errors
    10. Appropriate format, document design, and preparation in accord with manuscript requirements and genre convention.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Explores principles of rhetoric and stresses effective expository writing. Primarily a course in organization of ideas and development of these ideas through use of specific information. Also deals with matters of style, sentence structure, paragraph development, punctuation and vocabulary. Also introduces students to close reading of appropriate materials. By placement. To be taken prior to higher-numbered courses. Note: Fulfills SUNY General Education Requirement for Basic Communication. ESL018, ENG010, or placement. Offered on: A-E-G / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Explore ways to organize and develop expository writing, and demonstrate an awareness of form and audience.
  2. Revise and rewrite for some of the following (depending on document):
    1. Central purpose and/or argument
    2. Coherent organization, integration, and structure
    3. Support from relevant examples and evidence
    4. Connections between ideas and examples/evidence
    5. Connections between ideas and thesis
    6. Interpretation and explanation of ideas, connections, and examples/evidence
    7. Specific details and facts pertaining to audience and genre
    8. Citations and documentation (where applicable)
    9. Effective word choice, style, and tone
    10. Smooth flow of ideas through use of transitional words, phrases, or paragraphs where necessary
    11. Correction of grammatical and mechanical errors
    12. Appropriate format, document design, and preparation in accord with manuscript requirements
  3. Develop critical arguments and identify, analyze, and evaluate those arguments.
  4. Access, evaluate and utilize different types of research, information, and resources to support and strengthen writing.
  5. Use MLA in-text citations and compose a list of Works Cited.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Introduction to imaginative works of literature: the short story, novel, poem and drama. Close and analytical study of this literature introduces students to major literary themes and forms. Continues training in effective prose writing and requires students to demonstrate maturity in thought and style. Recommended for those who plan to continue their studies at a four-year institution. Note: Fulfills SUNY General Education Requirement for Humanities. Prerequisite: ENG101. Offered on: A-E-G / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Write about and respond to literature in order to effectively and intelligently communicate views, insights, and criticisms
  2. Revise and rewrite for some of the following (depending on document):
    1. Central purpose and/or argument
    2. Coherent organization, integration, and structure
    3. Support from relevant examples and evidence
    4. Connections between ideas and examples/evidence
    5. Connections between ideas and thesis
    6. Interpretation, analysis, and explanation of texts, ideas, connections, and examples/evidence
    7. Specific details and facts pertaining to audience and genre
    8. Citations and documentation
    9. Effective word choice, style, and tone
    10. Smooth flow of ideas through use of transitional words, phrases, or paragraphs where necessary
    11. Correction of grammatical and mechanical errors
    12. Appropriate format, document design, and presentation in accord with manuscript requirements
  3. Develop the ability to read literature carefully and critically, actively engaging and analyzing the symbols, themes, and issues constructed through interpretive readings and discussions
  4. Engage in textual analysis and critical thinking
  5. Demonstrate correct MLA documentation (format, citations, Works Cited, etc.)

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Evolution of the English language and syntactical patterns from which English sentences are generated. Particular attention given to traditional, structuralist, and generative-transformational theories of grammar and to pedagogical and sociological assumptions underlying each. Prerequisite: ENG101. Offered on: A-E-G / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Demonstrate a familiarity with fundamental linguistic concepts such as phonology, morphology, syntax, sociolinguistics, and language acquisition, and apply these to language situations.
  2. Analyze various grammatical components and how they work together.
  3. Demonstrate an awareness of the historical development of the English language, including the major periods (Old English, Middle English, Modern English) and the social effects of language and culture.
  4. Create analytical responses which reflect an understanding of the structure and/or historical developments of English.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Orientation in field of technical writing and editing. Introduces various forms of technical writing: reports, manuals, publication specifications and standards, proposals, training materials, brochures and technical articles. Mechanics of manuscript preparation and preparation of reproduction-ready copy are discussed in detail, as are activities of various publications departments - editing, layout, printing, quality control, etc. Prerequisite or corequisite: ENG101. Offered on: A-E-G / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Understand the value and necessity of collaboration in producing technical documents.
  2. Understand the resources for locating secondary information and be able to incorporate those resources into their documents using proper attribution.
  3. Understand technical writing rhetorically, discussing such topics as organizational conventions, audience expectations, real-world applications, visual design, format, and style in the context of specific rhetorical and professional situations.
  4. Understand the ethical, international, social, and professional constraints of audience, style, and content for writing situations.
  5. Write a series of projects that will help them discover that there are different ways to organize and develop technical writing, and that their choice of form depends primarily on what they are trying to do in their writing and with whom they are communicating.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: For readers and writers of autobiography. Reading select memoir and autobiographical literature, students analyze composing techniques and write their own autobiographical pieces. Substantial writing practice includes approaches to memoir writing such as portraiture, landscape and memory, travel and history. Prerequisite: ENG101. Offered on: A-G / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Write a series of autobiographical essays through successive revision to effectively create significant scenes, dialogue, interior monologue, reflection, setting, and character.
  2. Understand such aspects of descriptive and analytic writing as point of view, sequencing and thematic organization, balanced argument (point and counterpoint; evidence and illustration), tone and diction, and historical and cultural context, through the use of some of the following: informal writing projects, formal essays, in class writing workshops, and writing conferences.
  3. Understand the following ideas:
    1. The relationship between facts and crafted writing
    2. The nature of memory as contingent—influenced by social interactions, situations, and purposes
    3. How imagination engenders critical thinking

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Develops control and style in creative writing, specifically of prose fiction, poetry and plays. Students pursue individual projects and assignments of established forms of creative writing. Discussions pay attention, as well, to development of stronger criteria for self-evaluation and particular needs of a creative writer to gauge his or her audience in order to market his or her work. Prerequisite: ENG101. Offered on: A-E-G / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Write original pieces of creative writing in at least three established genres of prose fiction, poetry, and plays.
  2. Understand how to present or market creative writing for an intended audience.
  3. Apply revision techniques to improve creative writing for control and style.
  4. Edit writing for clarity and correctness.
  5. Understand the role of contemporary creative writing through the study of classmates’ work and/or the work of published writers.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Through close reading of major works, students examine development of the novel from the 18th century to the present. Discussion covers techniques, themes and cultural-historical contexts of the works. Note: Fulfills SUNY General Education Requirement for Humanities. Prerequisite: ENG101. Offered on: A-E-G / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Understand each novel read as an aesthetic work and in relation to relevant historical, political, religious, cultural, and philosophical influences of the era.
  2. Understand the origin and development of the novel as a genre.
  3. Understand the conventions of the novel as a genre.
  4. Write essays of literary analysis which demonstrate the following qualities: controlling purpose, clear focus, adequate development, logical organization, and use of pertinent textual details to support purpose.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Study of theme, structure, characterization and imagery in representative drama from the Greeks to the present day. Note: Fulfills SUNY General Education Requirement for Humanities. Prerequisite: ENG101. Offered on: A-E-G / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Understand the development of dramatic literature and performance in representative texts from ancient Greece to the present.
  2. Understand the conventions of dramatic literature, such as: staging, the chorus, soliloquy, aside, dénouement, dramatic irony, pathos, and the fourth wall.
  3. Analyze the intersections between structure, characterization, performance, historical context and meaning in dramatic literature texts.
  4. Write literary analysis essays that demonstrate the following qualities: controlling purpose, clear focus, effective development, logical organization, and use of pertinent textual details to support a thesis.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Study of major works of world literature emphasizing mythological, social and philosophical backgrounds of Classical, Medieval and Renaissance periods. ENG143 deals with such authors as Homer, Sophocles, Dante and Cervantes. Note: Fulfills SUNY General Education Requirement for Humanities. Prerequisite: ENG101. Offered on: A-G / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Distinguish aesthetic qualities of the literature.
  2. Understand representative narrative, lyric and dramatic forms.
  3. Understand how various traditions, such as the Classical, Judeo-Christian-Islamic and Eastern traditions, have shaped the literature.
  4. Write analytical essays which reflect an understanding of the literature, are logically organized and are written in clear, concise prose.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Study of major works of world literature emphasizing mythological, social and philosophical backgrounds of Neo-classical, Romantic and Modern periods. ENG144 deals with such authors as Moliere, Voltaire, Goethe and Tolstoy. Note: Fulfills SUNY General Education Requirement for Humanities. Prerequisite: ENG101. Offered on: A-G / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Distinguish aesthetic qualities of the literature.
  2. Understand representative narrative, lyric and dramatic forms.
  3. Understand how various traditions, such as the Classical, Judeo-Christian-Islamic and Eastern traditions, have influenced the literature.
  4. Identify key literary movements (e.g. Romanticism, Literary Realism).
  5. Write analytical essays which reflect an understanding of the literature, are logically organized and are written in clear, concise prose.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Emphasis on various kinds of journalistic writing. Additional areas of concentration include graphics and design, photo journalism and broadcast journalism. Prerequisite or corequisite: ENG101. Offered on: A-E-G / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Demonstrate a basic knowledge of the history of the media, as well as understand its changing role in maintaining an informed democracy.
  2. Understand the principles relating to libel, invasion of privacy, and journalistic ethics.
  3. Identify, acquire, and verify information considered newsworthy in a professional and responsible manner, and present that information with clarity, objectivity, accuracy, thoroughness, and economy.
  4. Identify the differences between fact and opinion and be able to present opinions with clarity and substantiation.
  5. Write copy in accordance with the Associated Press style criteria, and other applicable and current style formats.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: In-depth study of reporting news and writing features, with emphasis on developing sources of news, such as governmental bodies, police stations, courts and boards of education. Emphasis on covering events in municipalities in and around Suffolk County. (Offered spring semester only.) Prerequisite: ENG170. Offered on: A-E-G / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Understand the role of reporting in society including coverage of governmental agencies, community power brokers, and community issues.
  2. Understand the journalist’s separate and individual role in alerting the public to issues in a way that encourages judgment.
  3. Understand the role of freedom of information in newsgathering and be able to access information through the use of freedom of information letters.
  4. Gather and present information as it relates to public affairs.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Prepares students for writing magazine articles and introduces study of public relations. Students learn to write query letters. Includes material on interviewing and developing sources to prepare longer stories for magazine market. Students learn how to prepare and market story for publication. Students write press releases and work on developing publicity campaigns. (Offered fall semester only.) Prerequisite: ENG170. Offered on: A / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Understand and utilize the tools of feature writing, such as voice, style, and characterization.
  2. Discriminate between different types of nonfiction.
  3. Write query letters and proposals and also demonstrate a basic knowledge of market evaluation.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Current books of non-fiction are read and discussed. Includes selections from books of "New Journalism" as well as non-fiction novels of a narrative and documentary type by such writers as Truman Capote, Joan Didion, Hunter Thompson, Betty Friedan, Jimmy Breslin, Tom Wolfe, Norman Mailer, Gay Talese and Theodore White. Prerequisite: ENG101. Offered on: A / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Demonstrate a knowledge of the history of literary journalism and an understanding of the role literary journalism plays in contemporary media.
  2. Understand qualitative research methods (interview, field work, immersion, etc.) Used in literary journalism.
  3. Identify the techniques of literary journalism that have come to be regarded as “literary” (description, narrative, dialogue, etc.) And consider the effects these techniques have on readers.
  4. Write pieces using some of these techniques to develop journalistic and literary voice.
  5. Identify the difference between the participatory nature of literary journalism and the objective nature of “straight news”.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: For students who work 30 contact hours per semester on the student newspaper. Includes working on all phases of newspaper: editing, reporting, feature writing, photography, layout, advertising, and editorial and sports writing. Students meet weekly with instructor for evaluation of their work. Registration priority given to students working on student newspaper. Registration in this course requires that students purchase liability insurance through the College. (offered spring semester only) Prerequisites: ENG101 and ENG170 or permission of Chair/Academic Dean. Course restricted to journalism majors or newspaper staff members. Offered on: A-E-G / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Demonstrate their ability to write news, features, and opinions, and their knowledge of journalism history, ethics, and the role of the media in a democratic society.
  2. Write a letter of application and a resume.
  3. Market themselves through the creation of an electronic portfolio.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Special and current topics in English may be available. See "Class Schedule Search" for a complete listing each term. Prerequisite: ENG101.

The study of editing and design techniques for print and electronic media. Methods for editing and packaging stories will be discussed, as well as the topics of design and pagination. Headline writing, caption writing and typography and their employment in newspaper design will be explored. Use of the Associated Press Style Manual will be emphasized. (Offered spring semester only.) Prerequisite: ENG101 and ENG170. Offered on: A / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Understand the importance of editing, fact checking, and news judgment in media writing.
  2. Understand the working relationship between editor and writer, including the role of editor as manager and leader in the newsroom.
  3. Improve copy, write headlines, and design pages for print media.
  4. Write copy in accordance with Associated Press style criteria and other applicable current style criteria.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Advanced course in writing, emphasizing good organization and forceful expression. Treats various forms of exposition: the personal essay of opinion, introspection, retrospection and experience, and the descriptive essay of observation and analysis. Prerequisite: ENG101. Offered on: A-E-G / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Demonstrate a variety of strategies for planning, organizing, and writing an essay.
  2. Write essays that demonstrate the following qualities: a controlling purpose; logical organization (an appropriate method of development); a consistent tone (suitable for the purpose of the paper); use of specific examples or details to support the central purpose of the essay.
  3. Write essays that demonstrate the following writing skills: conciseness, emphasis, sentence variety, and coherence.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Examines some of principal elements shared by literature and film (narration, character development and motivation, choice of setting, symbols and theme) to develop understanding of common factors between the two genres and the realization that when literature is transformed into film it must undergo some fundamental changes which may ultimately alter the text's intent. Note: Fulfills SUNY General Education Requirement for Humanities and The Arts. Prerequisite: ENG101. Offered on: A-G 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
