1. To identify shared components of literature and film (narration, character development, setting, symbols, theme) and components exclusive to each medium to understand how these components shape meaning.
  2. To compare and contrast notions of authorship between literature and film, identifying strategies and methods used by writers and filmmakers.
  3. To close read both literary texts and films for interpretation and evaluation.
  4. To write critically and creatively about literature and film, producing thesis driven arguments supported by evidence.
  5. To participate in a shared community of readers, writers, and viewers, contributing to group workshops and class discussions.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Advanced workshop course devoted to writing fiction, with emphasis placed on development of craft, voice and editorial skills. Students submit short stories and/or novel excerpts for review and discussion. Prerequisite: ENG101 and ENG131. Offered on: A-E-G / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Write original pieces of fiction. Develop understanding of the writing processes appropriate to creating a significant work of fiction—a novel or unified series of short stories.
  2. Understand how to present or market fiction for an intended audience.
  3. Apply revision techniques to improve plotting, structure, character development, and pacing with emphasis on completion of a writing project.
  4. Edit writing for clarity and correctness.
  5. Understand the role of contemporary fiction through the study of classmates’ work and/or the work of published writers.
  6. Develop a critical vocabulary and further the understanding of contemporary fiction through critically responding to peers’ writing.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Advanced workshop course devoted to writing poetry, with emphasis on development of craft, voice and editorial skills. Students submit poems for review and discussion. Prerequisite: ENG101 and ENG131. Offered on: A-E-G / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Write original pieces of poetry. Develop understanding of the writing processes appropriate to creating a significant work of poetry a book of poems, a chapbook, or unified series of Poems.
  2. Understand how to present or market poetry for an intended audience.
  3. Apply revision techniques to improve and develop form and structure, genre, prosody, sound crafting, and diction.
  4. Edit writing for clarity and correctness.
  5. Understand the role of contemporary poetry through the study of classmates’ work and the work of published writers.
  6. Develop a critical vocabulary and further the understanding of contemporary poetry through critically responding to peers’ writing.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Study of significant contemporary works which illustrate important themes in modern thought with emphasis on contemporary insights. Note: Fulfills SUNY General Education Requirement for Humanities. Prerequisite: ENG101. Offered on: A-E-G / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Analyze common aesthetic and philosophical trends associated with contemporary literature.
  2. Understand the cultural, historical, and social traditions reflected in contemporary literature.
  3. Write essays of literary analysis which demonstrate the following qualities: controlling purpose, clear focus, adequate development, logical organization and use of pertinent textual details to support purpose.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Explores origins and historical development of the short story, its unique characteristics and its relationship to other literary forms. Students read wide variety of short stories from different historical periods. Some authors who may be included are Faulkner, O'Connor, Melville, Poe, O'Henry, Updike, Cheever, Joyce, Hemingway, Welty, de Maupassant, James, Kafka and others. Note: Fulfills SUNY General Education Requirement for Humanities. Prerequisite: ENG101. Offered on: A-E-G / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Understand the origin and development of the short story as a unique art form, and have a working knowledge of appropriate cultural, economic, or philosophical concepts that have influenced its production.
  2. Analyze representative texts, taking into consideration some of the following: the specific historical, literary, and aesthetic movements associated with the short story, and the major elements of fiction, such as setting, exposition, theme, plot, characterization, and narrative point of view.
  3. Write essays of literary analysis which demonstrate the following qualities: controlling purpose, clear focus, adequate development, logical organization, and use of pertinent textual details to support purpose.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Study of communication techniques used by mass media in American society: newspapers, periodicals, television, radio, films. Prerequisite: ENG101. Offered on: A-E-G / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Demonstrate through verbal discussions and presentations, written assignments, group collaborations and other mediums a critical understanding of mass media texts and their representations.
  2. Recognize through media literacy the relationship between mass media and consumer choices.
  3. Understand the history, evolution, and ideological influences of various genres of mass media; for example, print, radio, television, and the internet.
  4. Identify through critical analysis media bias and propaganda.
  5. Understand the complex paradigm that characterizes media delivery and intended audience.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Traces development of documentary film through viewing films, reading critical essays, and discussing and writing about the films. Students analyze films focusing on cinematic elements such as point of view and narrative. Students examine films as statements by individuals living within a particular cultural framework, as instruments of propaganda, as entertainment, and as devices which expand our perspectives of world around us. Note: Credit given for ENG208 or CIN156, but not both. Prerequisite: ENG101. Offered on: G / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Analysis of camera shots and distances, camera movement, framing techniques.
  2. Analysis of narrative choices including the selection of voice-over and the use of interviews, pacing and rhythm of a film.
  3. Analysis of editing choices made by a director, which determine a film’s objectivity or subjectivity and bias and how manipulation affects the overall value of the film.
  4. Students will read reviews of the films online which will allow them to examine professional top critics’ responses to the films when they were initially shown, thus giving them a model for film critique which will help them understand how a film succeeds or fails.
  5. Planning, organizing, and structuring written drafts of responses which access each film for its educational, entertainment.
  6. Analyzing the ethical issues that arise from a director’s cinematic choices both orally and through written responses.
  7. After lectures and class discussions, students will connect the important concepts of the films into a draft whose ideas are focused, clearly stated, and fully supported with specific references to sequences and scenes from the films.
  8. Editing final drafts for clarity, coherence, and correctness.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Survey of historical, prophetic and poetic literature in the Old and New Testaments with attention paid to historical and cultural context. Note: Fulfills SUNY General Education Requirement for Humanities. Prerequisite: ENG101. Offered on: A-E-G / 3 cr. hrs.

Deals with the future as seen through literature of science fiction. Among themes covered are the effect of science and technology on human beings in a futuristic landscape and the modern mythological journey of the heroine/hero. Among writers included are H.G. Wells, Robert Heinlein, Arthur C. Clarke, Isaac Asimov, Frederick Pohl and Ursula LeGuin. Note: Fulfills SUNY General Education Requirement for Humanities. Prerequisite: ENG101. Offered on: A / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Analyze common aesthetic and philosophical trends associated with science fiction.
  2. Understand the cultural, historical, and social traditions reflected in science fiction.
  3. Write essays of literary analysis which demonstrate the following qualities: controlling purpose, clear focus, adequate development, logical organization and use of pertinent textual details to support purpose.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Focuses on major works by black writers and social/historical contexts informing these works. The literature includes slave narratives, essays, autobiographies, poetry, plays and film. Among writers whose works are considered are F. Douglass, L. Brent, W.E.B. DuBois, B. T. Washington, R. Wright, J. Baldwin, G. Brooks, R. Hayden, T. Morrison, A. Walker, A. Wilson, I. Reed and T. McMillan. Note: Fulfills SUNY General Education Requirement for Humanities. Prerequisite: ENG101. Offered on: A-E-G / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Understand the genres and distinctive aesthetic features of African-American texts.
  2. Understand the context of the works, including but not limited to literary, historical, social, political and cultural contexts.
  3. Write essays of literary analysis which demonstrate the following qualities: controlling purpose, clear focus, adequate development, logical organization and use of pertinent textual details to support purpose.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Focuses on contemporary literature from Caribbean, Latin America, North and Sub-Saharan Africa, Middle East, East Asia and Southeast Asia. Note: Fulfills SUNY General Education Requirement for Other World Civilizations and Humanities. Prerequisite: ENG101 and ENG102. Offered on: A-E-G / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Understand and analyze contemporary fiction, poetry, essays, and film by authors from at least three of the following: Caribbean, Latin America, North and Sub-Saharan Africa, Middle East, East Asia and Southeast Asia.
  2. Examine non-western civilizations and their values as revealed through the texts.
  3. Identify cultural and historical importance of various non-western contemporary issues.
  4. Write essays of literary analysis which demonstrate the following qualities: controlling purpose, clear focus, adequate development, logical organization and use of pertinent textual details to support purpose.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Study of major themes and styles in Middle Ages, Renaissance and Age of Reason as they appear in the works of such authors as Chaucer, Marlowe, Shakespeare, Donne, Milton, Swift and Pope. Note: Fulfills SUNY General Education Requirement for Humanities. Prerequisite: ENG101. Offered on: A-E-G / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Analyze works of representative English writers through the end of the eighteenth century.
  2. Demonstrate an understanding of English literary texts on their own merits and in relation to relevant literary, historical, political, religious, and philosophical contexts.
  3. Distinguish among the major literary movements and genres of this era, such as Metaphyscial Poetry, Neoclassicism, Restoration Drama, and Elizabethan Drama.
  4. Demonstrate an ability to write analytical essays which reflect an understanding of the literature, are logically organized, and are written in clear, concise prose.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Study of works of such Romantic poets as Blake, Wordsworth, Coleridge, Shelley, Keats and Byron; such major Victorian writers as Bronte and Tennyson; and such 20th century writers as Joyce, Thomas and Beckett. Note: Fulfills SUNY General Education Requirement for Humanities. Prerequisite: ENG101. Offered on: A-E-G / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Analyze works of representative English writers from the end of the eighteenth century to the present.
  2. Demonstrate an understanding of English literary texts on their own merits and in relation to relevant literary, historical, political, religious, and philosophical contexts.
  3. Distinguish among the major literary movements of this era, such as Romanticism, Gothic Fiction, Victorian Fiction and Poetry, Aestheticism, Modernism, Postmodernism, and Postcolonialism.
  4. Demonstrate an ability to write analytical essays which reflect an understanding of the literature, are logically organized and are written in clear, concise prose.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: A study of primary trends and themes in literature of American writers from the Colonial Period through the Civil War. Works of such writers as Franklin, Irving, Cooper, Poe, Emerson, Thoreau, Hawthorne, Melville, Whitman and Dickinson are discussed. Note: Fulfills SUNY General Education Requirement for Humanities. Prerequisite: ENG101. Offered on: A-E-G / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Analyze works of representative American writers through the Civil War.
  2. Understand American literary texts on their own merits and in relation to relevant literary, historical, political, religious, and philosophical contexts.
  3. Distinguish among the major literary movements and genres of this era, such as the Native American tradition, Puritanism, Enlightenment thinking, Romanticism, Transcendentalism, Slave Narrative, Sentimentalism, and Domestic Fiction.
  4. Write analytical essays which reflect an understanding of the literature, are logically organized, and are written in clear, concise prose.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Study of American literature from end of the Civil War to the present, highlighting such central figures as Twain, Crane, Fitzgerald, Hemingway, Faulkner, O'Neill and Frost. Note: Fulfills SUNY General Education Requirement for Humanities. Prerequisite: ENG101. Offered on: A-E-G / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Analyze works of representative American writers from the Civil War to the present.
  2. Understand American literary texts on their own merits and in relation to relevant literary, historical, political, religious, and philosophical contexts.
  3. Distinguish among the major literary movements of this era, such as Realism, Naturalism, Regionalism, Harlem Renaissance, Modernism, Post-Modernism, and the Beat Generation.
  4. Write analytical essays which reflect an understanding of the literature, are logically organized and are written in clear, concise prose.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Focuses on literature that investigates humankind¿s relationships with natural world. Among writers whose works are considered are H.D. Thoreau, R. Carson, E. Abbey, A. Dillard, W. Berry, H. Beston, W. Heyen, A. Leopold and R. Nelson. Prerequisite: ENG101. Offered on: A-E-G / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Understand the origin and development of environmental literature, and have a working knowledge of appropriate cultural and philosophical concepts that have influenced its production.
  2. Identify and analyze specific historic, literary, and aesthetic movements associated with literature of the environment.
  3. Write essays of literary analysis which demonstrate the following qualities: controlling purpose, clear focus, adequate development, logical organization, and use of pertinent textual details to support purpose.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: This course focuses on works of modern Latina/o writers, including such authors as Oscar Hijuelos, María Irene Fornés and Nilo Cruz (Cuban-American), Julia de Burgos, Miguel Algarín, and Sandra María Esteves (Puerto Rican/Nuyorican), Gloria Anzaldúa and Luis Valdéz (Chicana/o), and Junot Díaz and Julia Alvarez (Dominican-American). Such themes as language, alienation, identity, exile and assimilation, prejudice, cultural and ethnic pride, religion, and family are explored. Note: (1) Fulfills SUNY General Education Requirement for Humanities. (2) Credit given for either ENG218 or HUM218, but not both. Prerequisite: ENG101. Offered on: G / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Develop the ability to read thoughtfully, critically, and creatively and to respond to literature both orally and in writing.
  2. Compare and distinguish between a variety of Latina/o literary voices associated with different genres and countries of origin.
  3. Analyze, discuss, interpret, and reflect on the work of Latina/o writers and their unique status in the United States.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Study of British, European and American literature of the modern period (up to and including WW II) focusing on such literary developments as naturalism, impressionism, stream of consciousness and existentialism. An attempt is made to view the works in a psychological, historical and sociological context. Writers who may be included in discussion are Dostoevsky, Hesse, Conrad, Mann, Joyce, Kafka, Camus, Yeats, and Faulkner. Note: Fulfills SUNY General Education Requirement for Humanities. Prerequisite: ENG101. Offered on: A-E-G / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Understand how modernism represented a conscious break from traditional forms of art and culture.
  2. Demonstrate an understanding of modernist texts on their own merits and in relation to relevant historical and cultural contexts.
  3. Identify various innovative techniques used in modernist texts, such as collage, objective correlative, stream of consciousness, handling of myth, and experimentation with plot, point of view and time.
  4. Write analytical essays which reflect an understanding of the literature, are logically organized and are written in clear, concise prose.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Critical study of representative Shakespearean comedies, tragedies and histories, including examination of the Elizabethan world picture. Note: Fulfills SUNY General Education Requirement for Humanities. Prerequisite: ENG101. Offered on: A-E-G / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Analyze representative Shakespearean texts.
  2. Understand relevant social, intellectual, aesthetic, historical and/or political ideologies surrounding Shakespeare's work.
  3. Understand issues associated with the plays as either live or filmed performance.
  4. Write essays of literary analysis which demonstrate the following qualities: controlling purpose, clear focus, adequate development, logical organization and use of pertinent textual details to support purpose.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Study of theme, form and imagery in traditional and contemporary poetry. Note: Fulfills SUNY General Education Requirement for Humanities. Prerequisite: ENG101. Offered on: A-E-G / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Analyze poems by employing various critical methods.
  2. Understand the context in which the poem was produced, including some of the following: biographical, aesthetical, historical, political, or social contexts.
  3. Understand the poetic craft, including various poetic structures, rhythm and sound devices, imagery, figurative language, symbol and allegory, allusion, denotation and connotation of words as a way to appreciate how a poet transforms human experience into a poem.
  4. Demonstrate proficiency in analyzing and interpreting poems by some of the following: writing papers, presenting panel discussions, and preparing and presenting oral reports.
  5. Write essays of literary analysis which demonstrate the following qualities: controlling purpose, clear focus, adequate development, logical organization and use of pertinent textual details to support purpose.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Examines development of modern detective story from its origins in mid-19th century to today's popular formats. Explores differing representations of society by "classic" British, American and contemporary multicultural writers and critiques the ways in which recent film and weekly TV series attempt to fuse classic motifs with info-age commercialism. Encourages students to become detectives themselves as they research topics for in-class discussions and papers. Prerequisite: ENG101. Offered on: G / 3 cr. hrs.

Examines the genre of magical realism, fiction in which the relationship between ordinary and extraordinary provokes narrative interpretations in relation to the history, cultures, myths superstition and the politics it represents. This course will analyze ideologies which combine the conflicting perspectives of what is a rational view of reality and what is imaginary. Among writers included are Nikolai Gogol, Gabriel Garcia Marquez, Toni Morrison, Angela Carter, Carlos Fuentes, Isabel Allende and John Cheever. Note: Fulfills SUNY General Education Requirement for Humanities. Prerequisite: ENG101 and ENG102. Offered on: A / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Recognize magical realism as a genre.
  2. Understand how oral traditions served different social functions before written words took their place.
  3. Explore how cultures rooted in oral traditions are sensitive to superstition and interpretations of everyday events.
  4. Research histories, social and cultural changes in magical realist texts.
  5. Examine mythology and its social functions in magical realist texts.
  6. Write essays of literary analysis which demonstrate the following qualities: controlling purpose, clear focus, adequate development, logical organization and use of pertinent textual details to support purpose.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Special and current topics in English may be available. See "Class Schedule Search" for a complete listing each term. Prerequisite: ENG101.

Honors special topics courses in English may be available for Honors students as well as those who have received permission from campus honors program coordinator. See "Class Schedule Search" for a complete listing each term. Prerequisite: 3.0 GPA in 9 credits of English: ENG101, ENG102 and English elective.

Explores basic electronic design principles and system design approaches through construction and measurement of a specific system. Projects incorporate various engineering disciplines with learning analysis techniques utilizing hands on design and simulation software. Students learn basics of team building, problem solving, individual and group dynamic communication skills. Each project constructed, tested and presented by the group. (2 hrs. lecture, 2 hrs. laboratory) Corequisite: MAT141. Offered on: A / 2 cr. hrs.

Introductory course in use of computers for solving engineering problems. Principle emphasis on formulation of problems and their solution within framework of the C programming language. Prerequisite: Admission to Engineering program. Offered on: A / 3 cr. hrs.

Application of Newtonian mechanics to equilibrium of particles and rigid bodies, vector representation of forces in two and three dimensions, moment of a force about a point or axis; centroids and moment of inertia, laws of dry friction, and force analysis of simple structures. Prerequisite: MAT142 and PHY130. Offered on: A / 3 cr. hrs.

Continuation of application of Newtonian mechanics to particles and rigid bodies in motion; rectilinear and curvilinear motion of particles; time-rate of change of linear momentum; angular momentum work of a force and kinetic energy; kinematics and kinetics of rigid bodies; plane motion; rigid body dynamics; and mechanical vibrations. Prerequisite: ENS118. Offered on: A / 3 cr. hrs.

Introduction to electrical networks and devices in both DC and AC systems. Introduces analysis techniques such as Kerchief¿s current and voltage laws, Ohm¿s law, superposition reciprocity, Mesh and Nodal analysis, and Thevenin and Norton theorems. Components and circuits include resistors, capacitors, inductors, R-L, R-C and R-L-C circuits. Topics include sinusoidal steady-state response, resonance, positive real functions, power calculations, Fourier analysis, and transient analysis using Laplace Transforms. (3 hrs. lecture, 3 hrs. laboratory) Prerequisite: MAT142 and PHY130. Corequisites: MAT204 and PHY230. Offered on: A / 4 cr. hrs.

This course is an introductory level study of the Earth’s environmental systems and the role of humans in those systems. Students will be introduced to key elements of ecology and ecosystem sciences, focusing on their function and importance for human societies, as well as the impact of human activity on these systems. The course stresses the roles of resource availability and use, biogeochemical cycling, and anthropogenic effects, both locally and globally. This course also addresses the importance of maintaining the natural functioning of environmental systems for the well-being of human society, culture, and survival. Note: Fulfills SUNY General Education Requirement for Natural Sciences. (3 hrs. lecture, 2 hrs. laboratory) Prerequisite: MAT101 or higher. Offered on: A-E-G / 4 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Define and describe key components of “What is Environmental Science?”
  2. Describe nutrient, energy, and chemical cycles at both the ecosystem and biosphere level of complexity.
  3. Describe and understand the methods used to measure and study environmental problems.
  4. Define resources and their limitations as used by ecosystems and human societies.
  5. Describe how human activities directly or indirectly impact resource availability locally and globally and be able to give examples.
  6. Define and describe the components of the environmental footprint of individuals and societies.
  7. Develop skills in hypothesis development, experimental design, data collection and analysis.
  8. Be able to interpret and evaluate basic and new scientific data about environmental topics.
  9. Be able to apply critical thinking strategies to environmental issues and the development of possible solutions.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Focuses on cause and effect relationship of pollution and environmental degradation. Emphasis on current environmental issues threatening well-being of earth's ecosystems, resources and populations. Special attention given to Long Island's environmental problems. Notes: (1) Credit given for ENV115 or ENV128, but not both. (2) Does not fulfill a laboratory science requirement. No prerequisite. Offered on: E / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Interpret many environmental principles, such as, eco-sanity, sustainability, the Precautionary Principle, the Law of Unintended Consequences, the Value of a Statistical Life, and quantifying environmental impacts and ecological footprints.
  2. Gauge the influence of pollutants on the major causes of death in the U.S. and the world.
  3. Describe the environmental history of London and New York City before, during and after the Industrial Revolution.
  4. Cite the history of toxic waste disposal in New York Harbor and Long Island Sound.
  5. Evaluate the intent and success of environmental legislation, e.g., the River’s Pollution Act, Clean Water Act, Clean Air Act, Safe Drinking Water Act, Marine Pollution Treaty.
  6. Illustrate and describe the various ways society collects and processes sewage, garbage and industrial wastes.
  7. Present the dynamics of human population growth verbally and graphically, and explain the challenges presented by population growth and decline.
  8. Explain the environmental impacts of extracting and using fossil fuels.
  9. Understand the military and civilian applications of nuclear energy and the challenges of nuclear waste containment.
  10. Examine the potential of alternative energies and renewable resources.
  11. Compare the different explanations for global warming and global climate change, and describe how these changes will affect natural ecosystems and human society.
  12. Identify and describe the origins and distribution of public drinking water, the sources of drinking water contamination, and water purification methods.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Identifies and examines current environmental problems from viewpoint of environmental, social, political and economic consequences. Solutions are formulated and their impacts examined. Notes: (1) Credit given for ENV115 or ENV128, but not both. (2) Does not fulfill a laboratory science requirement. No prerequisite. Offered on: A / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Critically analyze both novel and already considered environmental problems.
  2. Identify the key biological and/or ecological principles at the root of major environmental problems.
  3. Identify the major social, political, and economic factors impacting the environmental problem and its possible solutions.
  4. Make informed decisions in the future on how their actions impact the environment.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: This is an e-folio course for the GTFH Scholar Program. The course does not carry any credit/fees and will be taken as a Blended course by all GTFH scholarship receipents.

Study of Planet Earth, its origin, structure, composition and the forces which shape its surface. Plate tectonics provides framework for understanding processes of volcanism, mountain building and earthquakes. External forces such as glaciers, streams and ocean waves are examined in order to interpret the landscape. Laboratories include studies of minerals, rocks, maps, photographs and other materials used by geologists to study the earth. Some field work required. Note: Fulfills SUNY General Education Requirement for Natural Sciences. (3 hrs. lecture, 2 hrs. laboratory) Prerequisite: MAT007 or equivalent. Offered on: A-E-G / 4 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Understand the origin and composition of the earth.
  2. Identify common minerals and rocks.
  3. Distinguish between igneous, metamorphic and sedimentary rocks.
  4. Interpret the rock cycle.
  5. Interpret geologic maps and cross-sections, and identify geologic structures.
  6. Understand volcanism, mountain building, earthquakes and glaciology.
  7. Understand plate tectonics and its relationship to earth features.
  8. Understand basic hydrogeologic principles and the importance of groundwater.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Introduction to evolutionary aspects of geology, development of continents, mountains and basins through the ages, and the parallel evolution of plants and animals. Laboratory stresses fossil relationships and stratigraphic problems. May include field trips. Note: Fulfills SUNY General Education Requirement for Natural Sciences. (3 hrs. lecture, 2 hrs. laboratory) Prerequisite: MAT007 or equivalent.Offered on: A-E-G / 4 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Describe the origin of the universe.
  2. Understand the origin and composition of the earth.
  3. Distinguish between igneous, metamorphic and sedimentary rocks.
  4. Understand plate tectonics.
  5. Interpret ancient sedimentary environments based on sedimentary structures such as cross bedding, graded bedding, ordinary bedding, ripples, and mudcracks.
  6. Interpret earth history from sedimentary beds, rock units, or other bodies of rock using relative dating techniques.
  7. Describe possible theories on the origin of the solar system and the formation of earth.
  8. Describe theories on the origin of the earth's internal structure, its oceans, and atmosphere.
  9. Describe the various methods of fossilization.
  10. Describe the doctrine of organic evolution and evidence supporting it.
  11. Use fossils to recognize units of rock deposited during particular increments of geologic time and to reconstruct paleoenvironments.
  12. Describe the geologic history and the record of life (with an emphasis on North America) during the Hadean, Archean, Proterozoic, and Phanerozoic .

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Topics include current environmental issues relating to geologic environment. Topics covered will include geologic hazards, land use planning and development, surface and subsurface water systems, solid waste disposal and management, energy sources and consumption. May include field trip(s) and attendance at town planning board meetings. (3 hrs. lecture, 2 hrs. laboratory) Prerequisite: MAT007 or equivalent. Offered on: A-G / 4 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Understand the origin and composition of the earth.
  2. Identify common minerals and rocks.
  3. Distinguish between igneous, metamorphic and sedimentary rocks.
  4. Interpret the rock cycle.
  5. Understand common sources of energy resources.
  6. Interpret topographic, groundwater contour, land use and zoning maps.
  7. Understand volcanic and seismic hazards.
  8. Understand plate tectonics and its relationship to natural hazards.
  9. Understand basic hydrogeologic principles and be able to perform and interpret basic groundwater contamination studies.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: This course will focus on the geology and geological history of the terrestrial planets, planetary satellites and minor bodies of the solar system as revealed by the most recent planetary missions. Topics will include the origin of terrestrial bodies, the internal structure of terrestrial planets, planetary tectonics and volcanism, and surface processes such as meteorite impacts and weathering. Note: Fulfills SUNY General Education Requirement for Natural Sciences. (3 hrs. lecture) Prerequisite: MAT007 or equivalent. Offered on: A / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Demonstrate an understanding of the basic geology and geophysics of Earth.
  2. Demonstrate an understanding of the various techniques used to acquire geological knowledge of Earth and of other planets.
  3. Demonstrate an understanding of the geologies of the different terrestrial planets and bodies within the solar system.
  4. Demonstrate an understanding of the origin and evolution of the Solar System as a whole.
  5. Demonstrate an ability to transfer geological knowledge gained in the context of the Earth to a wide range of different planetary environments.
  6. Demonstrate a wider understanding of how scientific hypotheses are developed and tested.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Familiarizes students interested in geology with field methods in various geologic environments. Topographic maps and aerial photos are used in conjunction with study of stratigraphic sections and structural relationships. Fossil assemblages, weathering and erosional features are studied. Credits vary with duration of course. (Travel expenses are responsibility of the student.) Prerequisite: ESC101. Offered on: A / 1-4 cr. hrs.
Special and current topics in Earth and Space Science may be available. See "Class Schedule Search" for a complete listing each term. Offered on: A-E-G / 3-4 cr. hrs.

CourseInventory.CourseLongTitle: Special Topics Honors: Earth & Space Science
CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Honors special topics in Earth and Space Science may be available for Honors students as well as those who have received permission from campus Honors Program Coordinator. See "Class Schedule Search" for a complete listing each term. Offered on: A-E-G / 3-4 cr. hrs.
Independent study courses in earth and space science may be available. See the online catalog for a complete listing or contact academic chair. Offered on: A-E-G / 1-4 cr. hrs.

For students whose native language is not English, ESL011 is first of two courses which develop basic English reading skills necessary for content area study required in college. Concentrates on improving reading comprehension by focusing on main idea, vocabulary development, summary skills and critical thinking skills. In addition to class discussion on reading process, students also participate in independent book reading and small group activities. ESL011 and ESL012 each require minimum of 1 hour per week on selected assignments in Reading Center. Graded on an S/W/U/R basis. No prerequisite. Offered on: A-E-G / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Apply multiple reading comprehension skills to reading passages.
  2. Identify main idea and supporting details
  3. Demonstrate improved reading comprehension through discussion and writing.
  4. Relate readings to their own knowledge base and cultural background.
  5. Organize information from a text in schematic ways; e.g. outlines, sets charts and tables.
  6. Summarize information from the texts orally and in writing.
  7. Apply grammatical knowledge to reading skills.
  8. Use context clues to infer meaning of unknown words and idiomatic expressions.
  9. Use new vocabulary in appropriate contexts.
  10. Increase reading speed.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: For students whose native language is not English. ESL012 further develops college-level reading and study skills and examines new concepts and their applications such as English textual patterns. Introduces selections from various academic areas. ESL011 and ESL012 each require minimum of 1 hour per week on selected assignments in Reading Center. Graded on an S/W/U/R basis. Prerequisite: ESL011. Offered on: A-E-G / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Identify key words in main idea and supporting statements.
  2. Recognize and distinguish common patterns of text organization and discourse markers which identify same.
  3. Identify an author's purpose and intent.
  4. Distinguish fact from opinion.
  5. Make inferences and identify supporting evidence.
  6. Discuss cultural implications of reading topics.
  7. Recognize American English idiomatic expressions and apply strategies learned to derive meaning.
  8. Define their purpose for reading assignments.
  9. Relate new material to their cultural background and knowledge base.
  10. Extract and organize information from content area reading including graphic aids.
  11. Summarize readings orally and in writing.
  12. Preview, predict, and question before closely reading textbook chapters and articles.
  13. Annotate, underline, take notes and map text.
  14. Utilize new vocabulary and idiomatic and culture-specific expressions.
  15. Analyze and apply targeted grammatical and syntactic structures to text-based material.
  16. Derive meaning from content specific materials by utilizing syntactic cues.
  17. Recognize the difference between general and technical field specific vocabulary.
  18. Demonstrate the ability to use a college dictionary as well as a text glossary.
  19. Recognize stylistic differences in written discourse.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: For students who are not native speakers of English, ESL013 introduces and/or reinforces basic and complex language structures by practicing grammar and syntax through exercises designed to increase language fluency and understanding. Students learn to recognize and effectively use the structures presented through intensive study and practice. ESL013 and ESL014 each require minimum of one hour per week in Language Lab/Academic Skills Center. Graded on an S/W/U/R basis. No prerequisite. Offered on A-E-G / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Demonstrate comprehension of and accurately utilize in oral and written form the following verb tenses: simple present, simple past, simple future, present progressive, past progressive, future progressive, present perfect, past perfect, future perfect, present perfect progressive, past perfect progressive, future perfect progressive.
  2. Utilize gerunds and infinitives introduced in this course.
  3. Produce simple and compound sentences with correct subject/verb agreement.
  4. Use modals in the present/future and past as required by context.
  5. Demonstrate correct question formation.
  6. Accurately utilize singular and plural nouns, possessives, and pronouns.
  7. Differentiate parts of speech and parse sentences.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: For students who are not native speakers of English. ESL014 builds on skills developed in ESL013 and also teaches and analyzes different types of phrases and sentences to determine their correctness and appropriateness. ESL013 and ESL014 each require minimum of one hour per week in Language Lab/Academic Skills Center. Graded on an S/W/U/R basis. Prerequisite: ESL013. Offered on A-E-G / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Successfully employ dependent and independent clauses to express more complex relationships between ideas both in oral and written communication.
  2. Demonstrate comprehension of and accurately utilize restrictive and non-restrictive adjective clauses.
  3. Demonstrate comprehension of and correctly utilize the order of words in a noun clause and proper punctuation with quoted speech.
  4. Demonstrate comprehension of how English connects thought units in relationships of equality, time, or cause and effect by correctly utilizing coordinating conjunctions and adverb clauses.
  5. Demonstrate comprehension and accurately utilize conditional sentences in oral and written form.
  6. Accurately utilize the active and passive voice of the verb orally and in writing.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Develops oral communication skills of intermediate to advanced ESL students preparing for academic college courses. ESL015 develops speaking and listening skills through exercises designed to involve students in discussions on selected topics in American culture and college life. ESL015 and ESL016 each require minimum of 1 hour per week in Language Lab/Academic Skills Center. Graded on an S/W/U/R basis. No prerequisite. Offered on A-E-G / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Speech Production:
    1. Demonstrate improvement in spoken American English fluency
    2. Participate more self-confidently in academic conversations and small group discussions.
    3. Plan, organize, and deliver effective presentations by following clear, specific guidelines.
    4. Integrate notes from lectures, research, and readings into in-class discussions.
    5. Exhibit comprehension and production of basic non-verbal communication in English (e.g. appropriate body language, eye contact, turn-taking).
    6. Paraphrase information presented in listening exercises.
  2. Listening Comprehension:
    1. Show improvement in comprehension of American English spoken by different voices at different speeds of delivery using varied features of oral discourse.
    2. Develop analytic listening skills (e.g. distinguishing main and supporting ideas; identifying the speaker’s purpose, point of view and tone; recognizing fact versus opinion; listening objectively and critically).
  3. Note-taking and Study Skills:
    1. Assess his/her own progress to identify areas in need of help or extra practice in the Skills Center/Language Lab.
    2. Stay focused in class.
    3. Use note-taking abbreviations and formats.
    4. Strengthen critical thinking skills by brainstorming, supporting opinions, considering values, making decisions, solving problems, and analyzing issues.
    5. Use different types of visual aids in presentations.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Develops oral communication skills of intermediate to advanced ESL students preparing for academic college courses. ESL016 continues skills development by expanding pronunciation, presentation and listening comprehension skills. ESL015 and ESL016 each require minimum of 1 hour per week in Language Lab/Academic Skills Center. Graded on an S/W/U/R basis. Prerequisite: ESL015. Offered on A-E-G / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Effectively participate in paired, small-group and large-group discussion by analyzing and synthesizing information from lectures, readings and presentations.
  2. Use specific listening strategies to comprehend content-based informative and persuasive lectures of the type typically encountered in college classes.
  3. Develop organizational and note-taking techniques to adequately retain information for further study.
  4. Refine pronunciation (rate, parsing, and intonation) to improve comprehensibility.
  5. Use targeted academic vocabulary/grammar, including the correct word order of noun, adjective and adverb clauses.
  6. Create a coherent oral presentation using visual aids such as slides, tables and graphs to illustrate the key points.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Enhances second language academic writing skills to produce clearer and varied sentences and paragraphs for students whose native language is not English. ESL017 introduces essay writing and emphasizes spelling improvement, correct and appropriate use of vocabulary, idiomatic expressions and grammar in context that are often problematic for non-native speakers. ESL017 and ESL018 each require minimum of one hour a week on selected assignments in Language Lab/Academic Skills Center. Graded on an S/W/U/R basis. No prerequisite. Offered on: A-E-G / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Approach writing as a process.
  2. Write a 3 paragraph essay of narration, description, process and opinion.
  3. Implement the steps in the writing process: brainstorming/free writing, writing a thesis statement, drafting, revising and editing.
  4. Identify basic conventions of American academic discourse i.e., topic sentences, thesis statements, supporting statements (as opposed to patterns of organizations prevalent in native language discourse).
  5. Analyze model essays of description, narration, process, and opinion as well as cultural implications derived from each piece.
  6. Identify and analyze the connotative value of basic vocabulary, appropriateness of idiomatic expressions in writing, and build vocabulary through domain and vocabulary generating exercises.
  7. Recognize expressions and transitions of spatial relationships, linking ideas, chronology and sequence, direct and indirect statements.
  8. Examine grammatical structures in context and complete error correction exercises independently.
  9. Effectively utilize the dictionary/thesaurus.
  10. Utilize writing and grammar programs in the Academic Skills Center/Language Lab (Ammerman) to improve writing and usage.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Enhances second language academic writing skills to produce clearer and varied sentences and paragraphs for students whose native language is not English. ESL018 builds on skills developed in ESL017 and introduces various types of academic essay writing. ESL017 and ESL018 each require minimum of one hour a week on selected assignments in Language Lab/Academic Skills Center. Graded on an S/W/U/R basis. Prerequisite: ESL017. Offered on: A-E-G / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Follow the steps of the writing process (plan, organize, draft and revise) to write a series of essays that develop a clear thesis statement.
  2. Support a thesis with clear, well-ordered paragraphs that are developed with relevant details, examples or reasons.
  3. Revise drafts to correct syntactical errors arising from first language transference.
  4. Carefully edit and correct major errors common to non-native speakers resulting from language transference and overgeneralization or insufficient acquisition of target language.
  5. Write on both pre-planned and spontaneous subjects.
  6. Read and analyze specific rhetorical models considered standard in American academic settings.
  7. Produce essays appropriately employing the following rhetorical forms: exemplification, comparison/contrast, classification, cause/effect, persuasion and summary/reaction.
  8. Recognize and utilize the linear organization of conventional academic English as opposed to rhetorical structures of other cultures.
  9. Compare and contrast cultural similarities and differences to enhance and promote academic proficiency.
  10. Discuss and practice problematic vocabulary and idiomatic expressions to distinguish appropriate use in written expression.
  11. Demonstrate an understanding of the conventions of standard written English and the difference between spoken and standard written English.
  12. Demonstrate basic information literacy strategies (locate, evaluate and use information) to cite, source, quote, paraphrase and synthesize support for arguments and to avoid plagiarism.
  13. Examine, summarize and react to published works.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: The FLEW workshop will provide you with valuable resources to make your job less stressful and more manageable. Irate students? Annoying boss? Difficult faculty? We'll help you with all of them! The facilitators are Communications faculty at your campus. As College employees, they understand your needs and frustrations. Their goal is to make your job less stressful.

Introductory survey of fire prevention, protection and suppression systems providing an overview of such elements as composition of fire, home fire safety, building construction, extinguishing agents, fire-fighting equipment, fire-fighting procedures, detection and protection systems, fire extinguishers and their utilization. Foundation for other courses in the program. No prerequisite. Offered on: A / 3 cr. hrs.

Chemical characteristics and behavior of various materials which burn and/or react violently when acted upon by various other substances or conditions. Emphasis on flammable liquids, solids, dusts and gases, and attendant fire extinguishment problems. Study includes matter and energy, chemical and physical changes, atoms, the nucleus and planetary electrons, nuclear reactions and isotopes, atomic weights, kinetic molecular theory of state, forms of energy, conservation of energy, conversion of units, Boyle's Law, heat and its effects, halons and extinguishing agents. No prerequisite. Offered on: A / 3 cr. hrs.

Storage, handling, standards, explosives and firefighting techniques associated with chemicals, gases, flammable liquids, corrosives, poisons, rocket propellants and exotic fuel, and radioactive materials. Formation of toxic fumes and health hazards also stressed. Ignition and combustion characteristics of gases, liquids and solids related to free-burning fire, and explosion phenomena. Familiarization with radiological instruments, human exposure to radiation, decontamination procedures, common uses of radioactive materials and operational procedures. Prerequisite: FPT113. Offered on: A / 3 cr. hrs.

Review of fire protection considerations in building construction and facilities, including the Building Exits Code, air conditioning and ventilating appliances, roof coverings, building construction operations and tests of building materials to determine their fire safety characteristics. No prerequisite. Offered on: A / 3 cr. hrs.

Principles of hydraulics, suction and drafting water, velocity and discharge, friction loss calculations, engine and nozzle pressures, fire hydrants and mains, fire streams, sprinkler system calculations and pumps. No prerequisite. Offered on: A / 3 cr. hrs.

Principles of management as related to fire service. Includes management functions, the management cycle behavioral sciences, leadership, communications, public relations, records and reports. No prerequisite Offered on: A / 3 cr. hrs.

Enables students to devise strategies and tactics needed to resolve problems at fires and emergency scenes. Students learn Incident Command System, fire company operations, firefighter safety and operational guidelines, and procedures for major building types. No prerequisite. Offered on: A / 3 cr. hrs.

History, development and philosophy of detection and prosecutorial steps with respect to the crime of arson. Discussion of socio-economic conditions behind alarming rise in number of incendiary fires. Examination of investigatory skills, interrogation, record keeping, reports, court procedure. Study of federal, state and local arson laws. Study of chemistry of fire and explosions. No prerequisite. Offered on: A / 3 cr. hrs.

Fundamentals of industrial safety including history, safety, inspections, safety organization and committees, accident investigation records and injury rates. No prerequisite. Offered on: A / 3 cr. hrs.

More detailed safety engineering considerations, such as principles of guarding and transmission guards, local exhaust systems, electrical hazards, industrial hygiene and chemical hazards. Prerequisite: FPT171. Offered on: A / 3 cr. hrs.

First half of the introductory sequence in French which develops the four language skills of listening, speaking, reading and writing with emphasis on communicative competence. Basic concepts of French culture are introduced. Required online workbook/lab manual course component. This course is for students with little or no knowledge of French. Note: Fulfills SUNY General Education Requirement for Foreign Language. No prerequisite. Offered on: A-E-G / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Derive essential information by listening to and comprehending simple oral statements, questions, conversations, and narrations based on course-related themes.
  2. Make and respond to simple statements and questions.
  3. Engage in simple face-to-face conversation within the vocabulary, structure, and phonology appropriate to the communicative situations and functions at this level.
  4. Compose short informal notes and messages.
  5. Write short paragraphs based on familiar topics using known vocabulary and structures at this level.
  6. Articulate the basic aspects of the various Francophone cultures-in their variety-in comparison to each other and to U.S culture.
  7. React to cultural nuances by using appropriate registers.
  8. Read and demonstrate comprehension of authentic/realistic materials and texts within the context of course-related themes.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Second half of the introductory sequence in French which develops the four language skills of listening, speaking, reading and writing with emphasis on communicative competence. Basic concepts of French culture are introduced. Required online workbook/lab manual course component. Note: Fulfills SUNY General Education Requirement for Foreign Language. Prerequisite: FRE101 or fulfillment of equivalent high school placement requirement. Offered on: A-E-G / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Derive essential information by listening to and comprehending simple oral statements, questions, conversations, and narrations based on course-related themes.
  2. Make and respond to simple statements and questions.
  3. Engage in simple face-to-face conversation within the vocabulary, structure, and phonology appropriate to the communicative situations and functions at this level.
  4. Compose short, informal notes and messages.
  5. Write short paragraphs based on familiar topics using known vocabulary and structures at this level.
  6. Read and discuss authentic/realistic materials and texts within the context of course-related themes.
  7. Articulate the basic aspects of the various Francophone cultures—in their variety-- in comparison to each other and to U.S culture.
  8. React to cultural nuances by using appropriate register.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Continuing study of structures of French with more intensive oral and writing practice. Cultural and literary selections will be introduced. Required online workbook/lab manual course component. Note: Fulfills SUNY General Education Requirement for Foreign Language. Prerequisite: FRE102 or fulfillment of equivalent high school placement requirement. Offered on: A-E-G / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Derive and respond to essential information by listening to, answering/responding to oral statements, questions, conversations and narrations based on course-related themes.
  2. Make statements and questions as well as to summarize course-related material in French.
  3. Engage in face-to-face conversations within the vocabulary, structure and phonology appropriate to the communicative situations and functions of this level.
  4. Compose informal and formal notes and messages.
  5. Write essays and letters based on familiar topics using vocabulary and structures of this level.
  6. Read and answer comprehension questions on authentic/realistic material and texts within the context of course-related themes.
  7. Articulate aspects of the various Francophone cultures in comparison with the US and other cultures.
  8. Respond to cultural nuances by using appropriate registers.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Structural review focusing on oral and written communication. Introduces social, political and cultural aspects of French world through analysis of wide range of authentic literary and cultural selections. Required online workbook/lab manual course component. Note: Fulfills SUNY General Education Requirement for Foreign Language. Prerequisite: FRE201 or fulfillment of equivalent high school placement requirement. Offered on: A-E-G / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Employ the vocabulary acquired through course readings and classroom discussions when both writing and speaking the target language.
  2. Convey personal experiences, opinions and reactions to the pieces studied orally using any of the simple tenses in the target language.
  3. Refer to social, political and/or economic issues in the history of French-speaking countries.
  4. Write simple sentences without errors and write moderately complex sentences, that is sentences with conjunctions, relative pronouns, appositions and other syntactically intricate structures, without significant errors.
  5. Employ all simple verb tenses (present, past, future, conditional) with few grammatical errors and occasionally employ complex verb tenses such as past perfect, pluperfect subjunctive, conditional perfect.
  6. Make use of adverbial expressions appropriately in order to add depth to the phrase.
  7. Employ parenthetical quotes when citing passages from the text in writing.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Special and current topics in French may be available. See "Class Schedule Search" for a complete listing each term. Offered on: A-E-G / 3-4 cr. hrs.

Honors special topics in French may be available for Honors students as well as those who have received permission from campus Honors Program Coordinator. See "Class Schedule Search" for a complete listing each term. Offered on: A-E-G / 3-4 cr. hrs.
Independent study courses in french may be available. See the online catalog for a complete listing or contact academic chair. Offered on: A-E-G / 1-4 cr. hrs.

General survey of fundamental geographic characteristics of principal world regions. Particular emphasis on how differences in environment and culture greatly influence lifestyle, economy and social wellbeing. Focuses on dynamic interplay between spatial variations in the landscape and ecologic processes, socioeconomic systems and philosophic beliefs. Note: Fulfills SUNY General Education Requirement for Social Sciences and Other World Civilizations. No prerequisite. Offered on: A-E-G / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Demonstrate a basic geographic literacy.
  2. Describe the nature and scope of the discipline of geography.
  3. Show how the discipline links human society to the natural environment.
  4. Indicate the spatial forces that give uniqueness to each realm, including: physical landscape- mountains, rivers, climate, etc. and cultural landscape- religion, language, ethnicity, history, etc.
  5. Demonstrate a greater appreciation and tolerance of the multicultural world in which we live.
  6. Indicate a familiarity with maps by engaging in map-reading exercise.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Cultural geography focusing on variations among cultures as they differ, through time, from place to place. Deals with origins and diffusion of agriculture, race, religion, language, technology and settlement. Note: Fulfills SUNY General Education Requirement for Social Sciences and Other World Civilizations. No prerequisite. Offered on: A-E-G / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Understand the usefulness of geography as a tool for studying human problems and contemporary issues.
  2. Recognize how cultural differences modify the physical environment, and conversely, how environmental conditions affect humans in various cultural settings.
  3. Understand and identify basic cultural patterns and beliefs, e.g., language, political systems, religion, migration patterns, etc. and their locational associations.
  4. Identify and relate the importance of the distribution and growth of the world population.
  5. Recognize how increased urbanization impacts the global system.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Locational aspects of political characteristics. Emphasis directed toward geographic effects on political and territorial behavior of peoples of the world. Specific topics include changing frontiers and boundaries, territorial jurisdiction, population pressures, and colonialism and nationalism. Note: Fulfills SUNY General Education Requirement for Social Sciences and Other World Civilizations. No prerequisite. Offered on: A-E-G / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Understand the elements of territory and boundaries in terms of political control.
  2. Realize that an understanding of geopolitical complexities is necessary to observe and analyze the types and degrees of political control.
  3. Show how the resident population of a political region contributes to its stability, or lack thereof.
  4. Understand how human activities interface with the political environment.
  5. Understand the elements of territory and boundaries in terms of political control.
  6. Realize that an understanding of geopolitical complexities is necessary to observe and analyze the types and degrees of political control.
  7. Show how the resident population of a political region contributes to its stability, or lack thereof.
  8. Understand how human activities interface with the political environment.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Special and current topics in Geography may be available. See "Class Schedule Search" for a complete listing each term. Offered on: A-E-G / 3-4 cr. hrs.

Honors special topics in Geography may be available for Honors students as well as those who have received permission from campus Honors Program Coordinator. See "Class Schedule Search" for a complete listing each term. Offered on: A-E-G / 3-4 cr. hrs.

First half of the introductory sequence in German which develops the four language skills of listening, speaking, reading and writing with emphasis on communicative competence. Basic concepts of German culture are introduced. Required online workbook/lab manual course component. This course is for students with little or no knowledge of German. It is not appropriate for native/fluent speakers of German; GER201 is recommended or see department chair. Note: Fulfills SUNY General Education Requirement for Foreign Language. (Offered fall semester only) No prerequisite. Offered on: A-E-G / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Derive essential information by listening to and comprehending simple oral statements, questions, conversations and narrations based on course-related themes.
  2. Make and respond to simple statements and questions.
  3. Engage in simple face-to-face conversation within the vocabulary, structure, and phonology appropriate to the communicative situations and functions at this level.
  4. Compose short, informal notes and messages.
  5. Write short paragraphs based on familiar topics using known vocabulary and structures at this level.
  6. Read and respond to authentic/realistic materials and texts within the context of course-related themes.
  7. Articulate the basic aspects of the German cultures in comparison to U.S. culture.
  8. React to cultural nuances by using appropriate register.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Second half of introductory sequence in German which develops the four language skills of listening, speaking, reading and writing with emphasis on communicative competence. Basic concepts of German culture are introduced. Required online workbook/lab manual course component. Note: Fulfills SUNY General Education Requirement for Foreign Language. Prerequisite: GER101 or fulfillment of equivalent high school placement requirement. Offered on: A-E-G / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Listen and reply to relatively simple oral statement and questions as well as message and conversations based on topics in everyday situations.
  2. Make simple statements and engage in simple face-to-face conversation within the vocabulary, structure, and phonology appropriate to the communicative situations and functions at this level.
  3. Write short paragraphs based on familiar topics using known vocabulary and structures at this level.
  4. Read and respond to narrative and descriptive authentic materials and edited texts within a familiar context.
  5. Discuss the basic aspects of German culture, such as climate and geography, family life, school, and university life, and how they compare with American culture.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Continues study of structures of German with more intensive oral and writing practice. Cultural and literary selections are introduced. Required online workbook/lab manual course component. Note: Fulfills SUNY General Education Requirement for Foreign Language. Prerequisite: GER102 or fulfillment of equivalent high school placement requirement. Offered on: A-E / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Derive essential information by listening to, answering/responding to oral statements, questions, conversations and narrations based on course-related themes.
  2. Make and respond to statements and questions as well as to summarize course-related themes.
  3. Engage in face-to-face conversations within the vocabulary, structure and phonology appropriate to the communicative situations and functions of this level.
  4. Compose informal and formal notes and messages.
  5. Write essays and letters based on familiar topics using vocabulary and structures of this level.
  6. Read and answer comprehension questions on authentic/realistic material and texts within the context of course-related themes.
  7. Articulate aspects of the various German cultures in comparison with the U.S. and other cultures.
  8. Respond to cultural nuances by using appropriate registers.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Structural review focusing on oral and written communication. Introduces social, political and cultural aspects of German world through analysis of wide range of authentic literary and cultural selections. Note: Fulfills SUNY General Education Requirement for Foreign Language. Prerequisite: GER201 or fulfillment of equivalent high school placement requirement. Offered on: A-E / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Derive essential information by listening to, answering/responding to oral statements, questions, conversations and narrations based on course-related themes.
  2. Make and respond to statements and questions as well as to summarize course-related material in German.
  3. Engage in face-to-face conversations within the vocabulary, structure and phonology appropriate to the communicative situations and functions of this level.
  4. Compose informal and formal notes and messages.
  5. Write essays and letters based on familiar topics using vocabulary and structures of this level.
  6. Read and answer comprehension questions on authentic/realistic material and texts within the context of course-related themes.
  7. Articulate aspects of the various German cultures in comparison with the US and other cultures.
  8. Respond to cultural nuances by using appropriate registers.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Special and current topics in German may be available. See "Class Schedule Search" for a complete listing each term. Offered on: A-E-G / 3-4 cr. hrs.

Honors special topics in German may be available for Honors students as well as those who have received permission from campus Honors Program Coordinator. See "Class Schedule Search" for a complete listing each term. Offered on: A-E-G / 3-4 cr. hrs.
Independent study courses in german may be available. See the online catalog for a complete listing or contact academic chair. Offered on: A-E-G / 1-4 cr. hrs.

Introduces principles and elements of graphic design with learning to research, create thumbnails, refine sketches, and work up visual solutions to production projects. Students focus on the details of page composition and the relationship of space to clarity, legibiligy and aesthetics. (offered fall semester only) (1 hr. lecture, 4 hrs. studio) Corequisite: GRD102. Offered on: E / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Develop a sensitivity towards graphic design identification and problem-solving
  2. Learn and apply elements and principles to solve graphic design problems
  3. Apply the creative process from conception to final production/presentation utilizing key production techniques and skills
  4. Exhibit presentation abilities of design work to an audience
  5. Discuss and evaluate graphic design using appropriate terminology verbally and in written form

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Introduces technical execution of concepts in digital page production and vector graphics, including raster image and device resolution, translating physical to digital media, file types, and file managment. Emphasis will be on using sofware to solve problems related to GRD101 projects. (offered fall semester only) (2 hrs. lecture, 2 hrs. studio) Corequisites: GRD101. Offered on: E / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Demonstrate an ability to layout type and imagery to produce print-ready electronic files.
  2. Identify and cite sources for graphics, photographs and literary sources.
  3. Use technical skills and basic design guidelines from demonstrations to graphical communicate messages.
  4. Identify and use key graphic design terminology.
  5. Use rasterized and vector imagery and understand image resolution.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Examines typographic design and use of basic letter forms, contrast, hierarchy of information, type styles, families and characteristics, color theory, and grids. Production techniques examined using vector and page layout software. (offered spring semester only) (1 hr. lecture, 4 hrs. studio) Prerequisites: GRD101 and GRD102 with a grade of C or higher. Offered on: E / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Demonstrate the ability to visualize an control typographic spacing parameters such as kerning, tracking, leading, and inset spacing.
  2. Exhibit control of common typographic problems.
  3. Manipulate typographic settings to organize and improve the legibility and readability of text.
  4. Develop typographic systems to arrange text into hierarchical message systems.
  5. Construct and apply various grids systems in order to improve readability, and create emphasis, structure and organization to texts.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Introduces first-semester Computer Art and Graphic Design students with college survival skills for two distinctive degree programs. No prerequisite. Offered on: E / 1 cr. hr.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Demonstrate basic study skills including time management, goal setting, test and note taking.
  2. Synthesize information and procedures for establishing priorities, clarifying values, and determining short- and long-term goals within the professional, personal, and educational sphere including career development, academic advisement and planning.
  3. Assemble a vocabulary of terms when discussing digital design to communicate research, problem-solving, and critical thinking.
  4. Examine personal ideas and decisions regarding issues typically faced by college students (include, but are not limited to, health and fitness, relationships, financial planning, alcohol and drug use and abuse, sexuality).
  5. Recognize and demonstrate an understanding of diversity within academic and personal life as well as the diversity of working as a professional designer.
  6. Expand their knowledge of the resources and services provided by Suffolk County Community College and the extended community, such as health, computing, career and academic services.
  7. Acquire academic survival skills to promote active learning.
  8. Effectively use the computer to manage activities at the college, including E-mail, Internet usage, online course registration and digital design courses.
  9. Develop interpersonal skills through interaction in group activities.
  10. Demonstrate library research methods to search for career opportunities within the field of digital design and to research past and current professionals in the field.
  11. Describe and discuss procedures for improved time and money management.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Explores visual problem-solving as related to area of publication design. Investigates techniques and imagery within various formats of publications such as magazines, brochures and annual reports. Students develop contemporary graphic processes and techniques with typography, digital images and experimental media using computer studio class. (Offered fall semester only.) (1 hr. lecture, 4 hrs. studio) Prerequisites: ART130, GRD102 and GRD103. Offered on: E / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Demonstrate the technical skills and visual continuity in design required to prepare multi-paged visual communication.
  2. Demonstrate a high level of understanding with pre-production preparation that includes electronic image editing, page layout using a grid system, type treatment, color separations, printer’s spreads, binding, and print output such as PDF documentation and electronic packaging.
  3. Define the sequential steps involved in problem definition, information gathering, idea finding, solution finding and implementation.
  4. Identify the sources for graphics, images and photographs (clip art, stock photos, promo photos, art direction/shoots) and proper resolution for reproduction.
  5. Identify the components of a creative strategy or design brief and its relationship with the roles of the client, design, and production process.
  6. Synthesize gathered knowledge and demonstrate skills with the creative problem-solving process.
  7. Analyze the relationship between editorial content, form and style in the design of publications.
  8. Identify the basic principles of copyright law as it applies to graphic designers and illustrators.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Emphasizes advanced graphic design problems requiring thought processes behind all forms of visual communications. All problems require understanding and evaluating information, learning value of research, and accurately creating communication solutions. Structured to expand student production skills, complement portfolio development goals, and prepare students for entry into world of graphic design. (offered spring semester only) (1 hr. lecture, 4 hrs. studio) Prerequisite: GRD201 or permission of Chair/Academic Dean. Offered on: E / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Operate a work environment that successfully demonstrates file management and effective communication with a client.
  2. Demonstrate self-evaluation in project direction.
  3. Process original information within a specified time limit and produce results using a creative risk.
  4. Articulate a graphic message in a form of persuasion or information to express the client’s point of view.
  5. Unify a series of related messages through a visual language system, format and structure.
  6. Analyze and develop both typographic and object based imagery with regard to design principles.
  7. Demonstrate mastery knowledge of image generation, expressive typography, system unification, sequencing, and hierarchy of information.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: First course in a two-course sequence concentrating on the design and production of client websites using industry-standard markup languages. Emphasis placed on the understanding of web-design fundamentals using electronic typography and image-making to communicate a visual message. (1 hr. lecture, 4 hrs. studio) Prerequisite: ART130, GRD102 and GRD103. Offered on: E / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Identify the structure of building a framework and preparing graphic content for a successful web design.
  2. Demonstrate ability to construct different navigational structures.
  3. Recognize methods to review and analyze changes in technology as it relates to designing for new media.
  4. Construct a web design solution exhibits a navigable method for a viewer to interact visually.
  5. Practice site management skills of saving, importing, exporting, converting and preparing content for web-based media.
  6. Exhibit skill in the use of the tools for the creation of web-based information.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Second course in a two-course sequence concentrating on the design and production of client websites using industry-standard markup languages. Builds upon web-design knowledge, skills and abilities obtained in GRD203. (offered spring semester only) (1 hr. lecture, 4 hrs. studio) Prerequisite: GRD203 or permission of Chair/Academic Dean. Offered on E / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. recognize methods to review and analysis changes in technology as it relates to designing for new media.
  2. identify the structure of building a framework and preparing graphic content for a successful web media project.
  3. demonstrate the ability to assemble visual messages and graphic images in a narrative form for a comprehensive and well-managed presentation.

CourseInventory.CourseLongTitle: Graphic Design Portfolio Preparation and Assessment
CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Concentrates on completion of student's portfolio of work suitable for entry into the graphic design profession. Instructors work with individual students as both mentor and advisor. Students must be in their final semester of Graphic Design curriculum. (Offered spring semester only.) Prerequisites: GRD201 and GRD203. Corequisites: GRD202 and GRD204. Offered on: E / 1 cr. hr.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Identify and document strengths and weaknesses in personal graphic design solutions to polish for final presentation.
  2. Demonstrate a command of graphic design terminology and historical design during participation in group and individual critiques of current and past projects.
  3. Distinguish specific focus toward professional or educational goals in the graphic design industry.
  4. Plan strong sequence of design solutions to enhance final presentation.
  5. Construct and demonstrate a body of work that reflects creativity, technical skills, design principles and appropriateness for industry application.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Survey of history and technology used to make visual communication from prehistoric times to the present.
