Lectures, presentations, written research and studio projects introduce students to important creative designers and innovations that have shaped visual communication. Note: Fulfills SUNY General Education Requirement for The Arts. Prerequisite: ENG 101. Offered on: E / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Evaluate influences and identify key technological contributions to graphic design history.
  2. Develop a critical vocabulary to analyze, write, and discuss graphic design.
  3. Articulate the relationships between graphic design and world history to enhance local and global engagement.
  4. Identify the impact of social, cultural, and economic developments in graphic design history.
  5. Use research and techniques to create historical graphic design projects and write complimentary research papers.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Emphasis on creative theme development of strong concepts to communicate persuasively, effectively integrating color, type and image in multi-faceted projects. (offered fall semester only) (1 hr. lecture, 4 hrs. studio) Prerequisites: ART130 and GRD103 with a grade of C or better. Offered on: E / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Produce original designs using research, concept development, color theory, and typography through submission of written ideas, sketches, project drafts, and final products.
  2. Articulate a persuasive graphic message in a form of uniquely stylized visuals to captivate a desired target audience and express a specific point of view.
  3. Demonstrate an understanding of historical design influences.
  4. Unify a series of related messages or ideas through the development of a cohesive design system and grid structure.
  5. Demonstrate a technical knowledge of creative image generation, expressive typography and hierarchy of information design.
  6. Reflect critically about the relationship form, content, and meaning in visual communication.
  7. Professionally present work to an audience.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Emphasizes visual problem-solving and processing from research to pre-press to final production of print and digital publications. (offered spring semester only) (1 hr. lecture, 4 hrs. studio) Prerequisites: GRD211 with a grade of C or higher. Offered on: E / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Use grid systems for creating visual relationships between text and images.
  2. Demonstrate the technical skills and design principles required to create visual continuity with a multiple page publication.
  3. Demonstrate typographical skills with an emphasis on headings, subheadings, paragraph headings, linked text callouts, folios, and captions.
  4. Understand and practice with pre-production methods that includes electronic image editing, color modes, document layout, font management.
  5. Practice export and package for print and electronic distribution.
  6. Professionally present work to an audience.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Special and current topics in graphic design may be available. See "Class Schedule Search" for a complete listing each term. Offered on: A-E-G / 3-4 cr. hrs.
Independent study courses in graphic design may be available. See the online catalog for a complete listing or contact academic chair. Offered on: A-E-G / 1-4 cr. hrs.

Survey of principal forces that have shaped European civilization from antiquity to 1715. Notes: (1) Credit given for either HIS101 or IND101, but not both. (2) Fulfills SUNY General Education Requirement for Social Sciences and Western Civilization. Prerequisite: RDG099 or ESL012 or equivalent. Offered on: A-E-G / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Demonstrate an understanding of the larger political, social, intellectual and cultural issues and themes that have contributed to shaping the Western world up to 1715.
  2. Demonstrate critical understanding of a selection of primary sources.
  3. Demonstrate familiarity with different interpretations of the past.
  4. Express his/her own interpretations of the past.
  5. Practice his/her writing, thinking, and comprehension skills in tests and reading and writing assignments.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Survey of ideas, politics and economies that influenced European civilization since 1715. Notes: (1) Credit given for either HIS102 or IND102, but not both. (2) Fulfills SUNY General Education Requirement for Social Sciences and Western Civilization. Prerequisite: RDG099 or ESL012 or equivalent. Offered on: A-E-G / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Demonstrate an understanding of the larger political, social, intellectual and cultural issues and themes that have contributed to shaping the Western world since 1715.
  2. Demonstrate critical understanding of a selection of primary sources.
  3. Demonstrate familiarity with different interpretations of the past.
  4. Express his/her own interpretations of the past. 5. Practice his/her writing, thinking, and comprehension skills in tests and reading and writing assignments.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Survey of American history from its colonial beginnings through the Civil War. Topics include origin and development of American ideals, American Revolution and constitution, westward expansion and Jacksonian Democracy, social and economic changes in the mid-19th century, slavery and the Civil War. Note: Fulfills SUNY General Education Requirement for Social Sciences and American History. Prerequisite: RDG099 or ESL012 or equivalent. Offered on: A-E-G / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Demonstrate an understanding of the larger political, social, intellectual and cultural issues and themes that have contributed to shaping the United States up to 1877.
  2. Demonstrate critical understanding of a selection of primary sources.
  3. Demonstrate familiarity with different interpretations of the past.
  4. Express his/her own interpretations of the past.
  5. Practice his/her writing, thinking, and comprehension skills in tests and reading and writing assignments.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Survey of American history from mid-19th century to the present. Topics include impact of industrialism, development of America as a world power, increased role of federal government, and present state of American society. Note: Fulfills SUNY General Education Requirement for Social Sciences and American History. Prerequisite: RDG099 or ESL012 or equivalent. Offered on: A-E-G / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Demonstrate an understanding of the larger political, social, intellectual and cultural issues and themes that have contributed to shaping the United States since 1877.
  2. Demonstrate critical understanding of a selection of primary sources.
  3. Demonstrate familiarity with different interpretations of the past.
  4. Express his/her own interpretations of the past.
  5. Practice his/her writing, thinking, and comprehension skills in tests and reading and writing assignments.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Analysis of the part that women played in American history from Colonial period to the present. Emphasis on social, political and religious attitudes toward women; status of women; influence of specific women; female involvement in important movements and organizations, etc. Note: Fulfills SUNY General Education Requirement for American History. No prerequisite. Offered on: A-E / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Demonstrate an understanding of the many roles that women have played in American history.
  2. Demonstrate critical understanding of a selection of primary sources.
  3. Demonstrate familiarity with different interpretations of the past.
  4. Express his/her own interpretations of the past.
  5. Practice his/her writing, thinking, and comprehension skills in tests and reading and writing assignments.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Major events, personalities and factors shaping development of Long Island from pre-Columbian past to present. Covers historical highlights in Nassau and Suffolk Counties in general and examines local towns and their contributions. Also provides background for present and prospective teachers wishing to prepare themselves for state education department's directive that elementary schools teach local history. Note: Fulfills SUNY General Education Requirement for American History. No prerequisite. Offered on: A-E-G / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Demonstrate an understanding of the larger political, social, intellectual and cultural issues and themes that have contributed to shaping the history of Long Island.
  2. Demonstrate critical understanding of a selection of primary sources.
  3. Demonstrate familiarity with different interpretations of the past.
  4. Express his/her own interpretations of the past.
  5. Practice his/her own writing, thinking, and comprehension skills in tests and reading and writing assignments.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Study of major developments in world history from World War II to the present. Issues of war, population, the environment and the international economy are analyzed. Note: Fulfills SUNY General Education Requirement for Social Sciences, Western Civilization and Other World Civilizations. No prerequisite. Offered on: A-E-G / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Demonstrate an understanding of the larger political, social, intellectual and cultural issues and themes that have contributed to shaping the history of the world since 1945.
  2. Demonstrate critical understanding of a selection of primary sources.
  3. Demonstrate familiarity with different interpretations of the past.
  4. Express his/her own interpretations of the past.
  5. Practice his/her writing, thinking, and comprehension skills in tests and reading and writing assignments.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: A survey of the Iberian conquest and colonization of Latin America through the 19th century wars for independence. This course examines the colonial societies which emerged through the interaction of Europeans, Native Americans, and Africans in the New World. Areas of emphasis will include an examination of pre-Columbian Civilizations, the Iberian conquest, the establishment of a new, cross-cultural society, and the break between Spanish America and Spain in the early 19th century. Note: Fulfills SUNY General Education Requirement for Social Sciences, Western Civilization and Other World Civilizations. No prerequisite. Offered on: E/ 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Explain the significance of the political, social, and military interactions between Iberian explorers and conquerors and the indigenous peoples of the Americas in the 15th and 16th centuries.
  2. Identify how European colonists settled Latin America in the 16th century and explain the role played by imperial and religious institutions in the colonization effort.
  3. Describe the structure of European colonial societies in Latin America, including the role of women, indigenous peoples, and Afro-Latinos in these societies.
  4. Explain the mercantile significance of the Latin American colonies in the Spanish and Portuguese Empires and identity how European conflicts affected political and economic life in the colonies.
  5. Identify how the Napoleonic Wars of the early 19thcentury led to the rise of independence movements in colonial Latin America and explain the consequences of independence for ethnic European and indigenous populations.
  6. Analytically interpret primary source documents from the pre-colonial period though the beginning of the 19th century.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Survey of major intellectual and cultural achievements of the world's great non-European civilizations. Stresses global integration and the need to understand the unique beliefs and contributions of the many different human communities that have given shape to our present-day world civilization. Note: Fulfills SUNY General Education Requirement for Other World Civilizations. No prerequisite. Offered on: A-E-G / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Demonstrate an understanding of the major intellectual and cultural achievements of the world’s great non-European civilizations.
  2. Demonstrate critical understanding of a selection of primary sources.
  3. Demonstrate familiarity with different interpretations of the past.
  4. Express his/her own interpretations of the past.
  5. Practice his/her writing, thinking and comprehension skills in tests and reading and writing assignments.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Survey of historical, geographic, cultural and economic forces and features influencing people and policies of China and Japan. Special emphasis on contemporary problems of Far East. Note: Fulfills SUNY General Education Requirement for Other World Civilizations. No prerequisite. Offered on: A-E-G / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Demonstrate an understanding of the historical, geographic, cultural and economic forces and features influencing people and policies of China and Japan.
  2. Demonstrate critical understanding of a selection of primary sources.
  3. Demonstrate familiarity with different interpretations of the past.
  4. Express his/her own interpretations of the past.
  5. Practice his/her writing, thinking, and comprehension skills in tests and reading and writing assignments.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Origins, development and impact of major religions of the contemporary world: Hinduism, Buddhism, Confucianism, Taoism, Shinto, Judaism, Christianity and Islam. Main beliefs and practices of these religions are analyzed in relation to the social, economic, political and cultural background of each population. Note: Fulfills SUNY General Education Requirement for Other World Civilizations. No prerequisite. Offered on: A-E-G / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Demonstrate an understanding of the origins, development and impact of the major religions of the contemporary world: Hinduism, Buddhism, Confucianism, Taoism, Shinto, Judaism, Christianity, and Islam.
  2. Demonstrate critical understanding of a selection of primary sources.
  3. Demonstrate familiarity with different interpretations of the past.
  4. Express his/her own interpretations of the past.
  5. Practice his/her writing, thinking, and comprehension skills in tests and reading and writing assignments.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Medieval Europe focuses on the history of Western Europe from the breakup of the Roman Empire to the 15th century (476-1475). It emphasizes the rise of kings and kingdoms, intellectual and philosophical movements, the development of technology, the lasting influence of religious persons, beliefs, and movements, as well as the political, social, and environmental setbacks that factored heavily into medieval life. Emphasis is on both historiographical debate and historical development which led to the creation of Western Europe as a distinct cultural entity. Note: Fulfills SUNY General Education Requirement for Social Sciences and Western Civilization. Prerequisite: HIS101 or permission of Chair/Academic Dean. Offered on: A-E-G / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Demonstrate an understanding of Western Europe from breakup of the Roman Empire to the 15th century (476-1475).
  2. Demonstrate critical understanding of a selection of primary sources.
  3. Demonstrate familiarity with different interpretations of the past.
  4. Better express their own interpretations of the past.
  5. Use improved critical thinking skills in in-class discussions and writing assignments.
  6. Use improved writing skills.

CourseInventory.CourseLongTitle: The Past in Pictures: U.S. History through Film
CourseInventory.CourseDescription: This course examines key events in U.S. history by comparing and contrasting historical representations in feature films and historical texts. Students will learn how movies interpret the past and simultaneously reflect the cultural and social conflicts of the times in which they were made. The events examined may include the Civil War and Reconstruction; Native Americans and the West; the U.S. labor movement; World War II and the Cold War. Note: Fulfills SUNY General Education Requirement for Social Sciences and American History. (3 hrs. lecture) Prerequisite: Any 100 level HIS survey course including HIS101, HIS102, HIS103, or HIS104. Offered on: G / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Demonstrate an understanding of the larger political, social, intellectual and cultural issues and themes that have shaped modern American history, including the Civil War, Reconstruction, Native Americans and the West, the U.S. labor movement, World War II and the Cold War.
  2. Develop a critical understanding of the representation of historical events through film.
  3. Analyze and evaluate cinematic representations of history in comparison to various secondary and primary sources of U.S. history.
  4. Apply critical thinking and comprehension skills in writing.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Special and current topics in History may be available. See "Class Schedule Search" for a complete listing each term. Offered on: A-E-G / 3 cr. hrs.

Honors special topics in History may be available for Honors students as well as those who have received permission from campus Honors Program Coordinator. See "Class Schedule Search" for a complete listing each term. Offered on: A-E-G / 3-4 cr. hrs.
Independent study courses in history may be available. See the online catalog for a complete listing or contact academic chair. Offered on: A-E-G / 1-4 cr. hrs.

This course will introduce the students to the Health Care Delivery system, the role of the electronic health record and health informatics as it relates to data content, format and management. The National Health Information Infrastructure and the role of the Health Information Management professional will be presented. (Offered fall semester only.) Prerequisite: BIO138 and MED111. Offered on: G / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Discuss the factors affecting health care delivery in the United States.
  2. Explain the general structure and function of a hospital including governing and committee structures.
  3. Identify the role of the Health Information professional.
  4. Describe the purpose, content and format of the medical record.
  5. Describe the difference between primary and secondary health records and give examples.
  6. Perform concurrent and retrospective quantitative, qualitative, and statistical analysis.
  7. Set up numbering and filing systems.
  8. Explain the retention requirements for health information.
  9. Develop policy and procedures for work flow.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Examines the content and structure, maintenance, storage and security of the electronic health record and the personal health record. Standards and guidelines that refer to the interoperability, networks and internet will be discussed. (Offered fall semester only.) Corequisite: HIT114. Offered on: G / 4 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Examine the role of technology on the Health Information Management Department.
  2. Discuss the information systems including database architecture and design where patient related data is collected and stored including electronic or imaging technology for data/record storage.
  3. Develop policies and procedures to ensure data accuracy and data integrity.
  4. Review medical records and evaluate the documentation in paper records and the data elements in the electronic health records for completeness, accuracy and consistency of data and data sources.
  5. Explain the purpose and role of healthcare data sets.
  6. Discuss the security measures to protect electronic health information.
  7. Retrieve patient related data from HIM computerized database.
  8. Apply policies and procedures for the use of networks, internet/intranets, to facilitate the EHR, PHR, HIE and RHIO’s.
  9. Prepare for participation in planning, design, selection, implementation, integration, testing, evaluation and support for organization wide information systems.

CourseInventory.CourseLongTitle: Privacy and Security of the Electronic Health Record
CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Students will examine the legal proceedings; privacy and security regulations; and the technology that will secure the confidentiality of the electronic health record (EHR) and personal health record (PHR). HIPAA, network security, interoperability and regional health information organizations (RHIO) will be presented. (Offered spring semester only.) Prerequisite: HIT117. Offered on: G / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Describe the structure of the American legal system.
  2. Define court and legal practices.
  3. Explain principles regarding confidentiality and release of information.
  4. Define HIPAA Privacy and Security Regulations.
  5. Demonstrate familiarity with concepts such as malpractice and negligence.
  6. Discuss landmark decisions regarding legal aspects of health information.
  7. Distinguish between federal and state laws as they apply to the Electronic Health Record

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Provides students with knowledge of disease processes as documented by clinicians. Students study and interpret laboratory values and pharmaceutical information appearing in the medical record. (Offered fall semester only.)Prerequisite: BIO138 and MED111. Offered on: G / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Describe disease processes and symptoms of the major organs.
  2. Review medical records and explain the lab values and medications used to treat the condition.
  3. Define pathological and abnormal conditions of the body systems.
  4. Identify lab values and medication associated with diseases.

CourseInventory.CourseShortTitle: Reg Issues w/ Elect Health Rec
CourseInventory.CourseLongTitle: Regulatory Issues with Electronic Health Record
CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Enhances information acquired in HIT114. Students retrieve and prepare health statistics, learn how to graphically display health data, and examine various computer applications (hardware and software for health information) that relate to various functions within health care. (Offered spring semester only.) Prerequisite: HIT114 with C grade or higher. Corequisite: MAT103. Offered on G / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Retrieve health data from various computer applications and comply with changing regulations.
  2. Prepare graphic presentations of data using bar graphs, pie diagrams, and tables.
  3. Calculate and interpret healthcare statistics, occupancy rates and length of stay reports.
  4. Prepare reports for reporting vital statistics to state agencies. (Birth and death statistics)
  5. Apply Institutional Review Board (IRB) policies and procedures.
  6. Explain the regulations associated with the reimbursement/payment systems used in healthcare.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Introduction to medical nomenclatures and diagnostic classification systems and relationship of coding to reimbursement. Emphasis will be on inpatient coding of diagnoses and procedures. Students code utilizing medical and practice exercises. (Offered fall semester only.) Corequisite: HIT220. Offered on: G / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Define, identify and list all coding conventions, principal diagnoses, comorbid conditions, principal procedure, and secondary procedures documented in the medical record.
  2. Explain the importance of the ICD-9-CM coding and its application to the Hospital Reimbursement System.
  3. Analyze the medical record and properly sequence the ICD-9-CM code.
  4. Demonstrate the ability to read a medical record and determine the appropriate ICD-9-CM code.
  5. Define the various classification systems including ICD-10-CM and distinguish the differences between a medical vocabulary (SNOMED) and a classification.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Focuses on applying advanced coding techniques. Students are taught CPT-4 coding. Present forms of reimbursement and importance of new legislation emphasized. (Offered spring semester only.) Prerequisite: HIT235 with C grade or higher. Offered on: G / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Code records using CPT-4 accurately according to coding guidelines.
  2. Code complex records accurately using appropriate ICD9CM coding guidelines.
  3. Identify the reimbursement methodologies in inpatient and outpatient settings.
  4. Review legislation affecting all payer reimbursement.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Develops skills through clinical experience in various affiliated health care settings. Students attend a weekly on-campus seminar during clinical experience to discuss clinical experience and review completed fieldwork. (Offered spring semester only.) (1.5 hrs. seminar, 4.5 hrs. clinical) Prerequisite: HIT235 with C grade or higher. Offered on: G / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Apply knowledge and skill to department activities in various healthcare settings.
  2. Demonstrate competency on projects as indicated by the preceptor’s signature.
  3. Evaluate the management of the Health Information Department.
  4. Determine status of requests for Release of Information.
  5. Prepare a Performance Improvement study on delinquent medical records.
  6. Prepare a report on organization wide guidelines on documentation.
  7. Code medical records.

CourseInventory.CourseLongTitle: Management Issues in the Electronic Health Record Environment
CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Students will explore the functions of management such as human resources, financial and physical resources, and performance improvement as it relates to managing a health information management environment where the electronic health record is being developed. (Offered spring semester only.) Prerequisite: HIT235 with C grade or higher. Offered on: G / 4 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Explain the role of the supervisor, develop job descriptions, and perform interviews.
  2. Develop concept of teams and team building.
  3. Formulate and conduct an in-service education program.
  4. Plan a work environment for the electronic health record that will accommodate employees and comply with regulatory requirements.
  5. Communicate the changes in the healthcare environment that directly impacts the health information department, such as, reimbursement, correct coding initiative, HIPAA, cancer registry, corporate compliance.
  6. Apply methods and techniques to improve and monitor performance.
  7. Develop a resource allocation plan.
  8. Define the relationship between the medical staff committees and hospital-wide performance improvement.
  9. Explain the development of risk management and its importance to the healthcare facility.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Special and current topics in Health Information Technology/Medical Records may be available. See "Class Schedule Search" for a complete listing each term. Offered on: A-E-G / 3-4 cr. hrs.

The hospitality industry encompasses the entire "away from home market." It is composed of eating, lodging, travel, recreation, and gaming. These diverse businesses are all related in their history, development, and channels of distribution. This course will provide a framework for students to pursue individual segments of this multi-faceted industry. (Offered fall semester only.) No prerequisite. Offered on: E / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Discuss career opportunities in the food service, lodging and tourism industries.
  2. Understand the fundamentals of management and planning in the hospitality industry.
  3. Create a resume for use in the hospitality industry.
  4. Do research using the college’s electronic data bases.
  5. Communicate more effectively with faculty, classmates and other college officials.
  6. Identify and utilize campus and college resources, develop personal time management and study skills and successfully become a part of the college environment.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: This course concentrates on presenting the principles and practices necessary to effectively perform in a management position in the food service industry. The flow of food through a commerical food-service operation including purchasing, receiving, storing, fabrication, production, and service are examined. Upon successful completion of this course, the student will be able to understand basic cooking principles and apply them through the standardized recipe and menu. The development of effective and efficient managerial skills for the commerical or institutional kitchen will be presented and practiced. (3 hrs. lecture, 3 hrs. laboratory) Prerequisite: CUL111. Offered on: E / 4 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. The HACCP approach to sanitation with regard to the professional kitchen and chef.
  2. Different methods of food preparation, their common seasonings and flavorings.
  3. Components of a standardized recipe, its measurements, portion control, food costing, yield tests and conversion methods.
  4. Different types of menus, nutritional concerns, and methods of cutting foods.
  5. Procedures for preparing stocks, sauces, and soups.
  6. The cooking methods of fresh vegetables.
  7. The cooking methods of grains, legumes & potatoes dishes.
  8. Preparation methods of various poultry, meats & fish.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: The hotel/restaurant/tourism business is marketing. It is essential to determine what customers want and provide it to them when they want it. Furthermore, it must be all wrapped up in a beautiful package at a reasonable price. Students will learn the intangible nature of hospitality products and the importance of positioning, targeting, and image development. No prerequisite. Offered on: E / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Describe and analyze marketing, its function, action plans and control procedures.
  2. Analyze case studies and apply this analysis to current problems facing the industry.
  3. Explain how supply and demand relates to pricing.
  4. Will be able to distinguish between strategic and tactical operational planning.
  5. Distinguish between traditional marketing concepts and nontraditional marketing concepts.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Concentrates on the knowledge a manager needs to understand and supervise the "hardware" of the hospitality industry. Food service equipment and kitchen layout are covered along with heating, cooling, refrigeration, electrical, and transportation systems. Security systems and fire safety are also stressed. Prerequisite: HRM105. Offered on: E / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Identify principles of environmental/energy management, and inventory management.
  2. Describe the processes of guestroom and public space cleaning.
  3. Identify the role of Facilities Management.
  4. Summarize sustainability management issues.
  5. Describe important elements in hotel facility systems.
  6. Discuss the role of loss prevention in the lodging industry.
  7. Identify security procedures covering guest concerns.
  8. Delineate appropriate responsibilities in emergency situations, including handling the media.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Functions of front-office management and housekeeping as they are related to organization, control, and operation. Emphasis on registration, reservations, service, seasonal projections, ledger, billing, interior design, furnishings, purchasing, inventory, control, schedules, and sanitation. (Offered spring semester only.) Prerequisite: HRM105. Offered on: E / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. List hotel categories based on product/service offerings.
  2. Classify types of hotel guests and identify their buying influences.
  3. Define the importance of the front office and telecommunications within the total hotel.
  4. Explain and differentiate types of Front Office and Property Management Systems.
  5. Develop a working knowledge of reservations, registration, and account settlement.
  6. Demonstrate knowledge and understanding of forecasting, budgeting, and room rates.
  7. Define principles of yield management.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: This course introduces the hospitality student to the important area of group businesses. Topics to be covered include corporate meeting planning, exposition sales and management, trade shows, the role of the hotel sales office, group marketing, convention services, and the role of intermediaries in sales and meeting management. (Offered spring semester only.) Prerequisite: HRM120. Offered on: E / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. List and describe hotel revenue sources.
  2. Analyze the profit impact of room sales, restaurant sales, and catering sales.
  3. Define Revpar and analyze a STAR report.
  4. Explain and differentiate the types of positions in a Hotel Organizational Chart.
  5. Describe and compare/contrast duties of each position in a hotel sales office.
  6. List and explain the differences of each hotel sales market segment.
  7. Demonstrate understanding of yield management principles through real-world computations and resulting decisions.
  8. Define the sales process and participate in a live example.

CourseInventory.CourseLongTitle: Hotel and Resort Management Internship/Cooperative Education
CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Supervised on-the-job training in an establishment representative of the hospitality industry. Students work 150 hours in their placement, attend weekly on-campus seminar, and maintain a journal. Taken during the summer semester, after completion of first and second semester program requirements. Registration in this course requires that students purchase liability insurance through the college. Prerequisite: CUL112, HRM105 and HRM210. Offered on: E / 4 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Further their theoretical and practical skills and apply them to a real work environment.
  2. Identify areas of responsibility in a working environment.
  3. Develop their oral and written skills by working with industry professionals.
  4. Promote critical thinking by problem solving on- the- job and classroom discussions.
  5. Promote creativity through their work-related experience and classroom discussions.
  6. Analyze own and peers workplace situations to optimal conclusions.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: The student will be required to develop a boutique hotel as a faculty-supervised project. The project will include a concept restaurant, a front-office reservation area, and a room-amenity package. The student's ability to integrate each area of learned understanding will be defined by the project and implemented by the student using written and oral assessment methods. Prerequisite: CUL112, CUL113, CUL116, CUL132, HRM105, HRM120, HRM205, and HRM210. Offered on: E / 2 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Identify trends and discuss relevant issues that face our hospitality industry.
  2. Develop a restaurant or hotel / Restaurant project from concept inception through opening day.
  3. Develop a market analysis of their proposed location, competition and customer demographics as it relates to their concept.
  4. Develop and perform an operating statement based on criteria established as part of the project.
  5. Research and interpret State Liquor Licensing, Health Department requirements, building department codes and music licensing agreements as it applies to their concept.
  6. Develop a workable lunch and dinner menu based on their concept using correct design elements, pricing and culinary terminology.
  7. Develop written recipes, and a purchase order list of ingredients based on their menu.
  8. Interpret portion sizes correctly and understand the schematics of plate presentation.
  9. Develop a bar and restaurant layout based on their concept.
  10. Develop a bar equipment specification list.
  11. Develop staffing requirements, job specifications and payroll costs as they relate to their project.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Basic concepts, principles, attitudes and information regarding health for students within framework of their individual needs. Designed so that students can recognize and utilize those factors which contribute to creation and maintenance of a healthy lifestyle. No prerequisite. Offered on: A-E-G / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Identify and describe the information and practices which promote a high quality of healthful living.
  2. Recognize and describe their potential for maximum health within the framework of their own needs.
  3. Recognize, describe and analyze the health issues that challenge their health level today.
  4. Recognize, describe and evaluate their role in creating a healthy life style.
  5. Recognize and describe current concepts and trends that pertain to their personal and holistic health.
  6. Objectively describe, analyze, and evaluate key health factors.
  7. Describe and demonstrate methods of positive change in their personal health behavior.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Ideal for persons confused about nutritional claims advertised in media. Covers identification of reliable sources of nutrition information and overview of basic nutrition principles. Discusses popular and controversial nutrition topics such as immunity, megavitamin therapy, sports nutrition, antioxidants, weight control diets and vegetarianism. Prerequisite: No prerequisite. May be substituted for DTE101 for students transferring into Dietetic Technician curriculum. Offered on: A-E-G / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Distinguish between nutrition information based upon scientific research vs. quackery.
  2. Describe the role of nutrition and exercise in personal health management and apply those principles to one's own lifestyle.
  3. Describe the processes of digestion, absorption and metabolism and explain the roles of these systems in the nutritive process.
  4. Identify various nutrients and "non-nutrients" and evaluate their proposed functions in the body.
  5. Describe factors that affect energy balance, obesity and eating disorders and analyze them in terms of the weight management dilemma in the U.S. today.
  6. Evaluate the quality of their own diets and exercise regimens and describe realistic strategies to improve their nutritional health and lifestyles.
  7. Research topics of personal interest in reliable nutrition publications and evaluate those findings in relation to personal and public health.
  8. Access and utilize books, videos, journals, the internet and other sources of information on current topics in nutrition.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Interdisciplinary course offered by departments of Biology and Health Careers. Helps students understand human sexual functioning as an integrated phenomenon related to biology, emotions, motivation, personality and social interaction. A diversity of material is presented to assist students in understanding biopsychosocial aspects of sexuality. Satisfies a liberal arts and sciences, social sciences or unrestricted elective requirement, but not as a mathematics/science elective requirement. Credit given for either PSY247 or HSC111 but not both. Note: Fulfills SUNY General Education Requirement for Social Sciences. No prerequisite. Offered on: A-E / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Participate in discussions of the different aspects of human sexuality in an open and frank manner using correct terminology.
  2. Describe the structure and function of the reproductive system, and relate the roles of the nervous and endocrine systems to reproductive functioning and human sexuality.
  3. Describe the typical progression of human sexuality through the life cycle, and identify and recognize the continuing need for sexual expression.
  4. Describe the role of sexuality in reproduction, including conception and pregnancy, as well as contraception, and relate the impact of various developmental phenomena to sexuality.
  5. Demonstrate an understanding of one’s feelings and values in the area of human sexuality.
  6. Identify healthy attitudes towards human sexuality and recognize myths and misinformation.
  7. Describe the symptoms and causes of sexually transmitted diseases and their impact on sexual activity.
  8. Develop an awareness of the critical situation of AIDS on Long Island and identify symptoms of HIV infection, as well as, strategies for avoiding exposure and infection.
  9. Recognize human sexuality as an integrated phenomenon related to biology, emotions, motivation, personality development, business marketing, societal interactions, and role definition in families and culture.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Prevention and treatment of common emergency situations. Advanced First Aid techniques are utilized. Successful completion of this course qualifies the student for an Advanced First Aid Certificate and a Professional Rescuer/ Healthcare Provider Certificate through the National Safety Council, AHA, ARC or equivalent national training program. No prerequisite. Offered on: A-E-G / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Explain how the Emergency Medical Services (EMS) system works and the citizen responder’s role in the EMS system, including how and when to call EMS personnel.
  2. Identify the signs and symptoms of breathing emergencies, including choking, and demonstrate (on a manikin) how to provide rescue breathing and first aid for choking for adults, children and infants.
  3. Identify the major risk factors for cardiovascular disease, and describe how to minimize them.
  4. Recognize the signs and symptoms of a possible heart attack, and describe how to care for someone who is experiencing persistent chest pain.
  5. Identify the signs of cardiac arrest and demonstrate (on a manikin) how to provide adult, child and infant cardiopulmonary resuscitation until EMS personnel arrive.
  6. Explain the importance of early defibrillation and demonstrate (on a manikin) how to operate a semi-automatic defibrillator.
  7. Identify the signs and symptoms of life threatening bleeding and demonstrate (on a manikin and a programmed patient) how to control it.
  8. Identify the signs and symptoms of shock and describe and demonstrate (on a manikin and a programmed patient) how to minimize its effect.
  9. Identify the signs and symptoms of various soft tissue injuries and demonstrate (on a manikin and a programmed patient) how to care for them.
  10. Identify the signs and symptoms of various musculoskeletal injuries and demonstrate (on a manikin and a programmed patient) how to care for them.
  11. Identify the signs and symptoms of sudden illness, including fainting, seizures, strokes, diabetic emergencies, poisoning, bites and stings, substance abuse and misuse and heat and cold emergencies, and describe how to care for them.
  12. Demonstrate (on an obstetrical manikin) the procedure for assisting in the delivery of a baby and caring for the mother and the newborn.
  13. Describe when and how to move a victim in an emergency situation

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Introduction to concepts of behavior related to group activity and a study of sociometric techniques for the purpose of developing skill in interpersonal relationships within the health team. Recommended for students contemplating possibility of entering a health-oriented profession and/or students interested in health issues. Note: This course does not satisfy social sciences, humanities or liberal arts and sciences elective requirements. (3 hrs. lecture) No prerequisite. Offered on: A-E-G / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Recognize and identify how an individual’s feelings and behavior influence group process.
  2. Recognize various types of interaction within the group and how this affects the group process.
  3. Recognize and identify the principles of effective participation in a group.
  4. Recognize and identify the functions and behaviors necessary for small group effectiveness.
  5. Recognize and identify communication processes among people with a particular focus on health and human services.
  6. Identify and participate in various decision-making procedures pertinent to group problem solving.
  7. Recognize and identify the strategies for conflict management utilized within the profession of health and helping environments.
  8. Recognize and identify the different leadership functions and behaviors necessary for leadership in the helping professions.
  9. Through the development of self-awareness and sensitivity to group process, begin to evaluate their own participation in a group in terms of the above concepts.
  10. Through the development of self-awareness and sensitivity to group process, begin to use self more effectively toward accomplishment of group goals.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Covers all techniques of emergency medical care presently considered within the responsibilities of the Emergency Medical Technician-Basic. Emphasizes development of student skills in recognition of symptoms of illnesses and injuries and proper procedures of emergency care. Successful completion of this course leads to New York State certification as an Emergency Medical Technician-Basic. Registration in HSC126 requires students to purchase liability insurance through the College and complete a thorough physical examination with their own physician at their own cost (including laboratory work) as required by the College health service. (5 hrs. lecture, 5 hrs. laboratory, 24 hrs. clinical rotation) Notes: (1) The student must be at least 18 years of age prior to the last day of the month in which the course is scheduled to take the New York State Written Certification Examination. (2) All evening HSC126 sections require one full day SATURDAY CLASS, all summer HSC126 sections require one full FRIDAY CLASS, date to be announced first class meeting. No prerequisite. Offered on: A-E-G / 7 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Demonstrate the procedure for evaluation of a patient with suspected respiratory distress, including the evaluation of general appearance, respiratory rate, depth, pulse and lung sounds.
  2. Demonstrate, in the correct sequence, the procedure for opening an obstructed airway.
  3. Demonstrate the procedure for one and two person cardiopulmonary resuscitation on adults, CPR on infants and children and other basic and advanced life support techniques.
  4. Identify the probable cause and signs and symptoms of problems of the central nervous system. Demonstrate the treatment for problems involving the central nervous system.
  5. Demonstrate the techniques for controlling hemorrhage.
  6. Demonstrate the treatment for various types and degrees of burns, including the probable signs and symptoms.
  7. Demonstrate the treatment for problems involving the Musculoskeletal System, including the techniques of immobilization with the traction splint, air splint, rigid splint and frac-pack.
  8. Demonstrate, on an obstetrical manikin, the procedure for the preparation of a woman and delivery of an infant in a cephalic birth.
  9. Demonstrate, on a CPR manikin, the application and operation of a semi-automatic external defibrillator and integrate this skill into the treatment of a cardiac arrest patient.
  10. Demonstrate the appropriate procedure for dealing with emotionally disturbed patients.
  11. Demonstrate the various aspects of basic disentanglement.
  12. Define the overall roles and responsibilities of the EMT in performing both the emergency care and operational aspects of his/her job.
  13. Develop and demonstrate skill in diagnosis and emergency treatment procedures.
  14. Develop and demonstrate skill in the use of care for all equipment required to accomplish his/her job.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Examines range of activities that may occur, and for which rescuers need to be prepared for effective response, at the scene of a vehicle accident where emergency extrication is necessary. No prerequisite. Offered on: A / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Identify, experience and correctly use a wide variety of available tools of vehicle extrication.
  2. Describe, analyze, and evaluate the various designs and functions of new safety technology as it relates to vehicle extrication.
  3. Define the purpose of the rescue life cycle.
  4. Define and describe the term kinematics and its effects on an entrapped patient.
  5. Apply the techniques and concepts of patient extrication on a simulated entrapment.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Special and current topics in Health Careers may be available. See "Class Schedule Search" for a complete listing each term. Offered on: A-E-G / 3-4 cr. hrs.

Literature and film emerge from the most profound of human experiences. In the 20th century, perhaps the most profound of those experiences was the Holocaust. The scope of hatred, deadlines of purpose, and organization of mass murder raise questions which have become more and more disturbing even as we move away from the event. This course examines not only the roots and nature of the Holocaust, but also how internationally known writers and filmmakers have reacted to the event. No prerequisite. Offered on: A-E-G / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Understand and apply relevant concepts, such as good and evil, identity, and prejudice.
  2. Understand the historical roots of Nazism and anti-Semitism.
  3. Understand conditions and developments leading to the Holocaust.
  4. Distinguish between perpetrators, victims, and bystanders.
  5. Understand the world after the Holocaust.
  6. Realize the power of words and ideas.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Analyzes nature of myth and explores dominant themes and archetypes, including gender-based images and roles in the myths of various cultures. These myths, studied in context of today's world, help students develop an increased awareness of the influence of myth on contemporary life. No prerequisite. Offered on: A-E-G / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Understand myth, as distinct from and related to religion, literature, history and science.
  2. Recognize common themes and differences in myths from various cultures.
  3. Understand the importance of gender differences in myth and folklore.
  4. Develop the basic skills of critical analysis.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: This course investigates the notion of gender within its cultural contexts and its relation to sex, sexualities, gender roles and gender identity. By studying women and men as well as their images and representations in the humanities (language, literature, art, music and popular media), this course analyzes various forms of sexism and explores the possibilities for a wide range of genders, sexualities and interpersonal relationships. No prerequisite. Offered on: A-E-G / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Demonstrate an awareness of sexism: what it is, its cultural manifestation, and its implications for humankind.
  2. Explain the diverse theoretical and philosophical perspectives on sex and gender.
  3. Provide a general cultural perspective of how sexism has affected the perception of femininity and masculinity, and the impact this perception has on individuals’ lives.
  4. Recognize that race, ethnicity, geography, and social class also affect these definitions.
  5. Understand that change is possible in many different forms, and identify these changes as represented in the texts that are examined.

CourseInventory.CourseLongTitle: Effect Think: Problem Solving, Reason & Compr
CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Studies mental processes associated with sequential analytical thought. Focus of first part of course is thoughtful introspection. Classroom and text activities entailing verbal reasoning, analogical relationships, predicating patterns, and creative problem solving develop insight and understanding of one¿s own thought processes. Second part of course encourages thoughtful involvement with current controversy. Students learn analytical skills necessary for evaluation of controversial ideas presented from various perspectives in contemporary writing using journal articles, newspaper and magazine articles, editorials and essays. Note: Fulfills SUNY General Education Requirement for Humanities. No prerequisite. Offered on: E / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Demonstrate their ability to identify the various levels of consciousness in their lives.
  2. Through observation, identify how sensation, perception and thinking interact in the acquisition of knowledge.
  3. Differentiate among inferences, assumptions, opinions and facts; and demonstrate how these thinking activities influence perception of reality.
  4. Demonstrate an awareness of the origins of their own viewpoints and recognize the inevitable bias inherent in all knowledge.
  5. Evaluate their own ideas according to pre-established standards (i.e. validity, clarity, purpose, appeal, ethics, etc.), and give reasons and evidence to support their evaluation.

CourseInventory.CourseLongTitle: Developing Creative Imagination in the Arts
CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Theoretical foundation as well as practical experience in approaching problems of communication in literature and visual arts. Studies such areas as form, symbol and narrative meaning within selected historical contexts (e.g., romantic, modern, post-modern) to show how one interprets and gives meaning to creations of artists and writers. Also offers students opportunity to engage intensively in creative problem solving in the arts. Prerequisite: ENG101. Offered on: A-E-G / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Articulate a definition of creativity.
  2. Demonstrate an understanding of the imagination and approaches to tapping creative ability and problem solving.
  3. Apply techniques to help overcome obstacles to creative performance.
  4. Demonstrate an ability to think critically about the arts, and to articulate what is imaginative and creative in various art forms.
  5. Demonstrate an understanding of the techniques and formal elements used in the literary and visual arts, and their use in the creative process.
  6. Articulate the role of the arts in one’s life and in modern culture.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Examines place and image of women within American legal system. Investigates religious influences and philosophical origins of gender differences in the law, with emphasis on issues such as hate crimes, child custody and divorce. No prerequisite. Offered on: A / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Understand the role gender has played and continues to play in the American legal system.
  2. Understand basic legal terms and concepts.
  3. Critically evaluate gender-based laws.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Through an interdisciplinary approach, this course examines contemporary gender differences with respect to health issues and health related problems. Topics to be explored include women’s control over their bodies; women’s position in the health care system; gender differences with respect to illnesses, such as eating disorders, heart disease, breast and ovarian cancers, autoimmune diseases; reproductive technologies; women’s self-esteem and female body image; woman’s role as caretaker; alternative medicines and treatments. No prerequisite. No prerequisite. Offered on: A / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Explain and describe gender differences in dealing with health issues, in particular those specific for women.
  2. Identify instances of sexism within the current health care system by investigating the health-related perception and treatment of women.
  3. Analyze and distinguish specific health issues and options for dealing with them from a gender perspective.
  4. Examine the role of religion, the media, society, and the law for women’s health issues.
  5. Analyze contemporary health issues for women within the context of literature, music, media and popular culture.
  6. Employ tools and techniques of critical analysis and information literacy.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Offers broad spectrum of work opportunities in private sector as well as governmental agencies, under supervision of sponsors selected for their capacity to serve as exemplary gender role models. In addition to six hours per week of field work, students attend a weekly seminar. In this way, they learn to integrate theory and practice and recognize their own potential for change. They examine legal, public and private forces operating in the professions, such as affirmative action, tokenism and harassment. In the process, students develop organizational skills, ability to analyze social structure of the workplace and, above all, to think creatively about their ultimate career goals. Open to women and men who have commitment to equity in workplace. Prerequisite: ENG101 or permission of Chair/Academic Dean. Recommended: Minimum of 12 credit hours. Offered on: A-E / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Demonstrate knowledge of required work ethic and of the standards of the workplace.
  2. Prioritize tasks and accomplish their goals.
  3. Behave in a professional, non-discriminatory way at the workplace.
  4. Demonstrate skills in communication, planning and organization, and working as a team.
  5. Know how to behave in interview situations.
  6. Search a variety of resources (including the internet) to gather information relevant to their career goals.
  7. Understand the academic credentials necessary for their career goals.
  8. Understand and articulate the relation between their personal career goals and the reality of a given job.
  9. Understand the issues/conflicts of the workplace such as gender and ethnic discrimination, sexual harassment, unionism, Affirmative Action, right to privacy, American Disabilities Act, family right to medical leave and tokenism.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Interdisciplinary rotating course, its content varying from semester to semester. No prerequisite. Offered on: A / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Understand the specific role women played within the process of artistic creation.
  2. Understand how literature and art can be used to reflect upon women’s role in culture and society.
  3. Understand the connections between art, literature, and religion.
  4. Understand in what sense women have used literature and art as tool for liberation.
  5. Use literature and artworks in order to understand cultural and historical differences among women.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: This course focuses on works of modern Latina/o writers, including such authors as Oscar Hijuelos, María Irene Fornés and Nilo Cruz (Cuban-American), Julia de Burgos, Miguel Algarín, and Sandra María Esteves (Puerto Rican/Nuyorican), Gloria Anzaldúa and Luis Valdéz (Chicana/o), and Junot Díaz and Julia Alvarez (Dominican-American). Such themes as language, alienation, identity, exile and assimilation, prejudice, cultural and ethnic pride, religion, and family are explored. Note: (1) Fulfills SUNY General Education Requirement for Humanities. (2) Credit given for either ENG218 or HUM218 but not both. Prerequisite: ENG101. Offered on: G / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Develop the ability to read thoughtfully, critically, and creatively and to respond to literature both orally and in writing.
  2. Compare and distinguish between a variety of Latina/o literary voices associated with different genres and countries of origin.
  3. Analyze, discuss, interpret, and reflect on the work of Latina/o writers and their unique status in the United States.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Course introducing African art and culture from non-Western perspective. Emphasis on context within which art is produced. Geographic and historical background to African society. Study of role and function of artist in traditional African culture. Topics include belief systems, concepts of duality, myth, ritual, ancestor worship, 'living art' and art as function. No prerequisite. Offered on: G / 3 cr. hrs.
Special and current topics in Humanities may be available. See the online catalog for a complete listing. Offered on A-E-G / 3 cr. hrs.

Honors special topics in Humanities may be available for Honors students as well as those who have received permission from campus Honors Program Coordinator. See "Class Schedule Search" for a complete listing each term. Offered on: A-E-G / 3-4 cr. hrs.

Survey of historical, social, political and economic influences on social welfare system in United States. Includes examination of prevailing social problems of concern to human service professionals, descriptions of current public welfare programs and their predecessors, and overview of fields of practice in social welfare. Requires 25 hours of volunteer service in local social service agency. Open to all students. Serves as unrestricted, liberal arts or social science elective for students not enrolled in Human Services Program. (offered day and evening in fall semester and evening in spring semester) Note: Fulfills SUNY General Education Requirement for Social Sciences. No prerequisite. Offered on: A-G / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Identify and discuss the significant historical developments influencing the institutions of social welfare. Assessed by examination performance.
  2. Identify and discuss the underlying philosophy, values and structure of social work as a profession. Assessed by examination performance and quality of research paper.
  3. Identify and analyze the responses of the US social welfare system to the issues of poverty and human need. Assessed by examination performance and quality of short essay.
  4. Discuss and analyze the function of public and private agencies in the community and the services these agencies provide the client. Assessed by examination performance and voluntary service/interview report.
  5. Describe and analyze current social work practice or social welfare policy in selected areas of social welfare concern. Assessed by quality of research paper and quality of voluntary service/interview reports.
  6. Identify the current major entitlement programs, their benefits, eligibility criteria and underlying societal sanction. Assessed by examination performance.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Overview of theory and skills integral to the interview as part of the social work process of helping. Includes discussions and demonstrations of stages of the professional helping interview, impact of interviewer attitudes, cross-cultural interviewing, types of social work interviews and general principles of interviewing. Role-play and classroom experiential learning are significant course components. HUS101 must be completed prior to or simultaneously with this course to proceed in the program courses. (offered spring semester only) (2 hrs. lecture, 2 hrs. laboratory) Prerequisite or corequisite: HUS101 with grade of C or better. Offered on: A / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Distinguish between a professional helping interview and a conversation. Assessed by examination.
  2. Appropriately begin and end a helping interview. Assessed by instructor’s observation of role play, written assignments, examination.
  3. Demonstrate the principles of a positive relationship. Assessed by instructor’s observation of role play, written assignments, examination.
  4. Demonstrate empathetic responses to clients. Assessed by instructor’s observation of role play, written assignments, examination.
  5. Appropriately use open and closed questions. Assessed by instructor’s observation of role play, written assignments, examination.
  6. Accurately reflect content and affect. Assessed by instructor’s observation of role play, written assignments, examination.
  7. Effectively use and empathetically respond to silence in the interview. Assessed by instructor’s observation of role play, written assignments, examination.
  8. Appropriately use the skills of exploration and elaboration. Assessed by instructor’s observation of role play, written assignments, examination.
  9. Assess his or her strengths and challenges as an interviewer. Assessed by journal entries, self-analysis of two interviews and final paper.

CourseInventory.CourseLongTitle: Human Services Seminar and Field Practicum I
CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Classroom study in seminar setting along with 140 hours of off-campus field work. Students are placed in human service agency where they engage in intensive supervised work experience. Classroom work emphasizes discussions of field experiences and development of student's role as a human service professional. Explores issues relating to professional ethics and responsibilities, including boundaries and confidentiality along with application of theories of helping. Students enrolling in this course are automatically charged the liability insurance fee. Field work component is completed primarily during day hours. Enrollment requires permission of instructor and subsmission of preplacement forms and essay. (offered fall semester only) (3 hrs. seminar, 8 hrs. laboratory totaling 140 field hrs.) Prerequisite: Admission to Human Services curriculum and grade of C or better in HUS101 and HUS103. Corequisite: HUS205. Offered on: A / 5 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Identify the functions of his/her field site agency and the services this agency offers to clients. Assessed through workbook assignments, observations by the site supervisor, “First Reflections” paper.
  2. Identify his/her role as a human services professional in this agency and to demonstrate a beginning level of skill in carrying out this role. Assessed through “My Beginning to be a Helping Professional” essay, observations by site supervisor, “First Reflections” paper, journal entries and “Use of My Self” paper.
  3. Identify the role of supervision in professional development and to participate in this process through the acceptance and use of constructive feedback. Assessed by “First Reflections” essay, journal entries, and observations by site supervisor.
  4. Identify his/her strengths and challenges in learning and in performing as a human service professional. Assessed by journal entries, “Use of My Self” paper and classroom activities.
  5. Identify the importance of the “use of self” and demonstrate a beginning capacity to use one’s self in the helping role. Assessed by journal entries, site supervisor’s observations, “Use of My Self” paper.
  6. Identify personal feelings and experiences as they apply to his/her learning process and professional performance. Assessed by paper “My Beginning to be a Helping Professional” essay, presentation of field experiences in classroom, journal entries, site supervisor’s assessment, and “Use of My Self” paper.

CourseInventory.CourseLongTitle: Theory and Methods of Helping in The Human Services
CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Teaches process of assessment and helping as collaborative endeavor focusing on consideration of person's strengths and ecosystem variables. Particular attention paid to professional ethics and cultural competence in empowerment-based practice. (offered online or days only in fall semester) Prerequisite: A grade of C or better in HUS101 and HUS103. Corequisite: HUS201. Offered on: A / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Identify the principles inherent in generalist human services practice using empowerment, strengths and systems perspectives.
  2. Assessed by examination, class discussion, article reports and case analysis paper.
  3. Evaluate generalist human service practice. Assessed by case analysis paper and article reports.
  4. Recognize generalist human service methods as they apply within an agency’s functions. Assessed by examination, class discussion and article reports.
  5. Assess client needs and to formulate mutual goals with clients which are appropriate to agency function and client self-determination. Assessed by examination, case analysis paper.
  6. Select and apply appropriate generalist practice skills and techniques using systems theory and the problem solving process within a strengths perspective. Assessed by examination and case analysis paper.

CourseInventory.CourseLongTitle: Human Services Seminar & Field Practicum II
CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Classroom study in seminar setting along with 180 hours of off-campus field work. Students continue intensive supervised experience working at human service agency that began in HUS201. Classroom work emphasizes discussions of field experiences, applications of theories of helping, a capstone assignment, and exploration of professional ending process. Students enrolling in this course are automatically charged the liability insurance fee. Field work component is completed primarily during day hours. (offered spring semester only) (3 hrs. seminar, 12 hrs. laboratory totaling 180 field hrs.) Prerequisite: HUS205 and HUS201 with grade of C or better. Offered on: A / 6 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Demonstrate increased responsibility and competency in basic human service skills in their expanded role as a human service intern. Assessed by journal entries and site supervisor’s evaluation.
  2. Identify the generalist human service worker functions, roles and skills applicable to their current practice. Assessed by written analysis of their work with an individual or group.
  3. Effectively use the supervisory experience for personal and professional development. Assessed through site supervisor’s evaluation.
  4. Demonstrate an awareness of the current human service practice issues related to their current fieldwork experience. Assessed by written article reports, contributions to classroom discussion, site supervisor’s evaluation, case presentation.
  5. Write a complete biopsychosocial history and assessment or a group study. Assessed by instructor’s evaluation of the written work.
  6. Effectively present a case for classroom consultation. Assessed by instructor’s evaluation of presentation.
  7. Analyze his/her work as a generalist human service practitioner. Assessed by written analysis assignment.
  8. Contribute as a consultant to other students presenting case material for discussion. Assessed by participation in discussion with fellow students as each presents.
  9. Demonstrate knowledge of the interpersonal dynamics of the ending of the helping process. Assessed by journal entries and final paper.
  10. Successfully resolve the professional and personal issues of ending relationships associated with fieldwork and the classroom. Assessed by written assignment, classroom contributions and journal entries.
  11. Write an effective and accurate personal resume. Assessed by the quality of the written resume.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Comprehensive computer course designed for technology students. Interactive laboratory and lecture sessions provide students with skills needed to analyze and present solutions to engineering design challenges. Emphasizes how word processing, presentation and spreadsheet tools are used for engineering, statistical and numeric applications. (Offered fall semester only.) (2 hrs. lecture, 2 hrs. laboratory) No prerequisite. Offered on: G / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Become proficient in the use of Microsoft Office programs including Word, Powerpoint Access, and Excel.
  2. Become proficient in the use of Windows and Internet Explorer.
  3. Properly diagnose and service residential and light commercial air conditioning and refrigeration systems.
  4. Use meters, gauges, computer software and other diagnostic instruments to effectively and accurately identify system problems.
  5. Develop interpersonal and customer service skills that are essential in our service-oriented industry.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Teaches fundamental knowledge of air conditioning and refrigeration theory. Develops job-entry knowledge for installing, operating, troubleshooting and repairing refrigeration and air conditioning systems. As part of this course, students will learn to solder, braze, flare, swage, leak test, install, evacuate, charge service and evaluate air conditioning and refrigeration systems. (2 hrs. lecture, 2 hrs. laboratory) No prerequisite. Offered on: G / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Understand the basic vapor-compression refrigeration cycle.
  2. Interpret data that are gathered from gauge manifolds, thermometers and pressure/temperature charts.
  3. Discuss the operation of the four main components in the basic vapor-compression refrigeration system.
  4. Plot an air conditioning or refrigeration system on a pressure enthalpy (Mollier) diagram.
  5. Determine properties of air by using the psychrometric chart.
  6. Perform piping operations on copper tubing such as cutting, reaming, flaring, swaging, soldering and brazing.
  7. Properly handle and work with refrigerants.
  8. Leak check, evacuate and charge refrigeration systems.
  9. Prepare detailed and accurate laboratory reports.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Teaches fundamental knowledge of electricity as it relates to the HVAC/R industry. Lecture topics include electrical and workplace safety, Ohm’s law, voltage, current, resistance, power, series and parallel circuits, circuit protection devices, electric motors and starting components, relays and switches, and circuit/component troubleshooting. In the laboratory portion of the course, students will construct basic circuits, learn to use various pieces of electrical testing instrumentation and learn the basics of electrical circuit and component troubleshooting. (1 hrs. lecture, 2 hrs. laboratory) No prerequisite. Offered on: G / 2 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Demonstrate safe electrical practices.
  2. Explain the basic concepts of electricity including voltage, current, resistance and power.
  3. Describe the electrical components that make up an electric circuit.
  4. Explain the differences between power-passing and power-consuming devices.
  5. Explain the operation of relays, contactors and capacitors.
  6. Describe the operation of a simple electric motor.
  7. Describe various types of electric motors.
  8. Describe the function of various motor-starting devices.
  9. Construct basic electrical circuits.
  10. Evaluate the operation of basic electrical circuits.
  11. Identify various pieces of electrical testing instrumentation.
  12. Properly use various pieces of electrical testing instrumentation to measure voltage, current and resistance.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Covers operation, installation, servicing and maintenance of oil, gas and electric heating equipment, including water heaters. Emphasis placed on theory of operation of fossil fuel systems as well as electric and reverse-cycle refrigeration systems (heat pumps). In lab, students disassemble and evaluate component parts of oil burners, ignition systems, fan centers and other devices instrumental in operation of heating equipment. (2 hrs. lecture, 4 hrs. laboratory) Prerequisites: HVA111, HVA121 and HVA122. Offered on: G / 4 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Understand the basic vapor-compression heat pump cycle.
  2. Troubleshoot electrical and mechanical portions of a heat pump system.
  3. Explain the processes of fossil fuel refinement and combustion.
  4. Test systems for proper combustion.
  5. Evaluate the products of combustion.
  6. Determine proper venting strategies for various heating systems.
  7. Explain the operation of gas and oil-fired boilers.
  8. Fabricate piping layouts for gas furnaces.
  9. Evaluate the electric circuits in a gas furnace.
  10. Disassemble and reassemble oil burners.
  11. Evaluate oil burner components.
  12. Layout a hydronic heating system.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Covers electrical and solid-state devices used to control operation of air conditioning, heating and refrigeration systems. Students construct and evaluate circuits and their components to gain solid understanding of how components function together to provide desired system operation. Students troubleshoot components and design control systems based on projects assigned in class. Projects include control systems for air conditioning, oil heating, gas heating, and reverse-cycle refrigeration systems. Emphasis also on motor controls as well as pneumatics. (2 hrs. lecture, 4 hrs. laboratory) Prerequisite: HVA121, HVA122 and HVA141. Offered on: G / 4 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Identify and describe the various control components found in refrigeration, air conditioning and heating systems.
  2. Evaluate/troubleshoot control systems by using various pieces of test equipment.
  3. Design control systems to achieve the desired system operation.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Covers commercial air conditioning, heating and refrigeration systems. Emphasis on installation, service and troubleshooting, as well as air distribution systems, psychrometrics, water-cooled equipment, cooling towers and chillers. (3 hrs. lecture, 4 hrs. laboratory) Prerequisite: HVA121, HVA122 and HVA141. Offered on: G / 5 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Properly plot an air conditioning system on a pressure enthalpy chart.
  2. Properly plot the air side of an air conditioning system on a psychrometric chart.
  3. Evaluate the links between the pressure-enthalpy and psychrometric plots.
  4. Determine the energy efficiency rating (EER) of an air conditioning system using the psychrometric chart and pressure-enthalpy diagram.
  5. Read and interpret blueprints.
  6. Layout air distribution (duct) systems.
  7. Layout duct sections in a sheet metal fabrication shop.
  8. Construct sections of ductwork in a sheet metal fabrication shop.
  9. Join sections of duct material.
  10. Explain the operation and service of chilled water systems.
  11. Explain the concept of free cooling.
  12. Adjust belts and pulleys on belt-driven air delivery systems.
  13. Take motor speed and air velocity readings on belt-driven air delivery systems.
  14. Establish relationships between blower speed and air volume delivery rates.
  15. Describe the various components found on commercial refrigeration systems.
  16. Describe the operation of a cascade refrigeration system.
  17. Describe the operation of an absorption air conditioning system.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Teaches skills needed to logically and accurately troubleshoot and diagnose HVAC/R systems as well as skills needed to perform successful service calls.
