Self-monitoring of appropriate individualized intensity, frequency and duration of swimming stressed utilizing training journal in conjunction with class participation. No prerequisite. Offered on: E-G / 1 cr. hr.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Develop an interest, appreciation, and enjoyment of water activities.
  2. Demonstrate knowledge and skills necessary to feel comfortable in, on, or around the aquatic environment.
  3. Demonstrate the knowledge and skills necessary for Level III certification (minimally) as established by American Red Cross
  4. Learn-To-Swim Program; see course objectives.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Uses swimming as activity to enhance cardiovascular fitness and muscle endurance. Pre- and post-fitness levels assessed. Self-monitoring of appropriate individualized intensity, frequency and duration of swimming stressed utilizing training journal in conjunction with class participation. Students need to swim 400 yards continuously at first session or have permission of Chair/Academic Dean. No prerequisite. Offered on: E-G / 1 cr. hr.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Implement individualized skill development drills, conditioning sessions for swimming speed and endurance, and monitor training intensity.
  2. Assess improvements in above parameters by analyzing results in a pre & post timed swim test and other skills tests as determined by instructor.
  3. Demonstrate appropriate warm-up, cool-down and flexibility activities for swimming.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: The course provides "total" fitness experience through use of muscle training exercises, a variety of aerobic conditioning activities and stretching techniques. Training varies from day to day. No prerequisite. Offered on: A / 1 cr. hr.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Learn to calculate Target Heart Rate.
  2. Learn what is meant by training effect (FIT Principle) and exercise intensity.
  3. Demonstrate knowledge of the aerobic and anaerobic energy systems during class and on a written quiz.
  4. Improve cardiovascular system, muscle strength and flexibility.
  5. Distinguish safe and appropriate fitness regimens.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Techniques of jazz dancing from its origins to contemporary stage dancing. No prerequisite. Offered on: A-E-G / 1 cr. hr.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Demonstrate movement knowledge of jazz dance vocabulary and technique.
  2. Increase body flexibility and range of movement taught through traditional jazz techniques.
  3. Promote the development of rhythmic senses, individual movement expression and a basic knowledge of various jazz styles.
  4. Develop an appreciation of jazz dance as an art form.
  5. Choreograph individual and/or group presentations.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Emphasizes improvement in cardiovascular endurance combining low- and high-impact moves and intensities through use of dance/locomotive patterns and a variety of other techniques. No prerequisite. Offered on: A-E-G / 1 cr. hr.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Calculate and understand their appropriate target heart rate training zone.
  2. Recognize the warning signs, and the sound and effective protocol relating to aerobic conditioning.
  3. Gain support information relating to health and quality of life issues, for ex., body composition, the role of aerobic conditioning for weight management, etc.
  4. Design a personal aerobic conditioning program.
  5. Demonstrate improvement in health and fitness parameters.
  6. Recognize and appreciate the importance of an aerobic conditioning program in one’s daily life.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Teaches an ancient and established art of the Orient using basic defensive and offensive techniques of Karate. First and second basic forms, called Katas, are introduced. No prerequisite. Offered on: A-G / 1 cr. hr.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Stimulate an improvement in physical fitness, flexibility, strength, speed, and power.
  2. Develop a heightened sense of self-confidence, assertiveness, relaxation, and above all respect.
  3. Develop practical self defense techniques.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Improves cardiovascular endurance combining low-impact work with moderate- to high-intensity conditioning response through use of creative step patterns, multidirectional variations and transitions and interval training. No prerequisite. Offered on: A-G / 1 cr. hr.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Demonstrate knowledge of aerobic conditioning, and how it affects the cardiovascular system and impacts an individual’s quality of life.
  2. Improve cardiovascular fitness through a series of assessments.
  3. Increase energy output and generate a greater sense of well-being as the semester progresses.
  4. Obtain health and fitness information to encourage a healthy lifestyle.
  5. Develop muscular improvements enhancing strength, endurance, coordination and flexibility throughout the semester.
  6. Monitor and acknowledge one’s appropriate heart rate training zone
  7. Distinguish a safe and appropriate step aerobic program by the end of the course.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Improves cardiovascular endurance by combining low-impact workout with moderate- to high-intensity conditioning through use of basic boxing skills such as jabs, punches, upper cuts and tae kwon do kicks. Some high-impact, high-intensity interval segments included. No prerequisite. Offered on: A-E-G / 1 cr. hr.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Learn to calculate Target heart rate zone and understand the Borge scale of Rate of Perceived Exertion.
  2. Demonstrate a knowledge of the aerobic and anaerobic energy system, through written assignments, class workouts, and final exam.
  3. Improve cardiovascular fitness and lactate threshold(measured by pre and post evaluations).
  4. Increase energy output and generate a greater sense of well being.
  5. Develop muscular strength, flexibility, agility, balance, and coordination (measured by pre and post evaluations).
  6. Distinguish a safe and appropriate cardio kickboxing program.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Introduces basics of equitation. Includes emphasis on controlling horse, understanding use of aids, movements of horse, rider's position and safely working with horses. Special fee and transportation required. No prerequisite. Offered on: E-G / 1 cr. hr.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Groom and tack the horse before riding
  2. Execute basic equitation skills
  3. Untack and groom the horse after riding

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: For students who have completed PED165: Introduction to Equitation and Horsemanship or its equivalent and can walk, trot and canter. Includes emphasis on hunt seat, forward seat, dressage seat, balance seat, polo seat, jumping, advanced movements of horse, rider's position and safely working with horses. Students must be able to mount and dismount horse without assistance. Special fee and transportation required. Prerequisite: PED165 or permission of Chair/Academic Dean. Offered on: E-G / 1 cr. hr.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives: 1. Reinforcement of proper handling of the horse on the ground and understanding its’ behavior. Review of the basics of riding and the safe control of the horse. Introduction of new riding disciplines on the intermediate level.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: This aerobics class is designed to teach the fundamental movements of Hip Hop dancing. Students will learn the importance of cardiorespiratory fitness, recommended guidelines and the benefits associated with leading a healthy, active lifestyle. A series of dance combinations will be taught throughout the semester, as well as the history and evolution behind this dance style. No prerequisite required. No prerequisite. Offered on: A-E-G / 1 cr. hr.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Be able to identify the history and evolution of hip hop and house dancing.
  2. Be able to perform basic hip hop and house dance skills with proper technique.
  3. Understand the personal barriers related to exercise and develop ways to overcome these barriers to increase student’s physical activity involvement.
  4. Have a solid foundation and broad understanding of the cardiorespiratory system and the benefits/adaptations that occur with regular physical activity.
  5. Identify the ACSM guidelines associated with cardiorespiratory fitness.
  6. Understand and identify the important role nutrition plays and learn how to make healthier choices that will make a positive impact on their lives.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: This course is designed for students to participate in a variety of activities emphasizing improvement in cardiovascular fitness. Activities include: Fitness Walking, Jogging, Cardio-Kickboxing, Spin, Step Aerobics and Interval Training. In addition, students will be introduced to basic fitness and wellness principles. Topics include the health-related aspects of physical fitness, proper nutrition, weight management, heart disease, cancer, stress, sexual health, addictive behaviors, and the influence of mental, emotional, and social factors on these aspects. This class is designed to help students define wellness, and to identify the behaviors that constitute a fit and well lifestyle. Note: Students may not take additional two-credit Physical Education courses for college credit. (1 hr. lecture, 2 hrs. laboratory) No prerequisite. Offered on: A-E-G / 2 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Participate in variety of aerobic activities helping to improve the cardiovascular system.
  2. Recognize the benefits of aerobic conditioning and how physical activity positively impacts an individual’s quality of life.
  3. Evaluate her/his present level of fitness and behavior patterns and make the necessary lifestyle adjustments for attainment/maintenance of a high level of wellness.
  4. Obtain the ability to apply principles of physical fitness, nutrition, weight control, stress management; alcohol/drug abuse, and disease prevention, to positively
  5. modify her/his own personal lifestyle.
  6. Identify the benefits associated with leading a healthy lifestyle and maintaining a high level of wellness.
  7. Recognize the personal barriers related to exercise and develop ways to overcome these barriers to increase student’s physical activity involvement.
  8. Identify community resources related to fitness that will help promote physical activity in the future.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Students will learn to recognize the benefits of maintaining a high level of wellness and how to live a healthy lifestyle through lecture and participation in lifetime activities. Covers the basic fundamentals of resistance training and the benefits of physical activity. (1 hr. lecture, 2 hrs. laboratory) Note: Students may not take additional two-credit Physical Education courses for college credit. No prerequisite. Offered on: A-E-G / 2 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Recognize the benefits of muscular strength and endurance training and how physical activity positively impacts an individual’s quality of life.
  2. Demonstrate proper training techniques and safety guidelines related to muscular strength and endurance training.
  3. Evaluate her/his present level of fitness and behavior patterns and make the necessary lifestyle adjustments for attainment/maintenance of a high level of wellness.
  4. Obtain the ability to apply principles of physical fitness, nutrition, weight control, stress management; alcohol/drug abuse, and disease prevention, to positively modify her/his own personal lifestyle.
  5. Identify the benefits associated with leading a healthy lifestyle and maintaining a high level of wellness.
  6. Recognize the personal barriers related to exercise and develop ways to overcome these barriers to increase student’s physical activity involvement.
  7. Identify community resources related to fitness that will help promote physical activity in the future.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Students will learn to recognize the benefits of maintaining a high level of wellness and how to live a healthy lifestyle through lecture and participation in lifetime activities. Covers the basic fundamentals of team sports, the concept of teamwork and the benefits of physical activity. (1 hr. lecture, 2 hrs. laboratory) Note: Students may not take additional two-credit Physical Education courses for college credit. No prerequisite. Offered on: A-E-G / 2 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Collaborate and problem solving to implement effective strategy and tactics during play in a variety of team sports.
  2. Identify the physical, mental, and social benefits to participating in team sports.
  3. Demonstrates competency in motor skills and movement patterns needed to achieve a standard of physical exertion as appropriate for a variety of team sports.
  4. Identify community resources related to team sports that will help promote physical activity in the future.
  5. Understand and recognize the benefits associated with leading a healthy lifestyle and maintaining a high level of wellness.
  6. Evaluate her/his present level of fitness and behavior patterns and make the necessary lifestyle adjustments for attainment/maintenance of a high level of wellness.
  7. Obtain the ability to apply principles of physical fitness, nutrition, weight control, stress management; alcohol/drug abuse, and disease prevention, to positively modify her/his own personal lifestyle.
  8. Recognize the personal barriers related to exercise and develop ways to overcome these barriers to increase student’s physical activity involvement.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Students will learn to recognize the benefits of maintaining a high level of wellness and how to live a healthy lifestyle through lecture and participation in lifetime activities. Covers the basic fundamentals of racket sports, the concept of teamwork and the benefits of physical activity. (1 hr. lecture, 2 hrs. laboratory) Note: Students may not take additional two-credit Physical Education courses for college credit. No prerequisite. Offered on: A-E-G / 2 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Collaborate and problem solve to implement effective strategy and tactics during play in a variety of racket sports.
  2. Identify the physical, mental, and social benefits to participating in racket sports.
  3. Demonstrates competency in motor skills and movement patterns needed to achieve a standard of physical exertion as appropriate for racket sports.
  4. Recognize the personal barriers related to exercise and develop ways to overcome these barriers to increase student’s physical activity involvement.
  5. Identify community resources related to racket sports that will help promote physical activity in the future.
  6. Understand and recognize the benefits associated with leading a healthy lifestyle and maintaining a high level of wellness.
  7. Evaluate her/his present level of fitness and behavior patterns and make the necessary lifestyle adjustments for attainment/maintenance of a high level of wellness.
  8. Obtain the ability to apply principles of physical fitness, nutrition, weight control, stress management; alcohol/drug abuse, and disease prevention, to positively modify her/his own personal lifestyle.

CourseInventory.CourseLongTitle: Introduction to Physical Education, Fitness and Sport
CourseInventory.CourseDescription: This course is an introduction to the personal and professional challenges, and opportunities available in the field of physical education, fitness and sport. Its primary purpose is to help the student gain an insight into these disciplines; to acquaint the student, generally, with the organized body of knowledge embraced within Physical Education; and to show the proper relationship among related fields. This course can only be used as an unrestrictive elective and is open to all students. It does not satisfy the physical education graduation requirement. No prerequisite. Offered on: A-E-G / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Know the evolution and history of physical education, fitness and sport.
  2. Develop a personal teaching philosophy.
  3. Understand the role physical education; fitness and sport have played in American life.
  4. Know the meaning and philosophy of physical education, fitness and sport.
  5. Identify current trends in physical education, fitness and sport and discuss possible future implications.
  6. Discuss both the psychological and sociological foundations of physical education and sport.
  7. Identify curriculum, program development and pedagogy at all educational levels.
  8. Discuss areas of concern in physical education (age, gender, etc.).

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: This is an introductory course to the fundamentals of coaching. Classes are structured to provide students with the basic knowledge and skills required to develop an effective coaching program and create a personal coaching philosophy. Students will learn about the many aspects of coaching from designing and executing a session to handling administrative responsibilities. It does not satisfy the physical education graduation requirement. No prerequisite. Offered on: A / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Demonstrate a basic understanding of the fundamentals of coaching: both on and off the field.
  2. Understand how leadership and motivation relate to success and failure in coaching.
  3. Create a personal philosophy of coaching based on the needs of today’s sports environment.
  4. Recognize the traits of a successful coach.
  5. Learn effective methods to relate to parents, administrators, colleagues and “fans”.
  6. Identify ways to promote a sports program.
  7. Understand the application process for a coaching position and proper interview etiquette.
  8. Design tryouts, plan practices, and organize a session.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: This course is designed as a content knowledge course for the team sports of volleyball, soccer and basketball. The course will provide students experiences that will lead to skill acquisition, as well as, the ability to analyze and correct errors in skill performance. Students will be introduced to the various progressions of teaching these skills that are developmentally appropriate for a K-12 physical education setting. (2 hrs. laboratory) Note: Course is restricted to Physical Education Majors. Prerequisite: PED190. Offered on: A / 1 cr. hr.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Identify and analyze developmentally appropriate skills for each team sport.
  2. Plan and prioritize the proper teaching progression of skills, drills, lead-up games and culminating events such as tournaments and games for each team sport.
  3. Recognize and demonstrate appropriate practice guidelines for teaching team sports in physical education.
  4. Plan and implement lesson plans for assigned skills, drills or games.
  5. Apply a variety of managerial and organizational techniques to ensure maximum academic learning time.
  6. Identify rules, history, etiquette, and safety of team sports.
  7. Plan authentic assessment for each team sport.
  8. Demonstrate effective communication skills

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: This course is designed as a content knowledge course for the racket sports of tennis, pickleball, and badminton. The course will provide students experiences that will lead to skill acquisition, as well as, the ability to analyze and correct errors in skill performance. Students will be introduced to the various progressions of teaching these skills that are developmentally appropriate for a K-12 physical education setting. (2 hrs. laboratory) Note: Course is restricted to Physical Education Majors. Prerequisite: PED190. Offered on: A / 1 cr. hr.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Identify and analyze developmentally appropriate skills for each racket sport.
  2. Plan and prioritize the proper teaching progression of skills, drills, lead-up games and culminating events such as tournaments for each racket sport.
  3. Recognize and demonstrate appropriate practice guidelines for teaching racket sports in physical education.
  4. Plan and implement lesson plans for assigned skills, drills or games.
  5. Apply a variety of managerial and organizational techniques to ensure maximum academic learning time.
  6. Identify rules, history, etiquette, and safety of racket sports.
  7. Plan authentic assessment for each racket sport.
  8. Demonstrate effective communication skills.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: This course is designed as a content knowledge course for a variety of Lifetime Activities which will include golf, Frisbee golf and bowling. The course will provide students experiences that will lead to skill acquisition, as well as, the ability to analyze and correct errors in skill performance. Students will be introduced to the various progressions of teaching these skills that are developmentally appropriate for a K-12 Physical Education setting. (2 hrs. laboratory) Note: Course is restricted to Physical Education Majors. Prerequisite: PED190. Offered on: A / 1 cr. hr.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Identify and analyze developmentally appropriate skills for each lifetime activity.
  2. Plan and prioritize the proper teaching progression of skills, drills, lead-up games and culminating events such as tournaments for each lifetime activity.
  3. Recognize and demonstrate appropriate practice guidelines for teaching lifetime activities in physical education.
  4. Plan and implement lesson plans for assigned skills, drills or games.
  5. Apply a variety of managerial and organizational techniques to ensure maximum academic learning time.
  6. Identify rules, history, etiquette, and safety of lifetime activities.
  7. Plan authentic assessment for each lifetime activity.
  8. Demonstrate effective communication skills.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: This course will examine the scientific foundations of human physiology and provide an understanding of the mechanisms by which the body functions during exercise and physical activity. Topics of discussion include: metabolism, function of the cardiovascular system, respiratory system, musculoskeletal system, neural and endocrine systems, and the acute and chronic adaptations of each system during exercise and training. Also discussed are the effects of environmental factors, nutrition, training principles and ergogenic aids on human performance. This course contains a laboratory experience. (3 hrs. lecture, 2 hrs. laboratory) Prerequisites: BIO130 and BIO132. Offered on: A / 4 cr. hr.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Identify and discuss acute and chronic adaptations to the cardiovascular, respiratory, musculoskeletal, neural, endocrine and metabolic systems in response to exercise and training.
  2. Discuss how the various systems of the human body interrelate in response to exercise.
  3. Locate and evaluate current research in exercise physiology.
  4. Discuss the effects of environmental factors, nutrition, ergogenic aids, and various training principles and programs on the performance of the human body.
  5. Evaluate the risks and benefits of various modes and intensities of exercise for a variety of populations.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Special and current topics in Physical Education may be available. See "Class Schedule Search" for a complete listing each term. Offered on: A-E-G / 1-3 cr. hrs.

CourseInventory.CourseLongTitle: Exercise Leadership and Concepts of Aerobic Conditioning
CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Physiological aspects of aerobic conditioning, principles of training, and biomechanics of appropriate movement patterns are covered. Exercise leadership techniques emphasized as students experience and learn design concepts for variety of aerobic conditioning programs: jog/walk, aerobic dance, bike, treadmill, rower, etc. (Offered fall semester only.) (1 hr. lecture, 2 hrs. laboratory.) Prerequisite: BIO132. Corequisite: PFS201, 205, 212 and BIO245. Offered on: A / 2 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Understand the physiology and training principles utilized in aerobic conditioning programs.
  2. Identify the proper techniques and appropriate training concepts necessary to accomplish cardiovascular endurance conditioning.
  3. Learn, analyze and demonstrate those exercise leadership qualities which are physiologically sound, safe and effective in a fitness setting.
  4. Investigate a variety of design patterns and aerobic equipment with insight into their use for special populations.

CourseInventory.CourseLongTitle: Overview of Fitness and Facility Management
CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Provides students with knowledge and skill required for employment in fitness field. Topics include growth and development of fitness industry, job opportunities, evaluation criteria for all levels, program planning, space and facilities design, equipment evaluation and purchasing, liability issues and more. Offered on: (Offered fall semester only.) Offered on: A / 3 cr. hrs.

CourseInventory.CourseLongTitle: Exercise Leadership and Concepts of Muscle Conditioning
CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Covers physiological aspects of developing muscular strength and endurance, principles of training, exercise analysis and biomechanics of techniques. Exercise leadership techniques emphasized as students experience and learn design concepts for calisthenics, free weights, machines, etc., and their application for various programs and populations. (Offered fall semester only.) (1 hr. lecture, 2 hrs. laboratory) Prerequisite: BIO132. Corequisites: PFS113, 205, 212 and BIO245. Offered on: A / 2 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Understand the physiology and training principles utilized in muscle conditioning programs.
  2. Identify the proper techniques and appropriate training concepts necessary to accomplish muscle strength and endurance training.
  3. Learn, analyze and demonstrate those exercise leadership qualities which are physiologically sound, safe and effective in a fitness setting.
  4. Investigate a variety of design patterns, equipment and machines with insight into their use for special populations.
  5. Demonstrate and participate in different techniques of muscle conditioning as a means of understanding, as well as improving their personal muscle conditioning.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Provides understanding of different components of fitness, various evaluation techniques, health screening of individuals, and their application to needs of clients and special populations in designing appropriate fitness program. (Offered fall semester only.) (1 hr. lecture, 2 hrs. laboratory) Prerequisite: BIO132. Corequisites: PFS113, 201, 212 and BIO245. Offered on: A / 2 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Properly screen and identify individuals whose participation in a fitness evaluation may be contraindicated.
  2. Communicate to a test subject the rational, and value of a fitness evaluation, and how to properly prepare for the test day.
  3. Choose and safely administer the proper physical fitness test protocol relating to cardio respiratory fitness, muscular fitness, anaerobic capacity, body weight and composition and flexibility.
  4. Properly interpret and communicate test results.
  5. Understand what effect a properly designed exercise program will have on test components.
  6. Demonstrate and participate in different techniques of muscle conditioning as a means of understanding, as well as improving their personal muscle conditioning.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Provides students in fitness field with nutritional information pertinent to enhancing human performance. Among subjects discussed are digestive system, food substances, minerals and vitamins; energy systems and their application to fitness and sports performance; supplemental and diet theories for sport enhancement and weight management; and relationship between food and exercise performance for special populations. (Offered spring semester only.) Prerequisite: BIO132. Corequisite: PFS217. Offered on: A / 3 cr. hrs.

Students study anatomy and biomechanics of human body discussing preventive and rehabilitative techniques for fitness and sport participation injuries. Stress reduction, over-training symptoms, and client's overall wellness included. (Offered fall semester only.) Prerequisite: BIO132. Corequisites: PFS113, 201, 205 and BIO245. Offered on: A / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Identify basic anatomy and physiology related to sports and fitness injuries.
  2. Understand the biomechanics involved in sports and fitness related movements.
  3. Identify and articulate the mechanisms of injury related to sport and fitness injuries.
  4. Describe and explore prevention techniques such as flexibility activities and prophylactic bracing related to sports and fitness injuries.
  5. Explain and describe the management and recovery activities associated with sports and fitness related injuries.1. Identify basic anatomy and physiology related to sports and fitness injuries.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Provides fitness specialists with on-campus practical fieldwork experience in working with clients by providing fitness assessment, screening, program design and leadership techniques through participation in an exercise program under supervision of department faculty. Knowledge base, skill and behavioral components covered in curriculum are assessed through this experience. Registration in this course requires that students purchase liability insurance through the college. (offered spring semester only) (1 hr. lecture, 8 hrs. fieldwork) Prerequisite: PFS113, PFS201, PFS205, PFS212 and BIO245. Corequisites: PFS211. Offered on: A / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Screen individuals to determine appropriateness for participation in a fitness evaluation and identify whose participation may be contraindicated.
  2. Administer, interpret and communicate the results of a fitness assessment.
  3. Determine how a properly designed exercise program will impact fitness assessment results.
  4. Demonstrate an understanding of proper training and conditioning principles and techniques by designing proper exercise programs for diverse populations.
  5. Understand the physiology and proper training principles and techniques utilized in muscle, cardiorespiratory and flexibility conditioning programs.
  6. Recognize common injuries with an emphasis on prevention, understand precautions for special populations.
  7. Demonstrate exercise leadership qualities which are physiologically sound, safe and effective in a fitness environment.
  8. Modify programs as needed based upon unexpected physical, emotional or mental changes expressed by a client.
  9. Demonstrate proper technique and safe usage of various exercise equipment.
  10. Demonstrate the ability to use the web and computer skills as tools in fitness assessment and nutrition research.
  11. Utilize appropriate communication and motivation skills during the workout sessions.
  12. Present a professional demeanor by displaying a positive attitude, self-confidence, punctuality and proper attire. This will be done in a working environment with a variety of clients under the supervision of a faculty member.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Special and current topics in Fitness Specialist may be available. See "Class Schedule Search" for a complete listing each term. Offered on: A-E-G / 3-4 cr. hrs.

Investigates traditional and contemporary philosophical issues such as problem of knowledge, nature of reality, question of freewill versus determinism, and existence of mind, soul and God. Note: Fulfills SUNY General Education Requirement for Humanities. No prerequisite. Offered on: A-E-G / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Identify and describe traditional and current issues in philosophy.
  2. Define metaphysics and epistemology.
  3. Explain theory of knowledge, nature of truth, personal identity, and the freewill/determinism controversy.
  4. Demonstrate skills of critical analysis.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Develops methods of inquiry and analysis as core of a strategy of critical thinking. Students examine hypotheses according to evidence, role of necessary and sufficient conditions, concept of cause and effect, and treatment of alternative hypotheses. Includes use of these structures to formulate, evaluate, criticize and improve argument, judgment and interpretation. Note: Fulfills SUNY General Education Requirement for Humanities. No prerequisite. Offered on: A-E-G / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Think clearly and critically.
  2. Recognizes patterns of correct and fallacious reasoning.
  3. Recognize the significance of ambiguous and imprecise definition.
  4. Stick to the point of an argument.
  5. Define technical distinctions between induction and deduction, soundness and validity, and necessary and sufficient conditions.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Nature and structure of the reasoning process as found in basic fields of thought. Emphasis on both formal and informal logic, including fallacies in reasoning. Note: Fulfills SUNY General Education Requirement for Humanities. No prerequisite. Offered on: A-E-G / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Define the logical connectives -- conjunction, disjunction, implication and negation.
  2. Use Venn diagrams and Euler circles.
  3. Apply the rules of syllogistic validity.
  4. Perform logical operations of natural deduction.
  5. Construct sound arguments.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Study of traditional and contemporary moral theories, along with consideration of some contemporary moral problems, designed to help develop student¿s ability to assess moral judgments. Note: Fulfills SUNY General Education Requirement for Humanities. No prerequisite. Offered on: A-E-G / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Distinguish morality from other forms of value.
  2. Define major classical and contemporary normative theories, including Egoism, Utilitarianism and the Categorical Imperative.
  3. Compare metaethical ideas of moral objectivity, skepticism, ethical relativism, emotivism, and moral cognitivism.
  4. Demonstrate ability to think critically about moral issues and evaluate practical moral judgment.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Addresses, across cultural boundaries, the great questions of philosophy. Can we integrate into Western philosophic heritage the wisdom of ancient China and insights of Japan? What can we learn from the Vedic tradition of pain and suffering, from Arab and Jewish traditions of God and the evil we find in the world, from African traditions of mysteries of the universe, and from our own native peoples of human vision? Note: Fulfills SUNY General Education Requirement for Other World Civilizations and Humanities. No prerequisite. Offered on: A-G / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Understand and discuss the concepts of “multiculturalism” and “ethnophilosophy.
  2. Appreciate and compare how various cultures approach the study of philosophy.
  3. Develop an ability to use philosophical language.
  4. Develop the basic skills of critical analysis.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: This course will study the most important movements in contemporary Western philosophy from the beginning of the 20th century to the present. Movements to be discussed will include Logical Positivism, Oridinary Language Philosophy, American Pragmatism, Phenomenology, Hermeneutics, Existentialism, Critical Theory, Structuralism and Post-Structuralism, Deconstruction, and Feminist Philosophy. Special emphasis will be placed on the differences and similarities of issues, methods, and possible applications of these theories as wll as on their continuation and transformation of questions raised within the history of philosophy. Note: Fulfills SUNY General Education Requirement for Humanities. No prerequisite. Offered on: A / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Identify and comprehend some of the basic ideas, theories, movements, and persons that have shaped the developments of Western Philosophy during the twentieth century.
  2. Understand these developments in the context of and as response to the Western tradition of thought.
  3. Develop an awareness of the interconnection between schools of thought and socio-political developments during the twentieth century.
  4. Understand their contemporary culture in terms of a contemporary theoretical framework.
  5. Develop skills of critical analysis in speaking and writing.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Using classic readings in political theory as well as texts by contemporary thinkers, the course will develop basic concepts of freedom and oppression and explore those with respect to race, class, gender, and sexual preference. It will be shown how specific mechanisms of oppression/liberation affect women, people of color, different classes, and LGBT persons. Required for Women’s Studies majors. Note: Fulfills SUNY General Education Requirement for Humanities. No prerequisite. Offered on: A / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Identify and comprehend the political concepts of oppression and liberation, the various sources of oppression, and the consequent models of liberation.
  2. Situate contemporary constructions of gender, race, and class within the framework of oppression and liberation and understand the various aspects of the respective group oppression.
  3. Understand the interrelated dynamics of the various forms of oppression as well as the role this dynamics plays for liberation.
  4. Apply the conceptual insights of this course to their own experience of oppression in order to transform those experiences in a liberating fashion.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: This is an interdisciplinary rotating course, its content varying from semester to semester, for example, Philosophy Through Film, Philosophy and Harry Potter, Philosophy and Contemporary Music. No Prerequisite. Offered on: A / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Identify the various theories of Metaphysics.
  2. Demonstrate a working knowledge of Epistemological approaches.
  3. Distinguish among various theories of Ethics.
  4. Understand and employ techniques of Critical Analysis.
  5. Employ tools and technology to gather information.
  6. Recognize multi-modalities, such as film, literature, music, etc., as learning tools.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Surveys contributions of principal figures in history of Western philosophy from early Greeks to Medieval thinkers. Emphasizes works of Plato and Aristotle as setting foundation of early Western thought. Note: Fulfills SUNY General Education Requirement for Humanities. No prerequisite. Offered on: A-E-G / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Identify and understand the contributions of principal figures in the history of Western philosophy from early Greeks to Medieval thinkers, with special emphasis on the works of Plato and Aristotle.
  2. Understand different positions on particular philosophical issues and questions as a product of a historical and cultural context.
  3. Understand historically changing concepts within metaphysics, epistemology, ethics, and social philosophy.
  4. Recognize the possible contributions of past philosophical theories to contemporary questions and issues.
  5. Develop basic skills of critical analysis in speaking and writing.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Surveys contributions of principal figures in history of Western philosophy from modern period to contemporary thinkers. Emphasis on Rationalists and Empiricists, as setting foundation of modern and contemporary thought. Notes: (1) Prior background in philosophy not necessary. (2) Fulfills SUNY General Education Requirement for Humanities. No prerequisite. Offered on: A-E-G / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Identify and understand the contributions of principal figures in the history of Western philosophy from the beginning of the modern period to contemporary thinkers, with special emphasis on Rationalism and Empiricism.
  2. Understand different positions on particular philosophical issues and questions as a product of a historical and cultural context.
  3. Understand historically changing concepts within metaphysics, epistemology, ethics, and social philosophy.
  4. Recognize the possible contributions of past philosophical theories to contemporary questions and issues.
  5. Develop basic skills of critical analysis in speaking and writing.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: In-depth exploration of abortion, euthanasia, genetic engineering, cloning, human experimentation, allocation of scarce life-saving resources and other related ethical issues of current vital concern. Note: Fulfills SUNY General Education Requirement for Humanities. No prerequisite. Offered on: A-E-G / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Describe the major competing ethical theories – Egoism, Utilitarianism, Categorical Imperative and other forms of traditional moralism.
  2. Apply ethical theory to contemporary moral issues that arise out of recent developments in the life sciences that affect public policy.
  3. Analyze and clarify moral beliefs about abortion, human reproduction, decisions of life and death, mental illness and other related issues.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Within context of traditional and contemporary moral theory, investigates whether idea of business ethics makes sense, whether modern democratic social- welfare state - or any proposed alternative - is grounded in moral principle, whether corporations should have 'social conscience', whether principle of caveat emptor ('let the buyer beware') takes precedence in consumer society, and (among other issues) whether 'globalization' or 'protectionism' is a wave of the future. Note: Fulfills SUNY General Education Requirement for Humanities. No prerequisite. Offered on: A / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Explain the major moral theories, Egoism, Utilitarianism, The Categorical Imperative.
  2. Apply moral theory to contemporary ethical issues arising from business practice and related areas of economics.
  3. Analyze and clarify beliefs about affirmative action, truth in advertising, insider trading, corporate loyalty and ‘whistle blowing,’ employee rights, sexual harassment, corporate social responsibility and related issues.

CourseInventory.CourseLongTitle: The Philosophy of Animal Rights and Welfare
CourseInventory.CourseDescription: The relationship between humans and animals is rich and complex. For the past several decades, philosophers have been exploring the ethical dimensions to this relationship. What moral duties do we have to nonhuman animals? Do animals possess "rights"? Are the various ways in which animals are exploited morally defensible, or do our attitudes towards animals reveal inconsistencies in our moral framework? This class will survey the philosophical arguements that have been offered in the debate surrounding these questions, and encourage the students to participate in the debate by forming and defending their own positions. Note: Fulfills SUNY General Education Requirement for Humanities. No prerequisite. Offered on: G / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Cite the major arguments in the recent debate over the moral status of animals, and understand the strengths and weaknesses of each.
  2. Recount the historical, scientific and cultural contexts of the debate.
  3. Discuss the broad range of animal exploitation and the moral issues that each form of it raises.
  4. Form a conclusion about the ethics of using animals and defend it with a strong logical argument.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: This course will investigate theories of social and political philosophy from the ancients to the 20th century. By discussing the most influential philosophical theories for the political life (e.g. democracy, social contract theory. liberalism, utilitarianism, Marxism, totalitarianism, anarchy), basic concepts of social and political philosophy, such as justice, equality, freedom, rights, social responsibility, oppression/liberation, and the common good will be developed. Special emphasis will be placed on questions of racial and gender equality as well as on contempory issues, such as terrorism, nationalism and globalization. Note: Fulfills SUNY General Education Requirement for Humanities. No prerequisite. Offered on: A / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Identify and understand the most influential models for governing, such as oligarchy, aristocracy, absolutism, social contract theory, democracy, liberalism, communism, and anarchism, and explain them within their respective historical context.
  2. Identify and accurately use basic concepts of social and political theory, such as justice, liberty, equality, rights, the common good, power, and oppression.
  3. Apply the conceptual insights of this course to contemporary political issues and problems, such as cultural diversity, nationalism, globalization, racial and gender relations.
  4. Develop skills of critical analysis in speaking and writing.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Critical analysis of nature of religion and major conclusions of religious thought. Class discussion concerns readings taken from works of traditional and contemporary philosophers, including Aquinas, Anselm, Hume, Kant, Russell, Ayer, Flew and Munitz. Note: Fulfills SUNY General Education Requirement for Humanites. No prerequisite. Offered on: A-E-G / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Understand religious belief as a dimension of human experience.
  2. Evaluate various philosophical approaches, both traditional and contemporary, to explain or define religious experience.
  3. Develop an ability to use philosophical language.
  4. Develop the basic skills of critical analysis.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Philosophical perspective on art, literature, music and popular culture. Classical and contemporary theories on aesthetics used to analyze examples from various artistic areas. Addresses problem of defining art, special character of aesthetic judgment, and distinction between art and non-art. Also investigates role of art in society, its function and purpose, relationship between art and morality, quality of aesthetic experience and process of artistic creation. Special emphasis on distinction between high and low art. Some field trips may be required. Note: Fulfills SUNY General Education Requirement for Humanities. No prerequisite. Offered on A-G / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Differentiate between the artwork and aesthetic reflection on art.
  2. Identify and comprehend traditional and contemporary philosophical theories of art (with emphasis on the notions of representation, expression, form, and social institutions).
  3. Understand their own artistic experience by using philosophical categories as they are developed in aesthetic theories.
  4. Develop an awareness for the distinction between high and low art and the interconnections between art and society.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Special and current topics in Philosophy may be available. See "Class Schedule Search" for a complete listing each term. Offered on: A-E-G / 3-4 cr. hrs.

Honors special topics in Philosophy may be available for Honors students as well as those who have received permission from campus Honors Program Coordinator. See "Class Schedule Search" for a complete listing each term. Offered on: A-E-G / 3-4 cr. hrs.
Independent study courses in philosophy may be available. See the online catalog for a complete listing or contact academic chair. Offered on: A-E-G / 1-4 cr. hrs.

First course of a two-semester algebra/trig-based college physics sequence for liberal arts, life science, and physical therapy majors designed to acquaint students with basic concepts of physics. Topics covered include linear and rotational kinematics, dynamics, conservation of energy and momentum. (3 hrs. lecture, 3 hrs. laboratory) Note: Fulfills SUNY General Education Requirement for Natural Sciences. Prerequisite: MAT124 or equivalent. Offered on: A-E-G / 4 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Apply the laws of classical mechanics in areas of linear kinematics and dynamics, force and work/energy concepts, conservation of linear and angular momentum, rotational kinematics and dynamics.
  2. Use algebra and trigonometry throughout the course in formulating principles and solving problems.
  3. Interpret and manipulate graphical data and perform simple linear fits.
  4. Apply concepts of vector addition and resolution to practical problems.
  5. Apply critical thinking skills in analyzing multi-step word problems and formulating solutions.
  6. Work in a technical setting such as a laboratory and be able to present findings in a coherent lab report.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Second course of a two-semester algebra/trig-based college physics sequence for liberal arts, life science and physical therapy majors designed to acquaint students with basic concepts of physics. Topics covered include mechanics, sound, light, heat and electricity. (3 hrs. lecture, 3 hrs. laboratory) Note: Fulfills SUNY General Education Requirement for Natural Sciences. Prerequisite: PHY101. Offered on: A-E-G / 4 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Solve word problems in the areas of thermodynamics, phase change, heat and mechanical work, electrostatics, D.C. circuits, capacitors, resistors, the effect of electric and magnetic fields on charged particles and currents, and optics.
  2. Identify the properties of waves such as amplitude, length, frequency and period.
  3. Distinguish between longitudinal and transverse waves and give examples of each.
  4. Apply the concepts of wave theory to the electromagnetic waves and the light spectrum.
  5. Identify the properties of electricity such as resistance, voltage and current.
  6. Analyze elementary DC circuits using Ohm’s and Kirchhoff’s Laws.
  7. Distinguish between alternating current (AC) and direct current (DC).
  8. Solve problems involving magnetic induction, Faraday’s Law, Gauss’s Law and Lenz’s Law.
  9. Identify the properties of sound and explain how mechanical energy (such as sound) is transformed into thermal energy (heat).
  10. Analyze the optics of lenses and spherical mirrors.
  11. Analyze lens systems using the lens equation and the Lens Makers formula.
  12. Utilize Snell’s law and the Law of Refraction to solve problems in ray optics.
  13. Apply critical thinking skills in analyzing multi-step word problems and formulating solutions.
  14. Work in a technical setting such as a laboratory and be able to present findings in a coherent report.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Basic course which acquaints ASEP students with some fundamental aspects of physics. Study of linear and rotational kinematics, Newtonian dynamics of linear and rotational motion, conversation of energy and momentum, and selected topics in strength of materials, fluids and thermodynamics. Emphasis on applications to automotive system. (Offered spring semester only.) Prerequisite: MAT007 or equivalent. Offered on: A / 4 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Apply the laws of physics in areas of kinematics and dynamics, force, momentum and collisions, work/energy concepts, rotational motion, behavior of fluids and basic thermodynamics, electricity, simple circuits, and electromagnetism.
  2. Understand the physical principles behind simple machines.
  3. Understand the physical principles behind production of electricity and electromagnets.
  4. Interpret graphical data and do linear fits.
  5. Use basic algebra throughout the course in formulating principles and solving word problems.
  6. Apply critical thinking skills in analyzing multi-step word problems and formulating solutions.
  7. Work as part of a team on projects involving application of the physical concepts.
  8. Work in a technical setting such as a laboratory and be able to present findings in a coherent report.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Acquaints students in the Mechanical and Electrical Technology programs with fundamental aspects of physics. Study of Newton¿s Laws of Motion and their applications, principles of conservation of energy and momentum, and rotation and rotational dynamics. (3 hrs. lecture, 2 hrs. laboratory) Note: Fulfills SUNY General Education Requirement for Natural Sciences. Prerequisite: MAT112. Offered on: A-G / 4 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Apply the laws of physics in areas of linear kinematics and dynamics, force and work/energy concepts, electricity and simple circuits, basic thermodynamics, optics and application to simple optical instruments.
  2. Interpret graphical data and do linear fits.
  3. Use basic algebra and trigonometry throughout the course in formulating principles and solving word problems.
  4. Understand and apply concepts of vector addition and resolution.
  5. Apply critical thinking skills in analyzing multi-step word problems and formulating solutions.
  6. Work as part of a team on projects involving application of the physical concepts.
  7. Work in a technical setting such as a laboratory and be able to present findings in a coherent report.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: For students pursuing careers in health technologies. Includes application of principles of equilibrium to the human muscular system; study of work and energy; electricity and magnetism and their relation to medical equipment, heat, wave motion, atomic radiation and light. (3 hrs. lecture, 1 hr. recitation, 2 hrs. laboratory) Note: PHY115 does not satisfy prerequisite for PHY102. Prerequisite: MAT111 or equivalent. Offered on: A-G / 4 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Apply the laws of physics in areas of kinematics and dynamics, force and work/energy concepts, hydrostatics, basic thermodynamics, electricity and simple circuits, magnetism and optics.
  2. Understand principles of sound, including ultrasound.
  3. Interpret graphical data and do linear fits.
  4. Use basic algebra and trigonometry throughout the course in formulating principles and solving word problems.
  5. Apply critical thinking skills in analyzing multi-step word problems and formulating solutions.
  6. Work as part of a team on projects involving application of the physical concepts.
  7. Work in a technical setting such as a laboratory and be able to present findings in a coherent report.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Basic course in sequence of courses offered to majors in physical sciences, mathematics and engineering. Includes vectors, kinematics, dynamics, rotational kinematics and dynamics, gravitation and fluids. (4 hrs. lecture/recitation.) Note: Fulfills SUNY General Education Requirement for Natural Sciences. Prerequisite: MAT141. Corequisites: MAT142, PHY132. Offered on: A-E-G / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Apply the laws of classical mechanics for solids and fluids in areas of linear kinematics and dynamics, force and work/energy concepts, conservation of linear and angular momentum, rotational kinematics and dynamics.
  2. Use differential and integral calculus throughout the course in formulating principles and solving problems.
  3. Interpret and manipulate graphical data including fits to linear and quadratic functions.
  4. Apply critical thinking skills in analyzing multi-step word problems and formulating solutions.
  5. Understand classical mechanics at a level comparable to that offered at four-year institutes in order to successfully transfer into competitive engineering/science programs.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Mechanics laboratory using experiments in kinematics, dynamics and conservation laws to verify concepts in PHY130. (2 hrs. laboratory) Note: Fulfills SUNY General Education Requirement for Natural Sciences. Corequisite: PHY130. Offered on: A-E-G / 1 cr. hr.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Experimentally verify the laws of classical mechanics in areas of linear kinematics and dynamics, force and work/energy concepts, conservation of linear and angular momentum, rotational kinematics and dynamics.
  2. Use various laboratory instruments including computer-based data acquisition.
  3. Interpret and manipulate graphical data including fits to linear and polynomial functions.
  4. Apply critical thinking skills in analyzing practical problems; take necessary data and formulate solutions.
  5. Present the results of experiments as coherent reports including error analysis.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Second course in the sequence of calculus based physics courses. Electricity and magnetism emphasizing the field and potential concepts, using Coulomb's Law, Gauss’s Law, Lenz’s Law, Ampere’s Law, Faraday’s Law, resistance, capacitance, inductance, DC circuits with Kirchhoff's laws and dielectric and magnetic materials. (4 hrs. lecture/recitation) Note: Fulfills SUNY General Education Requirement for Natural Sciences. Prerequisite: MAT142, PHY130. Corequisite: PHY232. Offered on: A-E-G / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Solve word problems in the areas of gravity, electrostatics, DC Circuits, capacitors, inductors and resistors, the effect of magnetic fields on charged particles and current elements and the origins of magnetic fields.
  2. Understand the concepts of fields and potentials at a level appropriate to someone beginning the study of engineering or physical science.
  3. Apply the laws of physics to describe electricity and magnetism at a level appropriate to someone beginning a study of engineering/physical sciences.
  4. Apply the use of integral calculus using a problem-solving approach in each of the areas listed in the catalog description.
  5. Understand how physical phenomena can be organized into a few qualitative and quantitative models.
  6. Transfer successfully into an engineering/physical science program at a four-year institution.
  7. Apply critical thinking skills in order to analyze multi-step word problems to formulate solutions.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Electricity and magnetism laboratory using experiments in DC circuits, ammeters, voltmeters, mesh and loop equations, Thevenin’s theorem, superposition, impedance matching, electromagnetism, and transients used to verify concepts in PHY230 and learn basic instrumentation. (2 hrs. laboratory) Note: Fulfills SUNY General Education Requirement for Natural Sciences. Corequisite: PHY230. Offered on: A-E-G / 1 cr. hr.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Understand, on an experimental basis, the concepts taught in PHY 230.
  2. Properly identify and use the fundamental components in D.C. electric circuits.
  3. Properly interpret the results of observations and experiments and communicate the results effectively.
  4. Demonstrate the ability to determine and apply the correct uncertainty for various measurements.
  5. Understand how to use a variety of laboratory equipment such as voltmeters, ammeters, oscilloscopes, and function generators.
  6. The successful student will be able to write a coherent scientific lab report.
  7. Apply critical thinking skills in order to analyze multi-step word problems and formulate solutions.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Thermodynamics, waves, group and phase velocity, Fourier series, oscillation in physical systems, AC circuit theory, Maxwell's Equations, electromagnetic waves, and geometrical and physical optics. (4 hrs. lecture/recitation) Note: Fulfills SUNY General Education Requirement for Natural Sciences. Prerequisite: MAT203, MAT204, PHY230 and PHY232. Corequisites: PHY246. Offered on: A / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Apply differential equations to solve problems in harmonic motion, AC circuits, and physical optics.
  2. Apply laws of thermodynamics in models of heat engines and refrigerators.
  3. Use phasor notation to solve problems involving AC circuits.
  4. Apply calculus and differential equations in formulating principles and solving problems.
  5. Apply critical thinking skills in analyzing multi-step word problems and formulating solutions.
  6. Be prepared for future undergraduate studies in physics subfields such as quantum mechanics at four-year institutes.
  7. Successfully transfer to competitive engineering/science programs.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: AC circuit theory, waves, thermodynamics, and geometrical and physical optics. Note: Fulfills SUNY General Education Requirement for Natural Sciences (2 hrs. laboratory) Corequisite: PHY245. Offered on: A / 1 cr. hr.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Demonstrate on an experimental basis the concepts taught in PHY 245.
  2. Construct simple low pass and high pass electronic filters.
  3. Properly use various laboratory detection instruments such as the oscilloscope, impedance meter, signal generators and signal counters.
  4. Utilize lasers to make fine accurate measurements safely.
  5. Design useful circuits using resistors, capacitors, and inductors.
  6. Measure and calculate the speed, amplitude, frequency and length of a standing wave.
  7. Determine the resultant frequency of a wave due to a source in motion.
  8. Distinguish between simple, forced and damped motion on an air track.
  9. Construct a simple telescope and microscope accurately predicting its power.
  10. Write a coherent laboratory report, including error analysis.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: A survey of the major physics theories of the 20th century (relativity and quantum mechanics) and their impact on most areas of physics. Topics include the special theory of relativity, blackbody radiation, Planck’s constant, photoelectric effect, Bohr’s atom, wave function, Schrödinger’s equation, uncertainty principle, atomic spectra and structure, introduction to nuclear physics and particles. (4 hrs. lecture/recitation) Note: Fulfills SUNY General Education Requirement for Natural Sciences. Prerequisite: PHY230. Corequisite: PHY248. Offered on: A / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Solve word problems in the areas of quantum mechanics, relativity, photoelectric effect, atomic and nuclear physics, and the wave nature of matter.
  2. Explain the scientific basis of modern physics along with a brief history of its evolution.
  3. Apply advanced mathematical techniques and principles to determine solutions in scientific and technical applications such as quantization of angular momentum, electron spin, Pauli Exclusion Principle, Zeeman Effect, X-ray spectrum, Bragg's law, Compton Effect, de Broglie wavelength, wave-particle duality, and Heisenberg's uncertainty relationships.
  4. Successfully apply the theory of Schroedinger's wave mechanics to simple systems, including the hydrogen atom.
  5. Understand how physical phenomena can be organized into a few qualitative and quantitative models.
  6. Transfer successfully into an engineering/physical science program at a four-year institution.
  7. Apply critical thinking skills in order to analyze multi-step word problems to formulate solutions.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Contains modern physics labs such as Michelson interferometer, photoelectric effect, measurement of e/m, radioactive decay and spectroscopy. (2 hrs. laboratory) Corequisite: PHY247. Offered on: A / 1 cr. hr.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Demonstrate on an experimental basis the concepts taught in PHY 247.
  2. Construct simple circuits and electronic amplifiers using transistors.
  3. Properly use various laboratory detection instruments such as the oscilloscope, digital multi-meters, signal generators and signal counters.
  4. Read simple electronic schematics containing resistors, capacitors, inductors, transistors, amplifiers, diodes, and other solid state devices.
  5. Identify an unknown gas using spectroscopic techniques.
  6. Measure the rate of radioactive decay of a substance and determine its half life.
  7. Use matrix operations to determine quantum states.
  8. Analyze periodic wave signals using Fourier and Laplace transforms.
  9. Write a coherent laboratory report, including error analysis.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Special and current topics in physics may be available. See "Class Schedule Search" for a complete listing each term. Offered on: A-E-G / 3-4 cr. hrs.

Honors special topics in physics may be available for Honors students as well as those who have received permission from campus honors program coordinator. See "Class Schedule Search" for a complete listing each term. Offered on: A-E-G / 3-4 cr. hrs.
Independent study courses in physics may be available. See the online catalog for a complete listing or contact academic chair. Offered on: A-E-G / 1-4 cr. hrs.

CourseInventory.CourseLongTitle: Foundations for Success in Practical Nursing
CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Introduction to the profession of practical nursing. The role of the practical nurse, ethical and legal considerations, and therapeutic nurse-patient relationships are discussed. Communication skills and medical terminology are explored. Study skills, test-taking, and problem solving skills needed to succeed in the nursing profession are emphasized. Connects learning skills with those needed by the practical nurse. (offered summer semester only) Prerequisite: BIO105, ENG101, PSY101; corequisites: PNU119. Offered on: E / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. 1. Professional Behavior
    1. Adhere to standards of the New York State Practice Act
    2. Utilize and incorporate resources for lifelong learning.
  2. Communication
    1. Learn basic skills in communicating effectively with nursing personnel and other health team members
  3. Data Collection
    1. Begin to understand how to data collect with the use of the nursing process
  4. Clinical Decision Making
    1. Identify key characteristics of critical thinking
  5. Caring Interventions
    1. Develop an understanding for cultural uniqueness, sensitivity, and competence

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Fundamental principles of medication safety and patient safety-goal standards are discussed. The practical nurse's role in the prevention of medication errors is defined. Legal, ethical, and cultural considerations are also explored. Computations and measurements essential for the safe administration of medications by nurses are presented. Skill in solving dosage problems, calculating intravenous drip rates, and conversions between measurement systems is developed. (Offered summer semester only.) Prerequisite: BIO105, ENG101, PSY101. Corequisite: PNU116. Offered on: E / 2 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Professional Behaviors:
    1. Describe the role of the practical nurse in safe preparation of medication dosages
    2. Practice within the framework of the New York State Practice Act
    3. Identify potential areas for error and appropriate intervention methods
    4. Describe the national safety goal standards as they relate to medication
  2. Communication:
    1. Communicate effectively with nursing personnel and the instructor
      1. Clinical Decision Making
        1. Apply the principles of three checks and five rights
        2. Identify potential areas for error and appropriate intervention methods
      2. Caring Interventions
        1. Demonstrate caring with clients and significant others through the safe administration of medications
      3. Collaboration
        1. Function as a client advocate by maintaining the national safety goal standards

CourseInventory.CourseLongTitle: Fundamentals of Nursing for Practical Nurses
CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Provides the foundation for subsequent nursing courses. The study of basic nursing concepts, as well as stress and adaptation theory, is emphasized. Through the use of the nursing process, health and fulfillment of basic human needs are assessed. Dysfunctional adaptation caused by stress is assessed with emphasis on health promotion and maintenance. College laboratory and clinical experience in healthcare settings are used to develop and apply nursing theories and skills. Registration requires that students purchase liability insurance through the college. (Offered fall semester only.) (5 hrs. lecture, 2 hrs. laboratory, 6 hrs. clinical) Prerequisite: PNU116, PNU119. Corequisite: PNU128. Offered on: E / 8 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. PROFESSIONAL BEHAVIORS
    1. Understand legal aspects involved in the care of individuals
    2. Practice within the framework of the New York State Practice Act
  2. COMMUNICATION
    1. Communicate effectively with nursing personnel and other health team members.
  3. DATA COLLECTION
    1. Collect data related to adult clients’ problems by identifying stressors and adaptive responses
  4. CLINICAL DECISION MAKING(with the RN)
    1. Apply foundational knowledge from social, biological sciences and humanities to nursing care of adults from various religious and sociocultural backgrounds, with acute or chronic health problems.
    2. Utilize the nursing process and critical thinking to prioritize planning and provision of nursing care for clients with selected stressors.
    3. Implement interventions to assist the client toward positive outcomes.
    4. Modify client care as indicated by evaluation of outcomes.
  5. CARING INTERVENTIONS
    1. Demonstrate empathy and caring with clients and significant others through effective therapeutic communication skills.
  6. TEACHING AND LEARNING
    1. Identify the clients’ ability to learn.
    2. Identify client’s learning needs.
    3. Apply teaching and learning concepts to assist individual adult clients in maintaining wellness and/or self-care management of illness.
    4. Evaluate the progress of the individual in achievement of identified learning outcomes.
    5. Assist client to identify community resources.
  7. COLLABORATION
    1. Work cooperatively with others to achieve client outcomes.
    2. Function as a client advocate.

CourseInventory.CourseShortTitle: Nurs. Care of Adult Clients I
CourseInventory.CourseLongTitle: Nursing Care of Adult Clients I
CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Focuses on the study of geriatric client and the client with a mental health disorder. Normal physiological and psychological changes associate with the aging process are discussed. The nursing process is utilized in the study of the geriatric client and the adult with a mental health disorder when response to stressors has resulted in illness. Adaptation and stress management are promoted for adults who manifest their response to stress with physical or mental illness Clinical experiences in various health settings are utilized to develop and apply nursing theory and skills. Registration requires that students purchase liability insurance through the College. (offered fall semester only) (2 hrs. lecture, 3 hrs. clinical) Prerequisite: PNU116, PNU119. Corequisite: PNU120. Offered on: E / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. PROFESSIONAL BEHAVIORS
    1. Understand legal aspects involved in the care of individuals
    2. Practice within the framework of the New York State Practice Act
    3. Maintain confidentiality
  2. COMMUNICATION
    1. Communicate effectively with nursing personnel and other health team members.
  3. DATA COLLECTION
    1. Collect data regarding the client’s problems by identifying stressors and adaptive responses.
  4. CLINICAL DECISION MAKING (with the RN)
    1. Apply foundational knowledge from social, biological sciences and humanities to nursing care of adults from various religious and sociocultural backgrounds with acute or chronic physical and mental health problems.
    2. Utilize the nursing process and critical thinking to prioritize planning and provision of nursing care for clients with selected stressors.
    3. With the RN implement interventions to assist the client toward positive outcomes.
    4. Modify client care as indicated by evaluation of outcomes.
  5. CARING INTERVENTIONS
    1. Demonstrate empathy and caring with clients and significant others through effective use of communication skills.
  6. TEACHING AND LEARNING
    1. Identify client’s learning needs.
    2. Identify client’s ability to learn.
    3. Apply teaching and learning concepts to assist individual adult clients in maintaining wellness and/or self-care management of illness.
    4. Along with the RN, evaluate the progress of the individual in achievement of identified learning outcomes.
    5. Assist the client in identifying community resources.
  7. COLLABORATION
    1. Identify collaborative services within the agency that facilitate plan of care.
    2. Work cooperatively with others to achieve client outcome. Function as a client advocate.

CourseInventory.CourseShortTitle: Nurs. Care of Adult Clients II
CourseInventory.CourseLongTitle: Nursing Care of Adult Clients II
CourseInventory.CourseDescription: The nursing process is utilized in the study of adult health when response to stressors has resulted in illness. Adaptation and stress management are promoted for adults who manifest their response to stress by developing acute and chronic physical illnesses. Clients with multiple and complex health problems are explored. Experiences to integrate nursing theory and skill include the laboratory on campus and clinical experiences in health care settings. Registration requires that students purchase liability insurance through the College. (offered spring semester only) (5 hrs. lecture, 2 hrs. laboratory, 6 hrs. clinical) Prerequisite: PNU116, PNU119, PNU120, PNU128. Corequisite: PNU135. Offered on: E / 8 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. PROFESSIONAL BEHAVIORS
    1. Understand legal aspects involved in the care of individuals.
    2. Practice within the framework of the New York State Practice Act.
  2. COMMUNICATION
    1. Communicate effectively with nursing personnel and other health team members.
  3. DATA COLLECTION
    1. Collect data regarding adult client’s problems by identifying stressors and adaptive responses.
  4. CLINICAL DECISION MAKING (along with the RN)
    1. Apply foundational knowledge from social ,biological sciences and humanities to nursing care of adults from various religious and sociocultural backgrounds, with acute or chronic health problems.
    2. Utilize the nursing process and critical thinking to prioritize planning and provision of nursing care for clients with selected stressors.
    3. Implement interventions to assist the client toward positive outcomes
    4. Modify client care as indicated by evaluation of outcomes.
  5. CARING INTERVENTIONS
    1. Demonstrate empathy and caring with clients and significant others through effective use of therapeutic communication.
  6. TEACHING AND LEARNING
    1. Identify client’s learning needs.
    2. Identify client’s understanding.
    3. Apply teaching and learning concepts to assist individual adult clients in maintaining wellness and /or self-care management of illness.
    4. Evaluate the progress of the individual in achievement of identified learning outcomes.
    5. Assist client to identify community resources.
  7. COLLABORATION
    1. Identify collaborative services within the agency that facilitates plan of care.
    2. Work cooperatively with others to achieve client outcomes. Function as a client advocate.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: The study of family health beginning with the mother and newborn during the childbearing process. The topic is continued through the study of the normal growth and development of the pediatric client. The nursing process is utilized in the study of family health incorporating responses and adaptation to stress. Adaptation and stress management is promoted with families during the childbearing process and with the ill pediatric client. Experiences to integrate nursing theory and skills include clinical experiences in healthcare settings and community agencies. Registration requires that students purchase liability insurance through the College. (offered spring semester only) (2 hrs. lecture, 3 hrs. clinical) Prerequisite: PNU116, PNU119, PNU120, PNU128. Corequisite: PNU133. Offered on: E / 3 cr. hrs.
CourseInventory.CourseLearningObjectives:
1. Professional Behavior
    1. Adhere to standards of New York State Practice Act.
    2. Utilize and incorporate resources for lifelong learning.
    3. Understand legal consideration in the care of the client and the family.
  2. Communication
    1. Demonstrate skill in communicating effectively according to the development of the child and family and members of the healthcare team.
    2. Utilize information technology to meet the needs of the client and to assist childbearing families to use self-management skills.
  3. Data Collection
    1. Collect data to identify problems related to the effects of stressors on the childrearing unit.
  4. Clinical Decision Making (with the RN)
    1. Identify dysfunctional health patterns and stressors of the individual and family in Community, school and clinical settings using evidence-based practice to formulate judgments that facilitate health promotion and maintenance.
    2. Have an understanding of cultural and spiritual differences and developmental Needs when caring for the child rearing family in order to provide sensitive, holistic nursing care.
  5. Caring Interventions
    1. Perform effective therapeutic and preventative nursing measures to facilitate health promotion and maintenance for the childrearing family.
  6. Teaching and Learning
    1. Advocate health promotion, identify learning needs of the childrearing family and modify interventions according to developmental level
    2. Evaluate the effectiveness of teaching with return demonstration when possible.
  7. Collaboration
    1. Collaborate with additional multidisciplinary team members to deliver cost effective quality individual and family nursing care.
    2. Convey mutual respect, trust, support and appreciation of each discipline’s unique roles and contributions to health care.

CourseInventory.CourseDescription: Special and current topics in practical nursing may be available. See "Class Schedule Search" for a complete listing each term. Offered on: E / 3-4 cr. hrs.

Court structure, courtroom testimony, laws of evidence and arrest, search and seizure, justification for use of force, confession and admissions and related subjects. No prerequisite. Offered on: G / 3 cr. hrs.

Enables students to perform various exercises designed to improve cardiovascular endurance, muscular strength and flexibility.
